``It's an outrage. These policies have encouraged the criminal element to stay in our community. People are prisoners in their apartments. They're even afraid to go shopping.'' _ Leslie Dutton, a resident of Santa Monica, Calif., complaining about the city's benevolent policy towards the homeless.
``My legs are buckling. I feel so sore.'' _ Ethel Levine, a secretary in Manhattan's financial district who had to walk down 33 floors after a fire knocked out power in the area.

DOC.HEAD: Paper: Four Belgian Captives to Be Freed
DOC.TEXT: A Beirut newspaper claimed today the radical Palestinian faction of terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal would release four Belgian hostages Wednesday. A Belgian government source dismissed the report by the newspaper Al-Lima, saying ``it is not the first time this paper has had a story like that.'' The official spoke on condition of anonymity in Brussels. The front-page report, attributed to unidentified Western diplomatic sources, said the four would be released Wednesday in a deal that includes the release of convicted Palestinian terrorist Sa'eed Nasser ``by a special pardon signed by the king of Belgium.'' It said the deal was worked out between Belgian officials and Fatah-Revolutionary Council and a Belgian press team is to arrive in Lebanon ``in the next few hours to cover the release of the four hostages.'' It did not disclose further details. The newspaper does not have a record of accurate reporting on the issue of the Belgian captives. A similar report last month predicting the hostages' July 21 release proved unfounded. Walid Khaled, Fatah-RC spokesman on the hostage issue, also declined to discuss the report.``We'll inform you of any developments,'' Khaled said in an interview. Fatah-RC said in 1987 it seized the four Belgians aboard their boat, Silco, off the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip. Newspapers have reported the hostages were kept in Libya, and that they had been abducted by the Libyan navy, not by Abu Nidal's group. They are Emmanuel Houtekins, 44, his wife, Godlieve Kets, 50, their son, Laurent, 20, and daughter, Valerie, 18. Five other people were seized with them, including three children. Two of the children were freed in 1988 and the rest last April. Sa'eed, believed to be a Fatah-RC member, is serving a life sentence in Belgium for killing a Jewish youth and injuring 20 others in a 1980 grenade attack. He became eligible for parole July 27. Several unconfirmed news reports have said Belgian authorities would pardon the Palestinian terrorist in exchange for release of the four hostages. Because the Belgian captives are not believed held in Lebanon, they are not classified among the 14 Western hostages kidnapped mainly by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem factions. Six Americans are among those Western hostages. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Six Servicemen Die in Training Exercise
DOC.TEXT: Six soldiers died when a blizzard trapped them during a winter training exercise, officials said today. Police spokesman Sgt. Darryl Nix said the bodies were found Monday only 150 yards from an emergency shelter on 9,177-foot Mount Ruapehu. The hut has six bunks and emergency rations, but it ``may as well have been 150 miles in those conditions,'' Nix said. The bodies will remain on the mountain until the weather clears so rescue teams and helicopters can move in safely. It was raining heavily today. The victims, ranging in age from 18 to 23, were part of a 13-member army and navy group which had been on the mountain since Thursday as part of an adventure training course. When a blizzard cut off their escape from the mountain, they were forced to dig in. Two of the soldiers began an 11-hour trek Sunday night to find help. When a search party reached the group Monday afternoon, six already were dead. The other five were brought down for treatment of exposure. Parliament observed a minute's silence for the victims today. A military court of inquiry into the deaths was scheduled to begin Wednesday. Mount Ruapehu is in the rugged center of New Zealand's North Island, about 100 miles south of Hamilton.

DOC.HEAD: Decision to Send Ships Proves Controversial
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Bob Hawke's decision to send Navy ships to the Persian Gulf is proving controversial in a country sensitive to any suggestions that it serves U.S. interests. The painful memory of involvement in Vietnam, Korea and virtually every other major conflict this century also has made Australians nervous about sending two guided-missile frigates, a supply ship and some 600 men to a conflict halfway around the globe. While Hawke's decision has been supported by the opposition, it has been criticized by the Arab community, small political parties, environmental and peace groups, and even some members of his own Labor Party. President Bush called Hawke on Friday to ask for an Australian contingent to participate in the attempt to stop Iraqi shipping to punish Baghdad for invading Kuwait. After the 20-minute chat, Hawke reportedly consulted with several key ministers. Then, without a formal Cabinet meeting, he announced he would send three ships, citing ``the gravity of the situation.'' The opposition Liberal party backed the move, but Janet Powell, leader of the Democratic Party, called Hawke's decision ``ill-considered, dangerous and undemocratic.'' ``Yet again, we have taken military action in a knee-jerk response to a request from the United States,'' she said. ``Tough diplomacy and sanctions, backed up by the U.N. policing, if needed, is the only way out of this mess. Any military `solution,' which would involve invading Kuwait and probably Iraq, could well spark chemical and nuclear warfare.'' The New Left Party in Victoria state also backed a U.N. settlement of the crisis. El Telegraph, an Arabic-language newspaper with a circulation of about 30,000, said a survey it was conducting of Australia's Arab community showed overwhelming condemnation of Hawke's decision. Hawke on Monday compared his critics to the politicians who tried to appease Nazi Germany. ``The crimes of the appeasers were, in a sense, as great as the crimes of Hitler and the Nazis,'' he told reporters while attending farewell ceremonies for the frigates. ``We wouldn't have had the Second World War if there hadn't been appeasers .... You can't stand idly by and allow those things to happen.'' Australia's interests in the gulf are primarily export-related, although about 127 Australians have been unable to leave Iraq and Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Former Time Editor Hedley Donovan Dead at 76
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS graf with memorial service.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY51 of Aug. 13
DOC.TEXT: Hedley Donovan, the former editor in chief at Time Inc. who oversaw the growth of Sports Illustrated, the founding of Money magazine and People and the re-birth of Life, has died at age 76. He died Monday at New York Hospital of an acute infection, the hospital said. He had a chronic lung condition. Donovan took over Time Inc. in 1964 as the hand-picked successor of Henry Luce, the staunch conservative who founded the magazine and had been its only editor in chief. Donovan gave Time a less ideological stance. He retired in 1979. He was responsible for the content of some of the nation's most widely read magazines. Time, Life, Fortune and Sports Illustrated had a combined circulation of more than 13 million in the United States and 50 million worldwide. Donovan also presided over the growth of Sports Illustrated's popularity, the founding of Money in 1972 and of People two years later and the success of Time-Life books. The once-popular weekly Life was suspended in 1972, but the photo magazine was resurrected as a monthly. Donovan also regulated the tradition under Luce of separating Time magazine's business and news operations. He created what came to be known as the Donovan Doctrine, which made the editor in chief answerable only to the board of directors. Donovan once said he tried to make Time magazine ``more thoughtful and more fair-minded.'' During his 15-year tenure _ which included the Vietnam War and Watergate scandal _ Time magazine stopped reflecting the conservative views of Luce, a staunch Republican with strong views on communism, China and other subjects. Donovan enjoyed the access his position afforded him to presidents, popes and other world figures. The job was ``wonderful,'' Donovan said, ``one in which it is impossible to say, `This is work and that is fun.''' On retirement, he became a non-salaried adviser to President Carter. He left before the 1980 election. Donovan wrote ``From Roosevelt to Reagan: A Reporter's Encounters with Nine Presidents,'' in 1985, and an autobiography, ``Right Places, Right Times: Forty Years in Journalism, Not Counting My Paper Route,'' published in 1989. Hedley Williams Donovan was born in Brainerd, Minn., the son of a mining engineer. He graduated magna cum laude from the University of Minnesota in 1934. He won a Rhodes scholarship and studied in 1936 at Oxford University, where he was campus correspondent for United Press. In 1937, he joined The Washington Post. He went on to cover Congress, the State Department and the White House. He left to serve in Naval intelligence in World War II. After the war, he joined Fortune, a Time-Life publication. He was named an associate editor at Fortune in 1951 and managing editor in 1953. He held that post until 1959, when Luce, looking for a potential successor after suffering a serious heart attack, made Donovan his chief deputy. Donovan was also a director of the Council on Foreign Relations, a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and a member of the Trilateral Commission. He lived in New York City and Sands Point, N.Y. He is survived by two sons and a daughter. His wife, Dorothy, died in 1978. A memorial service was scheduled for Thursday at the Congregational Church of Manhasset, on New York's Long Island.

DOC.HEAD: Elvis Sightings No Longer Big Talk at Death Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: As the faithful gather for the 13th anniversary of Elvis Presley's death, the question this year is not whether the King is really gone but whether he was a victim of suicide, accident or murder. Authors of a soon-to-be-published book say they'll give the first detailed report on his autopsy and show that Presley, a pill-popper of the first order, miscalculated the combined effect of various uppers and downers and died of an overdose. That not-surprising conclusion comes from Charles Thompson II and James P. Cole, authors of ``The Death of Elvis Presley,'' to be published in January by Delacorte Press. ``The conclusion is inescapable that this was an accidental drug overdose,'' said Cole, a former reporter and editor for two Memphis newspapers. Thompson, a ``60 Minutes'' producer, said he and Cole obtained from one of several doctors who worked on Presley's autopsy the sealed autopsy records they had sought for 11 years. The Shelby County medical examiner said Presley died of heart disease and the autopsy report was sealed at the family's request. Presley died Aug. 16, 1977 at his Memphis estate, Graceland, now a tourist attraction drawing more than 600,000 visitors a year. Graceland managers say up to 10,000 Elvis fans will take part this week in events tied to the anniversary of his death. Presley's abuse of prescription drugs has been discussed often in print and in court since 1977, but at the time of his death, friends and family wanted to keep down such talk ``to make the hometown boy look as good as possible,'' Cole said. ``Now we've got the complete record and people will be able to see for themselves what the documentation is,'' he said. At the Elvis anniversary two years ago, the hot talk was about a new book titled ``Is Elvis Alive?'' A flurry of Elvis sightings at fast-food restaurants and other sites around the country soon followed. Now there are new Elvis reports. Albert Goldman, author of the 1981 biography ``Elvis,'' said in a recent article in Life magazine that Presley killed himself with an intentional overdose. Murray Silver, co-author of a book on Jerry Lee Lewis, has been talking to publishers about an Elvis book to be written with the singer's former physician. Silver's book reportedly would say Presley suffered a blow to the neck, perhaps a karate chop, shortly before his death. Todd Morgan, a spokesman for Graceland, said managers of the Presley estate still believe the original conclusion: heart disease. ``We're not going to go head to head with the people who write these books. There's no benefit to it,'' Morgan said. ``Our getting into a big row with people like that just triples the publicity for their books.'' And anyway, he said, the public is ``getting pretty tired'' of the stories.

DOC.HEAD: Missouri 4-H Fashion Contest Gets First Boy Winner
DOC.TEXT: A boy's needle-and-thread work beat all the budding seamstresses at the State 4-H Fashion Revue, the first time a tailor-in-training took top honors in the 40-year history of the competition ``This is awesome. I can't believe it,'' said Paul Wilson, 17, of Hermann after placing first Saturday in the female-dominated contest. Wilson personally modeled his winning entry: a double-breasted, fully lined wool suit. ``They started calling off the top five. They called four girls, then me. Mom let out a gasp you could hear all over the room. Then she cried,'' Wilson said. His mother Marlene is his sewing coach. ``I enjoy sewing. It's a life skill. You never know when you could fall and rip your pants,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Obese Woman To Fight State's Effort to Yank Driver's License
DOC.TEXT: A woman who weighs 367 and stands 5 feet, 6{ inches tall is fighting for her driver's license. Police say her girth makes her a driving hazard. Regina Elizabeth Guy was asked to explain at a meeting set for Friday why the Motor Vehicle Administration should not revoke her license. The 25-year-old nursing assistant hired a lawyer and said Monday this is a fight against discrimination against fat people everywhere. ``Fat is not a four-letter word,'' she said. ``It's a description. That's all.'' Her troubles began in July when she was stopped while driving a friend's car with expired registration tags. Last week she got a letter from the MVA saying it was re-examining her driving privilege. It asked her to attend the hearing. The letter quoted the patrol officer who stopped her as saying her girth made it impossible for her to sit directly behind the steering wheel. She ``had to operate her 1978 Pontiac station wagon from the center of the front seat,'' the officer wrote. ``She was steering with her left hand and was using her left foot to control the pedals. I feel that this driver should have special equipment on her car.'' ``They say she is pushing a gas pedal with her left foot,'' attorney Christopher P. Brown said. ``If I would do that it is not a crime. There is no issue of safety here. They are treating a fat person differently.'' Guy denied she was driving from the center of the front seat. The National Association for the Advancement of Fat Acceptance plans a demonstration of support before the hearing.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Spot South, West; Most Areas Sunny
DOC.TEXT: Moisture in the air created hazy conditions in parts of the South early today and fog in the East. Showers fell in Arizona while the remainder of the country had mostly clear skies. Lingering wet weather was expected to end in most of the East as a high pressure system brought clearing skies, but continued humid conditions. Highs in the 80s were expected. Showers were developing over Maine, the result of a low pressure system, and thunderstorm activity was possible in Virginia and North Carolina. Sunshine and hot weather were expected in most of the South with highs in the 90s. Scattered showers were possible in Mississippi and Arkansas. The Midwest was expected to enjoy sunny skies and low humidity, with highs in the 80s. Thunderstorms and high humidity welled in the Southwest with rain expected in Arizona, New Mexico and Colorado. Temperatures for the region were forecast to climb into the 90s and 100s. Sunny, cool weather was forecast for the Northwest, with highs only in the 60s and 70s. The high temperature in the nation Monday was 105 degrees at California City, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Celebrities, Environmental Leaders Celebrate Walden Pond Preservation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `Thoreau was ...' to CORRECT typo to mid-1800s sted mid-1880s.
DOC.TEXT: Celebrities led by rock 'n' roll singer Don Henley have halted a condominium project on woodlands next to Walden Pond, where Henry David Thoreau contemplated nature in solitude more than a century ago. Henley, former member of the Eagles rock group, announced Monday that the celebrities' Walden Woods Project and the non-profit Trust for Public Land have made a $100,000 down payment on the 25-acre parcel valued at $3.55 million. The land will remain unspoiled, and a new site for the 139-unit housing project will be provided in nearby Concord. The settlement with housing officials and developers included provisions to save another 25-acre parcel from becoming an office and parking garage if a new site can be found. ``I think the word balance describes what we hope to achieve in Walden Woods,'' Henley said. He is co-chairman of the Walden Woods Project, whose advisory board includes actors Michael Douglas and Meryl Streep and Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass. The Trust for Public Land works to preserve land threatened by development. Henley, joined by singers Bonnie Raitt and Jimmy Buffett, performed two concerts in April that raised $250,000 to preserve the woods. ``It's easy to say no to a project,'' said Clark L. Ziegler, a spokesman for the state Office of Communities and Development. ``But people who were opposed to it have taken on the responsibility of finding an alternative solution. That's unusual.'' Walden Pond is a 62-acre body of water on a state reservation bordering Concord, an affluent town of 12,500 about 20 miles northwest of Boston. Thoreau was a naturalist writer who lived in isolation by the pond during the mid-1800s. He produced essays and other writings from his solitude. The pond is far less pastoral than when he lived there in a shack. It lies less than 100 yards from a highway and is adjacent to a dump. Other celebrities who helped to save the woods include actors Don Johnson, Ed Begley Jr. and Dana Delany. Also lending support were author E.L. Doctorow and singers Arlo Guthrie, Aimee Mann, John Hall and the band Boston.

DOC.HEAD: French Separatist Trounces Rival For Parliament Seat
DOC.TEXT: A French separatist has trounced a rival to win a Parliament seat in a special election in a district outside Montreal. The victory in Monday's election makes Gilles Duceppe the first parliamentarian elected under the banner of the Bloc Quebecois, a group of independent lawmakers committed to Quebec sovereignty. Duceppe, 43, immediately declared that his victory was a message to English Canada that Quebec is heading quickly toward a break with the rest of the country. ``Quebec has understood that English Canada will never say yes to Quebec demands,'' the labor negotiator told cheering supporters at a victory party. He was propelled to victory by a surge in separatist sentiment in Quebec after the death of the Meech Lake accord in June. The proposed consitutional amendement, rejected by Manitoba and New Brunswick provinces, would have given provinces special powers and recognized Quebec as a ``distinct society'' within Canada. Gilles picked up about two-thirds of all votes cast in the sububan Laurier-Ste-Marie district, trouncing his nearest rival, Liberal Denis Coderre. New Democrat candidate Louise O`Neill was a poor third and Conservative Christian Fortin finished fourth. In another special election, New Democrat Mike Breaugh handily defeated his opponents in the Ontario district of Oshawa. Breaugh had represented the district since December, when New Democrat leader Ed Broadbent retired.

DOC.HEAD: East German Farmers, Lumber Workers Protest in West Berlin
DOC.TEXT: East German workers drove tractors, combines and lumber trucks into West Berlin today, demanding help from East and West German governments for their struggling farms and forest industry. Farmers and lumber workers have been among the hardest hit by the massive changes sweeping East Germany. They're seeking higher wages and job security. Imported products from the West have cut demand for East German items. Inefficiency is another bone of contention. ``We have such old machines, some of them made before the war,'' said 20-year-old Alexander Witt during the protest at the historic Reichstag building. ``We're supposed to compete in a capitalist system, but it's hard with such old machines that often break down and need repairs and maintenance,'' he continued. Reflecting on the complexities that still pervade the East German economy, Witt said he was not a ``farmer'' but rather an ``expert for plant production.'' His job: ``preparing the soil, sowing and harvesting.'' Witt, from Schoenefeld outside Berlin, was one of about 70 workers who had gathered by late morning in front of the Reichstag, the massive building to become the parliament of a united Germany. The protesters drove there in more than 35 farm and forestry vehicles, with dozens more expected by the afternoon. All wore rough work clothes, often flecked with dirt. Some took the opportunity to sell their products, which have been unable to compete with Western goods flooding East Germany. ``If we don't sell, we can't keep working,'' shouted a burly farm worker as he sold potatoes and peppers. The banner on the side of his truck read: ``We can't go on like this.'' East Germany's agricultural sector _ driven by four decades by Communist governments before the inauguration of a non-Communist, free-market administration this year _ is collapsing under the weight of competition. About half of the farms are technically bankrupt, economists say. That means hard times for the 800,000 farmers who till the country's Soviet-style collectives. They face an uncertain feature when the two Germanys merge later this year. Most of the workers taking part in today's protest said they earned about $500 to $550 a month in base pay, adding they needed overtime to survive. Forest workers are having similarly difficult times. ``The sawmills won't take our wood any more,'' said lumber truck driver Edwin Braun. ``They take wood from Bavaria and the Soviet Union, but not ours.'' ``And our wood is still cheaper. It just doesn't make any sense,'' said Braun, from the town of Neustrelitz about 60 miles north of Berlin. Banners on the huge vehicles demanded support from the West German and East German governments. One predicted a ``hot autumn'' if East Germany's agricultural business continues its dangerous plunge.

DOC.HEAD: For American GIs, Baking, Waiting in the Desert Sun
EDITOR'S NOTE _ The following is based on a pool dispatch written by John King of The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: For one American soldier, deployment in Saudi Arabia is a honeymoon of sorts. The specialist, based at Fort Bragg, N.C., was scheduled to be married on Aug. 11, but was called for duty in Saudi Arabia a few days before then. ``My wife, then my fiancee, and I got to thinking that I might not come back so, we decided to go ahead and do it,'' said the specialist, among a contingent from the 82nd Airborne set up at a Saudi air defense camp. The Saudi desert has the specialist from Monroeville, Ala., thinking about changing his honeymoon plans. ``We were supposed to go to Florida but now maybe we'll go someplace better,'' he said. ``With this heat, maybe we'll go to Alaska.'' Ground rules for the Pentagon pool operation prohibit disclosure of the exact location and publication of the names of American troops deployed here to defend Saudi Arabia from a possible Iraqi attack. The 82nd Airborne troops visited Tuesday are living in tents on the Saudi complex, surrounded by M551-Sheridan airborne assault vehicles, a light tank, antitank vehicles equipped with TOW missiles and other weapons. When they arrived, their worries were potential battles with Iraqi troops and possible use of chemical weapons against them. Now, with Iraqi forces taking up defensive positions and the burgeoning American force digging in as well, the troops here are more worried about family back home and beating the intense desert heat. Temperatures were approaching 100 degrees when the pool visited the troops at 10 a.m. local time Tuesday and were expected to reach 115 degrees or higher by afternoon. The reddish sand of the desert can be seen for miles; shade is almost impossible to find. The most popular spot here is the maintenance garage, which offers a respite from the sun and _ by Saudi standards _ a cooling breeze. All of the American forces here are told to drink at least six gallons of water a day to avoid dehydration in the searing heat. These rapid-deployment forces were called into action so quickly that many said they did not get to say goodbye to family and friends. ``The last time I saw my wife was 5 a.m. the day I left,'' said one staff sergeant. ``She wasn't home when I got the call to go. So I got a quick note off before I left and wrote her from Spain on the way over.'' One of the few complaints from the soldiers is that they think the U.S. government should provide them with a free mail system. ``I didn't have time to get any money,'' said the staff sergeant, based at Fort Bragg and originally from New York. All of a dozen soldiers interviewed asked that reporters let family and friends back home know they were safe. ``I hope the American people realize the need for us to be here,'' one lieutenant said. ``As leaders of the free world we cannot allow this type of aggression to take place. No one really likes being here but we've got a job to do and we're eager to do it.'' A lieutenant interviewed atop a Sheridan tank said morale has been ``outstanding'' and that troops are beginning to adjust to the heat. ``We're settling in now,'' he said. ``We came in expecting anything from going into a peacetime mission to total war. In Panama we went in knowing it was a combat situation right off the bat.'' The troops left the states so quickly they could not bring any gear for recreation activities. So now they mostly sit and wait. Those assigned to day shifts say sleeping at night, when temperatures drop into the 80s, isn't so bad. There are rows of tents for those who need to sleep during the day, but they provide little escape from the dry heat. ``We'd rather sit and wait than go and fight but it's frustrating,'' said the lieutenant. The staff sergeant had a different perspective. ``If I have to come this far and go through all this trouble I'd rather get out there and fight, take care of business,'' he said. Saudi forces brought the American troops sandwiches and fries from a Hardees fast-food restaurant and also have brought breakfasts of bread, fruit and cheeses. But several said they would prefer to eat their Army-issued MREs _ meals ready to eat. ``No offense, because the Saudis have been great hosts, but things just taste a little different,'' said one sergeant. All of the troops have chemical warfare suits with them and gas masks strapped to their hips. ``You hear little rumors about it (the possibility of chemical attacks) from time to time but you just press on,'' another sergeant from Fort Bragg said as he stood next to a huge satellite communications disk. ``We've got a lot of duties to take care of here so you can't worry too much.'' Said a sergeant from Mt. Airy, N.C.: ``You can't worry about the gas or chemicals. You take in the equipment and if you need to use it you do. We're trained and ready.'' Gen. Ed Scholes, commander of the forward command forces here, said ``our troops are prepared for that and ready for it if it comes. ... You're always concerned about that prospect but our troops here are trained in that and they have the equipment.'' Scholes described the mission as ``deterrence, assisting and training the Saudis and if necessary assisting them in the defense of the kingdom of Saudi Arabia.'' Part of the 82nd's current work, he said, was securing an area for the arrival of Marines and equipment. Scholes and the troops reported few equipment problems associated with the heat. ``There are obvious problems in operating in this environment but we've had nothing unusual,'' the general said. Some radio failures have been blamed on the heat. Army officials said last week that units with tanks and other vehicles would need additional air filters and higher viscosity oil to keep running in the desert environment. As much a problem as the heat is the talcum-like sand of the desert.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Hostage Freed By Palestinian Group
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Erriquez leaving for Switzerland. Pick up 4th graf pvs, `In Geneva...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DAM1
DOC.TEXT: Former Swiss hostage Elio Erriquez headed home today, his first full day of freedom after Palestinian kidnappers in Lebanon released him to Syrian officials. ``I am happy, very, very happy,'' Erriquez said at the Foreign Ministry minutes after his arrival in the Syrian capital. He was then whisked away by Swiss Ambassador Eric Pfister. Erriquez, 24, later left for Geneva. He and another Swiss national, Emanuel Christen, were kidnapped Oct. 6 near a clinic run by the International Committee of the Red Cross where they worked in Sidon. Christen, 33, was released from captivity a week ago. In Geneva, the relief organization's president, Cornelio Sommaruga, today welcomed the release and made a ``pressing appeal'' for the freeing of all other hostages. Swiss Foreign Minister Rene Felber joined the appeal. He said Switzerland would make available its information and its diplomatic cooperation to all countries which still had citizens held captive in Lebanon. The kidnappers turned Erriquez over to Syrian officials in Lebanon and Syria's state minister for foreign affairs, Nasser Qaddour, passed him to Pfister later the same day. Erriquez, wearing a white shirt and white pants, looked pale but in good health after his 10-month ordeal. He was taken to Pfister's residence and there was no word on when he would leave Syria. In Geneva, his mother, Graziana Erriquez, spent agonizing hours Monday before receiving official confirmation that her son was free. ``Waiting for the definite word was bad,'' she said. ``I had been waiting all day long. But now, I am very happy.'' In Beirut, a late-night communique from a group calling itself the Palestinian Revolutionary Squads said Erriquez was released to a representative of Brig. Gen. Ghazi Kenaan, chief of Syria's military intelligence in Lebanon. The 30-word handwritten statement in Arabic was delivered to a Western news agency in Beirut along with a black-and-white photograph of the hostage. But it gave no details about when or where he was released. The group said Erriquez, an orthopedic specialist, was freed from 10 months in captivity at the behest of Syria, Libya and Algeria. Erriquez and Christen were kidnapped by masked gunmen near a Red Cross center in Sidon, 25 miles south of Beirut. Police had blamed the abduction on Fatah-Revolutionary Council, a radical guerrilla group led by Palestinian terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal. The group denied the accusation. In its statement, the Palestinian Revolutionary Squads denied any connection to Abu Nidal or any other Palestinian faction. It paid ``particular tribute to Mustafa Saad for efficient role to ensure a success'' of the release. Saad heads the leftist Nasserite Popular Organization militia, which has controlled Sidon since the outbreak of Lebanon's civil war in 1975. Erriquez's release left 14 Western hostages in Lebanon, most held by underground Shiite Moslem extremists loyal to Iran. The captives are six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, an Irishman and an Italian. Longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Six-Day Parts Strike Shows GM's Vulnerability
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Voting not set to begin until 2 p.m. EDT; should stand for PMs. A version moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: A tentative settlement has been reached in a strike at a General Motors Corp. parts plant, but the walkout highlighted the giant automaker's vulnerability to local labor problems. The 2,800 United Auto Workers union members at the AC Rochester West parts plant in Flint walked off their jobs Wednesday in what was billed as a local dispute over health and safety and other matters. By Monday, parts shortages created by the strike forced the shutdown of four assembly plants and partial closings of four component factories, idling about 11,500 employees. A tentative agreement was reached Monday afternoon and union members were to vote on it this afternoon. Spokesman John Maciarz said GM hoped the strikers would return to work by Wednesday making fuel tanks and grilles for a variety of GM cars and trucks. But it will take longer for assembly plant workers to get back to their jobs since the parts pipelines to those plants have been dried up, Maciarz said. The rippling effect of the parts plant strike is a symptom of a ``just-in-time'' delivery system embraced by automakers. It calls for parts to be delivered to assembly plants sometimes just hours before they are needed on assembly lines. The strike came as the UAW was negotiating three-year contracts with GM, Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. covering more than 450,000 workers. Current UAW agreements with the Big Three expire Sept. 14. Labor experts said Monday that the strike may indicate that UAW leaders want GM to be the company the union chooses to bargain with first, to set the pattern for contracts at the other automakers. Dale Brickner of Michigan State University's School of Labor and Industrial Relations said it was significant that the international union didn't press the local at the parts plant not to strike in order to avoid friction at the national negotiations. ``The important point is the fact that the international hasn't clamped down, saying, `No, you can't do this because of negotiations going on,''' Brickner said. By Monday afternoon, GM shut down truck assembly plants in Moraine, Ohio; Shreveport, La.; and Pontiac; and a car plant in Flint. Other car plants near Pontiac and in Wentzville, Mo., outside St. Louis were in danger of closure. About 1,000 other workers were laid off when production was cut at component plants in Flint; Kokomo, Ind.; and Warren, Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: Jordan Keeps an Iraqi Oil Spout Open; Dubai Turns Away Iraqi Freighter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with reports of ship turned away, possible mining of channel, other details; No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY7,RIV1,XKNE1
DOC.TEXT: A second Iraqi ship was blocked from loading supplies at a Persian Gulf port today as a U.S.-led economic quarantine on Iraq intensified. Jordan, however, was reported keeping open a small Iraqi oil pipeline. Meanwhile, a mine alert was posted for a central Persian Gulf channel where an Iraqi ship was seen Monday, shipping sources said. President Bush cuts into his Maine vacation today to return to Washington for talks on the gulf crisis and the budget deficit. He will receive a Pentagon briefing on the military confrontation with Iraq's President Saddam Hussein. Authorities in the United Arab Emirates stopped the Iraqi freighter Al-Abid from entering the port of Dubai today, shipping sources said. Radio monitors in the Persian Gulf overheard the Al-Abid calling out every 10 minutes for permission to enter the harbor and load supplies for transport to Iraq. Diplomatic sources in the United Arab Emirates said the country's ports have quietly stopped allowing Iraqi tankers or freighters entry, although the government has made no official statements to that effect. Another Iraqi freighter, Al-Baya, has been waiting off Dubai for the last two days, the shipping sources said. They spoke on condition of anonymity. In other developments, a Japanese Foreign Ministry official said Bush asked Japan's Prime Minister Toshiko Kaifu for more Japanese financial aid to Middle East nations affected by the crisis. U.S. combat troops arriving in Saudi Arabia have been told to prepare for a long stay. U.S. navy ships maneuvered to block trade with Iraq. Bush said the Navy would halt Iraqi tankers to ``stop the oil from coming out.'' Britain and Australia also said they would help interdict Iraqi ships. The Washington Post today quoted unidentified U.N. sources as saying that at an informal, closed-door meeting of the Security Council on Monday, the Soviet Union, France, Canada and Malaysia ``sharply criticized'' the U.S. decision to proceed unilaterally with the naval quarantine of Iraq and Kuwait. A world embargo was placed on Iraq after it invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and announced it was annexing its small, oil-rich neighbor. Iraq massed troops near Saudi Arabia, sending alarm bells off throughout the Middle East. The Saudis have the world's largest oil reserves. Shipping executives said they were told by U.S. Navy officials that an Iraqi vessel was spotted dropping mines in the Shah Olam shoals, 80 miles northeast of the Qatar Peninsula. The channel is used by tankers heading for Saudi Arabian oil terminals. But another official said U.S. forces might have spotted mines left over from the Iran-Iraq war. Iran mined the waterway during the conflict, which ended in 1988. On Sunday, the Iraqi oil tanker al-Qaddisiyah was kept from docking at the Saudi terminal at Yanbu on the Red Sea after tugs failed to show up, Saudi diplomatic sources said on condition of anonymity. That, in effect, meant that Iraq's last major oil export outlet, a pipeline across the Arabian peninsula, was cut off. Turkey earlier closed two pipelines carrying Iraqi oil. However, a small Iraqi oil pipeline and road transport between Jordan and Iraq were reported operating normally Monday. Jordan's information minister, Ibrahim Izzeddine, said Jordan intends to abide by the mandatory U.N. Security resolution imposing sanctions on Iraq _ ``but it is still premature now to decide what sanctions will be imposed.'' Jordan's Foreign Ministry Undersecretary Mutasem Belbeisi said today Amman intends to discuss the economic embargo against Iraq with the United Nations. About 40 percent of Jordanian exports go to neighboring Iraq. Official sources at Jordan's Ministry of Commerce said the pipeline continued to operate as usual Monday. AP photographer Yousef Allan, at Jordan's border post of Ruweishid, 210 miles northeast of Amman, said a truck or tanker crossed into Jordan every three or four minutes. The pipeline terminates at a desert outpost known as H-4, where tanker trucks load the petroleum and drive it to the Red Sea port of Aqaba for export, with much of the oil kept for Jordanian domestic use. Visiting Rep. Stephen J. Solarz, D-N.Y., said Monday in Amman, Jordan's capital, that there was little chance of forcing Saddam to pull his forces from Kuwait without Jordanian sanctions. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the naval barricade had forced two or three ships to turn back at sea, and that ``the embargo is being maintained'' on shipping into and out of Iraq. He said the main target of the embargo is to squeeze the Iraqis so they cannot ``maintain their war machine.'' Baghdad is heavily dependent on oil exports to buy food and other supplies for its 17 million people. Saddam has asked Iraqis to cut meat consumption by half and not to hoard food, warning that black marketeers will be executed. The New York Times in today's editions reported Iraq transferred $3 billion to $4 billion in confiscated gold bullion, currency and goods from Kuwaiti institutions to Baghdad. The paper quoted Arab bankers in London and the gulf. On Monday, Pakistan voted to send troops to help defend Saudi Arabia, joining ground forces from the United States, Egypt, Morocco and Syria . Warplanes and navy ships from several nations have gathered in the region since the invasion. Today's Washington Post also quoted an unidentified Bush administration official as saying Egyptian authorities could send about 30,000 more troops, to supplement the 3,000 men dispatched to Saudi Arabia over the weekend. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said Cheney will fly to Saudi Arabia on Friday to visit U.S. troops and meet with the kingdom's leaders. It will be Cheney's second trip to the gulf since Kuwait was invaded. Maj. Gen. Don L. Kaufman, chief of the U.S. military training mission to Saudi Arabia, said Monday that planes bearing U.S. troops and equipment were landing every 10 minutes or so at a base in the desert. ``I think our position grows stronger with each day that goes by,'' he said. Saddam has called for a ``holy war'' against the Saudi royalty and Western military forces now assembled in the region. Today, Iraq remained defiant despite the naval buildup. The state newspaper Al-Jumhuriya said Iraq knows how to answer the Bush administration, ``how to foil its measures, penetrate its blockade, makes its troops taste death if they attack us and move the battlefield to where it (the United States) does not want or expect it to be.'' The paper was quoted by the Iraq News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, Cyprus. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler estimated that about 2,500 Americans still are in Iraqi-held Kuwait plus the 500 to 600 in Iraq itself.

DOC.HEAD: Surrogate Sues Fetus' Parents for Custody
LaserPhoto LA10 of Aug. 13
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-9, `Van Duesen...' with 5 grafs to CORRECT to Gilbert sted Gibert, UPDATE with comments on television today. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `The Calverts denied...'. Crispina cq in 3rd graf.
DOC.TEXT: A surrogate mother carrying a couple's test-tube baby is suing for custody of the child in a case that could re-define parenthood. ``There's nothing negotiable about it. This is my baby,'' declared Anna Johnson, a 29-year-old who filed suit in state court Monday for custody of the child on grounds that the biological parents would not provide a good home. Mark and Crispina Calvert gave the sperm and egg to create the embryo that was transferred from a lab dish to Johnson's womb under a $10,000 agreement with the woman, a single parent of a 3-year-old. The baby is due in two months. Johnson's effort to pursue custody of a baby that has no biological relation to her is unprecedented, said the Calverts' attorney, Christian Van Deusen. The case differs from the landmark Baby M custody case in New Jersey. In that case, the child was conceived with a surrogate mother's egg and the sperm of a man hiring her. The man's wife had no biological ties to the child. Van Deusen and an attorney for Ms. Johnson, Richard C. Gilbert, said the Johnson case will focus on what constitutes parenthood. Although California law presumes the birth mother is the legal parent, a judge has leeway, Gilbert said. Johnson, appearing today on ABC's ``Good Morning America,'' maintained she had biological and maternal bonds with the fetus. She said that ``the baby, while it's growing inside me, has my cells and my blood nurturing this child, maintaining its life.'' The Calverts' lawyer conceded Johnson was nurturing the unborn child. ``But I don't believe it puts her in a position of holding this child hostage,'' Van Deusen said this morning. Johnson, who is on disability because of pregnancy complications, also seeks child support and damages for emotional distress. She said she decided to seek custody because she believes the Calverts showed disregard for her complications and gave the impression they might not want the baby. The Calverts denied Johnson's allegations that they ignored her medical needs, failed to make timely payments or lost interest in the pregnancy. Johnson and Mrs. Calvert worked as nurses at the same Santa Ana hospital. ``I was surprised that she did this to us,'' a tearful Mrs. Calvert said. ``We thought that we had a good relationship after all I've done for her.'' Mrs. Calvert, who is unable to carry a child because of a hysterectomy, said, ``I just cry. I don't know what to do. We're really looking forward to this baby.'' Johnson also denied that she was seeking custody for monetary gain or because she craved publicity, as the couple suggested. She said she had seen the surrogate contract as a way to put herself through graduate nursing school. ``The problem is not money. The problem is fetal neglect. And they will have to address that in court,'' said Gilbert.

DOC.HEAD: About 19,000 Muscovites Quit Party
DOC.TEXT: About 19,000 Muscovites quit the Communist Party in July following a watershed party congress, Politburo member Yuri Prokofiev said today. The 19,000 were in addition to the 27,000 people who quit during the first six months of this year, he said. Prokofiev, the Moscow Communist Party chief, said half the people turning in their membership cards were workers and the rest were either intellectuals or pensioners. He told the official Tass news agency that 7,000 people have joined the Moscow wing of the party so far this year, nearly half of them under 35 years old. Prokofiev said the majority of those leaving had joined the party to promote their careers. But since taking office in 1985, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has moved to separate the government from party jobs and business. The Communist Party has during that time lost much prestige, and been stripped of its constitutionally guaranteed leading role in society. Prokofiev said Communists now must find a new role for the party in dealing with social and economic problems. He said they must find common ground with orthodox Communists as well as Democratic Platform, the reform group which had been working within the party but now plans to form a separate party. The party's national personnel chief said earlier this month that 370,000 people had followed Russian Federation President Boris Yeltsin and other prominent reformers in quitting the party so far this year. Yeltsin announced his resignation during the 28th Communist Party congress, which ended in Moscow on Juy 13. Boris Pugo, chairman of the party's Central Control Committee, said another 125,000 members were expelled, 120,000 died and 150,000 stopped paying their membership dues or participating in party activities. The Communist Party has more than 18 million members.

DOC.HEAD: Former Nicaraguan President Speaks in Manhattan
DOC.TEXT: Former Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega paid his first visit to the United States since his election defeat last February and admitted he made many mistakes while in power. ``I'd say the expectations that we created that we could solve all our country's problems was one of my biggest mistakes,'' he said. ``But we didn't have the resources to respond to all those problems.'' About 2,500 people gathered for Ortega's speech Monday at Riverside Church, an interdenominational, landmark church known for its support of liberal causes. The crowd was at times exuberant, often interrupting Ortega with applause and shouts of ``Viva Nica!'' Ortega, who spoke in Spanish and had a translator at his side, said the fact that democratic elections were held was more important than his loss to Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and her pro-U.S. United National Opposition alliance Feb. 25. She took office April 25, but her term has been beset by disputes within her alliance, high inflation resulting from a lifting of price controls, and Sandinista-led strikes. In his 90-minute speech, Ortega repeatedly called for stability in his homeland, something he said the Sandinistas have been fighting for since 1979, when they came into power after overthrowing the 45-year dictatorship of the Somoza family. ``This is the revolutionary project that didn't disappear with the elections,'' he said. Ortega also criticized U.S. foreign policy and urged autonomy for Puerto Rico. In a question-and-answer period, Ortega said, ``the United States must stop occupying Puerto Rico and stop occupying Guantanamo Bay,'' a U.S. military base on Cuba. Ortega, dressed in a dark pinstripe suit, did not mention his political plans. David Wilson, 23, a New Yorker who is a member of the Nicaragua Solidarity Network, said the turnout for Ortega's visit showed that support still existed for the former leader and his party. ``I think it's more important to support a party out of power with less access to all kinds of channels within the media and international forums than it is to support a party in power,'' he said. Ortega arrived in New York on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Car Bomb Kills One, Injures 19
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb exploded in front of an army barracks, killing one man and injuring at least 19 others. Authorities said they suspected Shining Path rebels were behind the attack. The blast occurred Monday afternoon in the heart of downtown Cusco, a block from a fashionable tourist hotel. Police said a 40-year-old Mexican woman and her 12-year-old daughter were injured in the explosion. Five soldiers, one officer and four enlisted men also were hurt. Cusco is in the Peruvian highlands, 350 miles southeast of Lima, and is one of Latin America's leading tourist centers. The city has been relatively free of political violence in recent years. Authorities said they suspected the Shining Path, a Maoist rebel group that has fought the government since 1980. More than 18,000 people have died in political violence in Peru in the past decade. In Lima, meanhwile, suspected terrorists tossed a hand grenade at a police car Monday evening, killing one officer and seriously wounding another. The attack took place outside a food market on the city's east side. In other political violence, five people were reported killed in two different regions of the Peruvian highlands over the past few days.

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Group Will Not Oppose Tests of Genetically Engineered Vaccine.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `The tests...', to CORRECT that institute is independent, not part of university. Holley in 7th graf cq
DOC.TEXT: An environmental group said it would not oppose plans to conduct the first field test of a genetically engineered vaccine on wildlife in the United States. The Virginia Department of Health announced Monday that a 10-day test of a rabies vaccine will begin Aug. 20. It will be tested on Parramore Island, an uninhabited barrier island about 4{ miles off the coast of Virginia. The National Wildlife Federation, which had initially fought plans to conduct tests because of safety concerns, will not object to the field test, according to Margaret Mellon, a molecular biologist and lawyer for the group. The tests will be done by the Wistar Institute of Philadelphia, which began work on the vaccine in 1982. Wistar is a non-profit, independent biomedical research center. Ms. Mellon said the group was ``appalled'' by the way U.S. Department of Agriculture officials were so quick to support Wistar's plans, but said refinements in the plans made the federation ``more comfortable'' with the project. The USDA, the state of Virginia and the Nature Conservancy, a non-profit organization that owns the seven-mile long island, approved the field test. The conservancy consented to the project Monday after coming to an agreement with Wistar over several concerns, including legal responsibility. ``We realized that this island was really one of the few, if not only, places the test could be done,'' said a conservancy spokeswoman, Holley Darden. The vaccine was developed to combat the problem of rabid raccoons, which have reached epidemic levels in the Mid-Atlantic states in recent years, said Dr. Warren Cheston, Wistar's associate director. So far this year, 127 rabies cases have been reported in Virginia, while Pennsylvania has documented 376 cases, according to state health authorities. During the field test, scientists will scatter bait laden with the vaccine over the island. Researchers will then spend the next year tracking the animals and testing their blood to see if they have developed antibodies to the rabies virus. Ms. Darden said the island's raccoon population, which numbers about 400, has not been previously exposed to rabies. She said the Wistar Institute would follow guidelines to prevent island animals from escaping to the mainland. The island will be off-limits to the public and monitored by the Virginia Department of Game and Inland Fisheries. The vaccine could be commercially available in as few as five years if the trial goes well and further tests are also successful, according to Dr. David Espeseth of the USDA. Scientists developed the vaccine by inserting a gene from the rabies virus into the live vaccinia virus, an organism used to develop vaccines against smallpox and other diseases. The vaccine cannot spread the disease because it does not use the parts of the virus that cause rabies, according to Cheston. More than 40 species of laboratory animals injected with the altered virus have shown immunity to rabies, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Students Demand Unification, Dissidents Crash Gate at U.S. Base
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with mass rally at university. Pickup pvs 6th graf, ``Dissident Roman...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos SEL2,3
DOC.TEXT: About 10,000 student radicals chanting ``Free travel, total border opening!'' rallied today to demand unrestricted travel to North Korea. Some students at Seoul's Yonsei University, a focal point of many disturbances, slashed rolls of barbed wire with wire cutters to symbolize the breaking of barriers between the bitterly divided Koreas. Earlier today, 79 students and dissidents were arrested at the sprawling U.S. 8th Army headquarters in central Seoul, five of them for ramming a car through the main gate. The car, carrying dissidents and a radical student shouting ``Drive out Yankees!'' barged through the main gate, but was surrounded by almost 50 riot police about 30 yards inside the facility. Police arrested the five occupants. There were no injuries. Student leaders said thousands of people were expected to march to the border Wednesday to attend a unification rally at the truce village of Panmunjom. Students at the rally were chanting ``Let's go North!'' The students also chanted ``Let's drive out the Yankees who block unification of the fatherland.'' They were demanding the withdrawal of some 43,000 U.S. troops stationed in South Korea claiming their presence hinders dialogue with the North on the unification of the Korean peninisula. Dissident Roman Catholic priests and radical students staged protests demanding unification of North and South Korea at Freedom Bridge, a major access checkpoint to the border. ``Withdraw U.S. troops which heighten tension and block unification,'' read a large banner at the border. Dozens of radical students shouting ``Unification!'' tried to ram their way through guards at the bridge, but were hauled away by riot police. In Seoul, the government's Unification Ministry charged North Korea with blocking the first-ever proposed travel between citizens of the divided Koreas and urged Communist North Korea to open its borders. North Korea, in broadcasts monitored in Tokyo, made similar accusations against the South and accused Seoul of being ``deceitful.'' Under a South Korean proposal, the heavily armed border was to have opened for unrestricted travel to North Korea for five days, beginning Monday. But both sides failed to agree on procedures. More than 61,000 South Koreans applied to visit the North during the trial border opening. The two Koreas have been bitter rivals since the division of their land in 1945. They fought a three-year war in the early 1950s. Their border is sealed and there is no mail or other forms of regular communication. ``Let's advance unification of the fatherland!'' shouted South Korean radical students at Freedom Bridge, on the edge of the Demilitarized Zone separating the two Koreas. When 37 students tried to forcibly ram through a 10-foot metal and wire gate onto the bridge, they were arrested and hauled away by riot police. Hundreds of riot police have been stationed at Freedom Bridge, 35 miles north of Seoul, to prevent violence during the failed border opening. The two Koreas have accusing the other of using the border opening as propaganda. Both sides have rejected meetings proposed by the other.

DOC.HEAD: Some Americans Sneak out of Kuwait, Others Get Turned Back
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Tops with 5 grafs, Voice of America cautioning Americans not to try to flee Kuwait, picks up 3rd graf, The Iraqi ...
DOC.TEXT: The Voice of America is cautioning Americans trapped in Kuwait not to try to flee across the border into Saudi Arabia, the State Department said today. About 500 Americans already have been able to sneak into Saudi Arabia, penetrating lax Iraqi security, but a caravan of others who tried to flee were forced to beat a sweltering retreat. The clandestine departures reduce the number of civilian Americans in Kuwait to 2,500, according to State Department figures. Also stranded are 500 to 600 Americans in Iraq. The Voice of America, a radio service operated by the U.S. government, is urging the Americans still in Kuwait not to try to cross the border ``due to the danger involved,'' but advising them to get ready to leave on short notice. ``When the orderly evacuation of Americans wishing to leave Kuwait becomes possible, American citizens will be contacted by phone or by radio and information will be broadcast by the Voice of America and the BBC,'' VOA broadcasts said. The Iraqi ambassador to the United States, Mohamed Al-Mashat, said today that the Americans will be freed in ``due time.'' ``We have already let many people go,'' Al-Mashat said on NBC's ``Today.'' ``It takes time and under current circumstances, in due time they are going to be let free.'' Meanwhile, Secretary of State James A. Baker III was scheduled to meet today with officials of the deposed Kuwaiti regime to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis. Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly had high-level contacts on Monday with Syrian authorities. The gulf crisis has brought Syria closer to the United States because of Syria's longstanding rivalry with Iraq. As the Iraqi conquest of Kuwait entered its 13th day today, the fate of the Americans continued to be a matter of utmost concern to the Bush administration. U.S. diplomats have been in constant contact with Iraqi authorities about the issue, but the Iraqis have given no indication that the Americans will be allowed to leave. Exempted from this policy are Americans attached to the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad, 10 of whom left for home on Saturday. More are scheduled to leave later this week. The stranded Americans have been caught up in the war of nerves between the United States and Iraq. Although they still are not being called hostages, U.S. officials suspect that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein may try to use the Americans as blackmail if his confrontation with the United States worsens. U.S. officials said the Americans who managed to flee Kuwait took advantage of lax Iraqi security at the final checkpoint on Kuwaiti territory and entered the relative safety of Saudi Arabia. But a Briton, David Thomas Croskery, who apparently tried to flee by the same route was shot to death on Saturday by Iraqi troops in Kuwait. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said the administration was ``shocked and extremely concerned'' by the incident. She said there were rumors Sunday that all foreigners were being allowed to leave, but the administration was told that only Africans, South Asians and Latins are being given such permission. Iraqi broadcasts indicate that Arabs and East Asians also have been allowed to depart. False news reports about the opening of the Kuwait-Saudi border to all foreigners prompted 40 to 50 carloads of Americans to head for the frontier, Ms. Tutwiler said. They were turned back at the border, their disappointment aggravated by blistering heat, she said. The attempted exodus may have been the result of an Iraqi broadcast on Sunday saying the authorities have been instructed to ``facilitate the travel of the Arabs and foreign residents in Kuwait and other cities of southern Iraq.'' Southern Iraq is the term Iraqis have used to describe what was once Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Mystery Pilot Indicted on New Charges
DOC.TEXT: Lawyer Thomas Root's legal troubles have mounted since his bizarre flight down the East Coast last year that ended in his dramatic rescue when his plane crashed off the Bahamas. Monday, he was among four men charged in connection with the allegedly fraudulent selling of investments in would-be Christian FM radio stations. Root, a former communications lawyer from Alexandria, Va., already faces up to 35 years in prison and $1.25 million in fines after pleading guilty to federal felony charges of misrepresenting clients. In addition, he was indicted in June by a grand jury in North Carolina on 455 counts of securities fraud and other charges. The latest charges were detailed by a 50-count indictment returned by a state grand jury and unsealed Monday. It charges Root and three executives of Sonrise Management Services with racketeering, securities fraud, organized fraud, sale of unregistered securities and grand theft. The defendants are accused of selling fraudulent investment opportunities in FM radio license applications pending before the Federal Communications Commission in Washington. Root has denied that financial and legal troubles were connected with the mysterious six-hour flight that brought him to national attention in July 1989. He said he blacked out and the Cessna 210 continued on autopilot until it hit the Atlantic Ocean off the Bahamas. But Navy fighter pilots who intercepted the flight said they saw Root moving in the cockpit. Divers who rescued Root discovered he had a gunshot wound in his stomach. Root says he does not know how he got shot. Root's attorney, Eugene Propper, said his client will turn himself in to authorities in Clearwater, but declined to say when. Bond for Root is set at $150,000. Propper said he has not seen the indictment and declined to comment further. Root, 37, handled applications for investors of Sonrise, a Columbus, Ga.-based company that touted Christian principles in literature carried by sales representatives in Georgia, Alabama, North Carolina, California and Florida. Prosecutors said more than 200 Florida investors put more than $1.3 million into the schemes, and that the defendants took in more than $40 million in 1986-89 from more than 3,000 people nationwide. Also named in the Florida indictment were Ralph M. Savage, 54, of Phenix City, Ala.; Eugene B. White, 43, of Columbus, Ga.; and Carl W. Hurlebaus, 31, of Landover, Md. In 1988, Savage and White claimed net worth of at least $9 million each, prosecutors said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Criticized For Moving Too Fast In Policing Quarantine
DOC.TEXT: Several Security Council members have criticized the United States for moving too fast, too forcefully and without council approval to cut off Iraqi shipping. The criticism of the United States was delivered Monday in closed council consultations on the Persian Gulf crisis, U.N. and Western diplomats said. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar did not criticize the U.S. quarantine, but said Monday that only the Security Council could legally enforce an embargo. ``I have nothing to say against it (the U.S. quarantine and military presence) provided there is consent from other parties,'' Perez de Cuellar told reporters. He said all states were free to act under the U.N. Charter, which supports ``the inherent right of individual or collective self-defense if an armed attack occurs against a member of the United Nations.'' But he added that: ``Only the United Nations, through its Security Council resolutions, can really decide about a blockade.'' Iraqi Ambassador Amir Al-Anbari later told the secretary-general that his government has no intention of invading Saudi Arabia, that the U.S. military buildup is unjustified and that the United States and its allies are creating pretexts for aggression against Iraq. U.S. and U.N. officials said there was no contradiction between the U.N. embargo resolution and the U.S. cut off of Iraqi shipping. Both bar import to Iraq of all grain and foodstuffs, except in cases of dire need and humanitarian concern. In the 15-member council Monday, Cuba and other nations criticized the U.S. decision to use force to police the trade embargo against Iraq. The embargo was ordered by the Security Council after Iraq invaded Kuwait. Cuba said the United States should not consider itself the world policeman and should have waited for the Security Council to decide that further action was necessary. The Washington Post said today that France, Canada, the Soviet Union and Malaysia strongly criticized the U.S. position in the council meeting. Cuban Ambassador Ricardo Alarcon told reporters later that: ``The United States does not have the right to interpret Security Council resolutions and act without council permission. It is undermining the role of the council.'' He said he ``did not remember any country who supported the U.S. stand'' in the council Monday. ``The United States cannot arrogate to itself the policeman's role which has not been first decided by the council,'' he said. A Security Council committee is to meet Friday and evaluate compliance with the embargo, based on reports from many of the 159 member states. It then will make recommendations on the enforcement of the embargo. Under the U.N. Charter, Article 42 of Chapter 7, the Security Council can call for an international military blockade to enforce its resolutions. The United States has said that Kuwait requested the U.S. action to enforce the quarantine against Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Opponents of King Holiday File Referendum Petitions in Arizona
DOC.TEXT: Led by impeached Gov. Evan Mecham, opponents of a paid state holiday commemorating assassinated civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. filed petitions to let the voters decide the issue. If 43,350 signatures submitted Monday are validated by spot checks, the holiday's fate will be determined during the November general election. Mecham and his supporters say an unpaid King holiday already exists. They say the real issue is whether voters want to give state employees another paid day off, not whether they want to honor the slain civil rights activist. Mecham, one of five Republicans running for governor this year, led a group that filed 71,000 signatures. Former Gov. Bruce Babbitt, speaking for a coalition of business and civic leaders, said the holiday is needed ``to honor the remarkable progress America has made in race relations.'' The cost of the holiday has been estimated at $500,000 to $4 million a year. But some civic leaders say they'd rather pay for the holiday than suffer bad publicity over Arizona's lack of a paid holiday. Mecham's successor, Democratic Gov. Rose Mofford, urged voters to approve the paid holiday. The holiday has been a sore point in Arizona since 1986, when Babbitt bypassed the Legislature and issued an executive proclamation establishing a paid King holiday for executive-branch employees. Republican Attorney General Bob Corbin issued an opinion saying Babbitt's action was illegal. Mecham, who took office in 1987, rescinded the paid holiday before it could take effect. He later established an unpaid ``Martin Luther King-Civil Rights Day'' on the third Sunday in January. That proclamation has never been repealed, but supporters of the paid King Day called it a second-class honor and refused to recognize it. The Legislature decided last year to swap state workers' paid Columbus Day holiday for a King Day, an action that already has been made subject to approval on this November's ballot. The Mecham drive would put a second referendum on the ballot to approve or reject a 1990 law that restored Columbus Day in addition to King Day. If voters approved both laws, the one with the most affirmative votes would prevail. If they rejected both, the state would revert to a paid day for Columbus and no paid day for King.

DOC.HEAD: Musician Curtis Mayfield Seriously Hurt in Concert Accident
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE condition report. Picks up 3rd graf, `Mayfield was...'.
DOC.TEXT: Curtis Mayfield, a rhythm and blues musician popular in the 1960s and '70s, was critically injured when a lighting tower blown over by a gust of wind fell on his head before a concert, authorities said. Mayfield, 48, was listed in critical but stable condition this morning at Kings County Hospital, suffering from head and neck injuries. Mayfield was scheduled to perform Monday night at the outdoor Martin Luther King Concert Series in Brooklyn. With rain threatening, the lighting tower and some speakers were blown over, concert officials and police said. Three stagehands and four concert volunteers also were injured, police spokeswoman Sgt. Mary Wrensen said. One other person was hospitalized with an unspecified injury, Wrensen said. None of the other injuries was serious. The Chicago-born musician was a teen-ager when he rose to prominence as the guitarist, songwriter and occasional lead singer for The Impressions. His hits with the Impressions included the civil rights song ``People Get Ready.'' He left the group in 1970 and two years later wrote the music for the film ``Superfly,'' including the song ``Freddie's Dead.'' He also wrote the soundtrack for the 1975 Bill Cosby-Sidney Poitier film ``Let's Do It Again.''

DOC.HEAD: Strong Quake Shakes Northeastern Taiwan
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake shook northeastern Taiwan today but there were no immediate reports of casualties or damage, authorities reported. The Central Weather Bureau said the quake registered a preliminary reading of 6 on the open-ended Richter scale. Its epicenter was located at sea about 29 miles southeast of Ilan on Taiwan's northeastern coast. The tremor was felt in Taipei. The Richter scale measure ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a 10-fold increase in intensity. An earthquake of magnitude 6 can cause severe damage in a populated area.

DOC.HEAD: Philadelphia Controller: City Going Broke Despite Big Borrowing Plans
DOC.TEXT: The city's chief accounting officer says Philadelphia will be broke in nine months, despite plans to borrow heavily this summer. ``There is an estimation that we'll run out of cash as a city, even with all the loans being purchased from outside investors, in May,'' Controller Jonathan A. Saidel said Monday. Saidel, quoted on KYW-AM, said he was told this by the mayor, treasurer and finance director, who have recently refused to discuss the city's finances. Mayor W. Wilson Goode and Finance Director Betsy Reveal had said that without new local taxes and more state money, the city might be unable to pay its bills within 18 months. As in past summers, the city is preparing to borrow millions of dollars. Reveal said Monday night the amount this year could be as much as $450 million, about $150 million more than expected. Last year, the city borrowed $220 million and in June, city officials said they would need $280 million to $300 million this year. The city's budget year runs from July 1 to June 30. Reveal said the administration is preparing an ``offering document'' detailing the city's finances for potential investors. Until the document is released Thursday or Friday, Reveal said, it would be improper for her to make public specific figures. The Philadelphia Inquirer reported Saturday that Standard & Poor's says the city had a larger deficit last fiscal year than the $60.8 million officials had projected. The company in June reduced its rating of Philadelphia's bonds to the lowest level recommended to investors, and the lowest level of any major U.S. city.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Blacks Killed In Rioting
DOC.TEXT: At least nine blacks were killed today in fighting east of Johannesburg between residents of a workers' hostel and squatters. Police Col. Gerrit Erasmus confirmed the deaths in Thokoza township. He said it was unclear how many people were injured. Police Lt. Nina Barkhuizen said the fighting was between hostel dwellers of the Zulu and Xhosa tribes. Ms. Barkhuizen said police used teargas and birdshot to quell the fighting. The independent South African Associated Press said the fighting broke out early in the morning when squatters from the Phola Park camp attacked the Khalanyoni workers' hostel. The squatters apparently attacked to avenge the slaying of one of their friends on Sunday. ``A group of armed men wearing blankets entered the Khalanyoni Hostel grounds and started attacking everyone in sight,'' hostel dweller Mpumuzt Tshabalala told the South African Press Association. ``We ran helter skelter and those in their rooms had to jump through windows to evade the attackers,'' Tshabalala said. He said he narrowly escaped death when his room was firebombed. An unconfirmed report in the Star newspaper said the fighting was between supporters of the African National Congress and the conservative Zulu-based Inkatha organisation. A CBS TV staffer in the township said a group of about 600 armed blacks, believed to be Inkatha supporters, marching after the rioting through the township followed by police. They were armed with weapons including iron rods and assegais - a traditional Zulu spear and some held shields. Phola Park residents' committee chairman Prince Mhlambi appealed for police neutrality. He said during the rioting two people were killed in the presence of police. Some blacks have accused the police of favoring Inkatha supporters. At least 33 people have died in clashes between rival black groups in townships around Johannesburg in recent weeks. More than 5,000 blacks have died since 1986 in fighting between Inkatha and ANC supporters in the eastern province of Natal. Fears that the conflict may be spreading to other parts of the country were sparked in recent weeks after fighting involving Inkatha and opposing groups erupted in areas around Johannesburg.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storm Fran Passes over Trinidad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with later position. Picks up penultimate graf.
DOC.TEXT: A weakening Tropical Storm Fran moved across the island nation of Trinidad and Tobago today with maximum sustained winds of 40 mph. The season's seventh tropical depression was heading west at nearly 25 mph, said the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. Fran was expected to dump up to 3 inches of rain on Trinidad, whose government is recovering from an unsuccessful coup attempt two weeks ago by radical Moslems. At 9 a.m. EDT, Fran was centered over Trinidad. The island is seven miles off Venezuela. The government of Trinidad and Tobago today issued a tropical storm watch in place of a more urgent warning that had been posted late Monday. A tropical storm watch was discontinued for Barbados, St. Vincent and the Grenadines at 9 a.m. The storm had dissipated Sunday but regained strength Monday. Forecasters said it was likely to degenerate into a tropical wave as it entered the southeastern Caribbean. A tropical depression becomes a tropical storm once its top sustained winds reach 39 mph. A hurricane has top winds of no less than 74 mph. The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 to Nov. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Blocks Enforcement of Restrictions on Phone Sex Services
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `The regulations...', to restore dropped word `effect.'
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has barred the government from enforcing a law sponsored by Sen. Jesse Helms to keep children from using dial-a-porn services. The Federal Communications Commission regulation said telephone companies could not bill for calls containing ``indecent speech'' unless a customer certified in writing that he or she was 18 or older and wanted the services. U.S. District Judge Robert P. Patterson ruled Monday that the law would probably infringe on the rights of free speech and due process. The ruling applies only to New York but may influence judges in other jurisdictions. The regulations were to have gone into effect Wednesday. The ruling came in a lawsuit by five companies that operate telephone services in the New York area with sexually explicit content. They sued to void the so-called Helms Amendment, named after the North Carolina Republican. Joel R. Dichter, an attorney for the plaintiffs, said the 1986 amendment ``would put these companies out of business.'' He said that the requirement for a written request would have a ``chilling effect'' on the First Amendment because most people would want to keep their anonymity when using the phone-sex services. In issuing the injunction, the judge said the amendment probably violated the First Amendment because it did not employ the least restrictive means to accomplish its goal _ preventing children from calling phone-sex services. The companies had argued voluntary blocking systems used by several states such as New York were effective and less restrictive than the FCC regulations. In New York, a household can have its access to sexually explicit telephone services blocked free of charge by contacting the telephone company. Most of the phone-sex numbers have a 900 area code, and 976 or 970 prefixes locally. Assistant U.S. Attorney Nancy Kilson, who represents the government, said a decision had not been made on whether to appeal.

DOC.HEAD: 20 Years Later, Art Institute Officially `Loses' O'Keeffe Painting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT day comments made to Monday sted Tuesday.
DOC.TEXT: A Georgia O'Keeffe painting has been formally declared ``lost'' by the Art Institute of Chicago, 20 years after a search for the misplaced painting began. Officials of the prestigious museum had continued to hope over two decades that the work, ``East River from the Shelton,'' would turn up, Art Institute director James Woods said Tuesday. But after a recent inventory of 1,500 pieces in the museum's department of 20th century paintings and sculpture, Wood said officials acknowledged the painting was nowhere to be found. ``Frankly, the reclassification of the painting as lost from the museum is long overdue,'' Woods said. ``The painting has been missing for 20 years. We are acknowledging that unfortunate fact now.'' Museum officials stopped short of saying the work, valued at between $250,000 and $500,000, was stolen. But they have notified the FBI, Interpol and other officials that it is missing. ``One has heard of objects being lost in museums or even going out with the trash,'' Wood said. ``So it still might be found here or in the hands of an innocent person.'' The 1926 painting, on a 12-by-32-inch canvas, depicts the view from a Manhattan hotel in which O'Keeffe and her husband, photographer Alfred Stieglitz, lived. Stieglitz's estate loaned the work to the Art Institute in 1949 and it entered the museum's permanent collection as a gift from the artist in 1955. O'Keeffe, acknowledged to be on of the foremost 20th century American artists, died in 1986. She is best known for her paintings of large-scale flowers and semi-abstract paintings reflecting the influence of years she spent in the American Southwest.
