DOC.HEAD: Tentative Settlement Reached in Portland Grocery Strike
DOC.TEXT: A union is asking its members to approve a contract that would end a 24-day strike involving 5,400 workers at five Portland-area grocery chains and some independent markets. The tentative agreement was reached Monday on a four-year contract for members of Local 555 of the United Food & Commercial Workers, who struck July 21. Details were not disclosed pending a ratification meeting Wednesday. Rick Sawyer, a union spokesman, credited federal mediator Tom Drew with putting together the deal. Sawyer said the grocers made a new offer including a company-paid health benefits package because of the economic impact of the walkout. A spokesman for the grocers said the settlement occurred because shoppers crossed picket lines. Stephen Erdmann, executive director of Food Employers Inc., said the strike had no winners. Full-time employees lost $1,400 in wages and up to two months of health and welfare eligibility while grocers lost sales and will have to pass along costs of the new contract to consumers, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Army's Order for Desert-Bound Troops: 5,500 Bottles of Suntan Lotion
DOC.TEXT: The Army went on a shopping spree at the Hinesville K mart last week and got a blue-light special on more than 24,000 items. K mart manager Wesley Bennefield said officials at Fort Stewart, which began sending troops and equipment to Saudi Arabia over the weekend, telephoned him Friday to order items essential for the desert: 2,400 cans of bug spray, 5,550 bottles of skin lotion, 5,550 tubes of lip balm, 5,550 containers of foot powder and 5,550 bottle of suntan lotion. ``This has been a real treat. I've spent three days on the telephone,'' said Bennefield, who had most of the items shipped to the base Sunday night from K mart's Atlanta warehouse. The Army also ordered an item the local K mart doesn't carry: 174,000 gallons of bottled water. Bennefield said he had rounded up 84,000 gallons from bottled water companies as of this morning and was trying to find the rest. Fort Stewart's public affairs officer, Maj. Don Keeling, said it isn't unusual for the Army to go to local stores for such items. ``We have been going to various vendors to obtain whatever we think is necessary for the protection of the welfare of our soldiers,'' Keeling said. K mart gave the Army a discount on the order, but Bennefield said he hasn't calculated the total cost yet. He said his store is not making a profit off the deal. ``You might say we're waving the flag,'' he said. ``I'm a patriotic guy.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Now Calls Kuwait a Southern Iraqi City
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein's government is now calling Kuwait City one of the ``cities of southern Iraq'' after annexing the oil-rich emirate. Baghdad at first installed a ``provisional government of free Kuwait,'' which in turn declared a ``republic'' just 24 hours before Iraq's Aug. 2 annexation. Under the emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, it was known as the State of Kuwait and bridled at being called an ``emirate,'' because in Arabic that term connotes a tiny sheikdom or fiefdom. Iraqi spokesmen are now referring to ``Kuwait, al-Jahra ... and other cities of southern Iraq.'' Al-Jahra is one of the municipalities that made up the State of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: U.A.E. Refuses to Dock Iraqi Freighter, Mine Alert Canceled
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with mine alert canceled. CORRECTS spelling of shoal to Shah Allum sted Shah Olam. Pickup pvs 18th graf, ``Meanwhile, the....' Edits to trim
DOC.TEXT: Authorities in United Arab Emirates stopped an Iraqi freighter from entering the port of Dubai today, and shipping sources said a mine alert for a central Persian Gulf channel was canceled. Radio monitors in the gulf overheard the Iraqi freighter Al-Abid calling out every 10 minutes to authorities in the bustling southern port of Dubai for permission to enter the harbor. The vessel was anchored three miles northwest of the Dubai breakwater, they said. But the port control officials were overheard replying ``We've no instructions, we've no instructions'' to give the ship permission to enter. The shipping sources said Al-Abid also repeatedly requested contact with its agent to help bring provisions for the crew, but there was no indication the port authority would cooperate. Diplomatic sources in the United Arab Emirates said the country's ports have quietly stopped allowing Iraqi tankers or freighters entry. The government, however, has made no official statements to this effect. Another Iraqi freighter, Al-Baya, has been waiting off Dubai for the last two days to enter Dubai, the shipping sources said on condition of anonymity. On the other side of the Arabian Peninsula, the Iraqi tanker al-Qadissiyah was still anchored off the Red Sea terminal of Yanbu today. It was turned away by Saudi authorities Sunday when it tried to load oil from the trans-Saudi Iraqi pipeline. Meanwhile, a U.S. military source said that a mine alert in the central gulf has been canceled. Shipping executives said they were told by U.S. Navy officials that an Iraqi vessel was spotted dropping mines in the Shah Allum shoals, 80 miles northeast of the Qatar Peninsula. The channel is used by tankers heading for Saudi Arabian oil terminals. A U.S. military source in Dubai said a helicopter crew spotted a merchant ship Saturday near Shah Allum, but on closer investigation found it was not laying mines. ``The notice has since been rescinded and as of now there is no specific concern about mines in the Gulf,'' the source said, on condition of anonymity. The channel was the site where the USS Samuel B. Roberts hit a mine in April 1988. The frigate, escorting a U.S.-reflagged Kuwaiti tanker, struck Iranian-sowed mines and 10 American sailors were injured in a massive explosion. Kuwait was then the primary target of Iranian attacks on shipping in the vital waterway because it was assisting the Iraqi war effort against Iran. Meanwhile, the U.S.-led efforts to enforce U.N. sanctions against Iraq to force that country to withdraw from Kuwait appeared to widen today. Shipping executives said they monitored today the British warship York questioning a Cypriot-flagged tanker named Glory that is known be shuttling oil from Iraqi ports. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, and subsequently annexed the country. The U.N. sanctions placed an embargo on oil from Iraq and Kuwait and blocked imports from Iraq. But Iraq remained defiant today. The state newspaper Al-Jumhuriya said Iraq knows how to answer the Bush administration, ``how to foil its measures, penetrate its blockade, makes its troops taste death if they attack us and move the battlefield to where it (the United States) does not want or expect it to be.'' The paper was quoted by the Iraq News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, Cyprus.

DOC.HEAD: NYC Guards Block Access to Jail Island In Protest Over Beating Of Guard
DOC.TEXT: Angry correction officers blocked the only bridge to the city's prison island today in a protest over safety as top city officials flew there in an effort to defuse the 2-day-old demonstration. Some 200 guards, angered by the recent robbery and beating of a fellow officer by inmates, began blocking the bridge that leads from Queens to Rikers Island around 6 a.m. Monday. Most jail workers on the overnight shift at the time have been stuck at the jail complex ever since. ``We are not moving until we get results,'' Correction Officer Timothy McLilly declared on Monday. First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel and Labor Relations Commissioner Eric Schmertz took a police helicopter to Rikers Island, joining Correction Commissioner Allyn R. Sielaff in talks with union officials, a mayoral spokesman said. ``The talks are continuing. I can't say what they're centered on until there's a break and I get to talk to the commissioner,'' Correction Department spokeswoman Ruby Ryles said today. ``We're very hopeful it's going to be resolved soon,'' she said. A handful of employees were able to get to work or get off the island before the entrance to the Francis R. Bruono Memorial Bridge was completely blocked, Ryles said. But, she added, ``basically the same people who were on since the 11 p.m. to 7 a.m. shift on Sunday night are still there.'' Those stranded included Dr. Pearl Brown, who said that she and about 20 other health care workers could not get off the island. Correction officials told her the bridge was closed. ``I would like to get out of here,'' she said this morning, adding that like several of her colleagues, she has been unable to keep up her private practice as a result of the protest. On Monday, the action kept inmates from being transported to court, visitors could not enter, and supply vehicles were stopped, Ryles said.She also said that several inmates had to be taken off the island in police launches overnight so they could be treated at area hospitals. Even Sielaff was stopped and had to reach the island by boat to meet union president Phil Seelig to try to defuse the situation. Seelig said the union had not authorized the protest. The officers were protesting the fact that attempted murder charges were not brought against three inmates who allegedly attacked a guard, Steve Norby, 37, last Tuesday. Norby suffered a broken jaw and other injuries, and his jewelry was stolen, authorities said. The inmates, Gregory Curry, 20, Michael Coleman, 28, and Nathan Legrand, 21, were charged with first-degree robbery, assault and promoting prison contraband, Ryles said.

DOC.HEAD: Criminal Charges Filed After Teen-Ager Dies in Survival Program
DOC.TEXT: Operators of a wilderness program for rebellious teen-agers have been charged with negligence in the death of a Florida girl and criminal mistreatment of other youngsters. Challenger Foundation founder Stephen Cartisano and field director Lance Jagger were charged with negligent homicide, a misdemeanor, in the June 27 death of 16-year-old Kristen Chase of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. The complaint signed Monday before 6th Circuit Judge David L. Mower also charged Cartisano and Challenger with five counts of child abuse. Mower set arraignment for Sept. 13. Chase collapsed while hiking atop the Kaiparowits Plateau in southern Utah with three other youngsters. An autopsy concluded that she died of exertional heat stroke, likely complicated by altitude and near triple-digit temperatures. She had been in the program just three days, placed there by her mother and stepfather. Cartisano denied any negligence in the death, and said the girl suffered from other ailments. Medical Examiner Dr. Todd Grey said the girl's prior ailments did not contribute to the death. Cartisano said the girl had not yet entered the ``impact'' portion of the 63-day program which, according to brochures, strips rebellious teen-agers of their belligerence through ``five days and nights of physical and mental stress with forced march, night hikes and limited food and water.'' However, two counselors who were with the girl said they were on a ``forced hike'' and that she had collapsed from heat exhaustion several times the day before she died. ``The tragedy is that when we were going strong, we put over $2 million a year into Kane and Garfield counties,'' Cartisano said Monday night. ``Now, if they are successful, not only will they lose that, it is going to cost them hundreds of thousands of dollars to fight this _ because we are going to fight this like nothing before.'' Cartisano repeatedly has claimed Kane County Sheriff Maxwell Jackson's investigation was politically motivated. The Challenger program began two years ago and initially refused to comply with state regulations governing residential youth treatment programs. The operators claimed they were not providing treatment. New laws were enacted during the 1990 Legislature and went into effect four days after Chase's death. Last week, Challenger filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, with Cartisano citing legal fees and bad publicity. Challenger listed $63,040 in assets and more than $1.1 million in debts, including some $200,000 in back taxes.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting for all needing.
Sales Tax for Baseball Stadium on Ballot
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT proposed sales tax to 0.1 percent sted 0.01 percent.
DOC.TEXT: Denver-area voters were asked today to approve higher sales taxes to finance a stadium that could attract a major league baseball team. Also on today's ballot were a Democratic primary for the U.S. Senate and a Republican runoff for a seat in Congress. Recent polls showed voters in six Denver-area counties nearly even on whether to approve the 12-year, 0.1 percent sales tax _ one cent on each $10 purchase. The measure would raise $139 million. Denver is bidding for one of two baseball franchises to be awarded this year. Baseball proponents hope approval of the tax will lure a team. An estimated 1.8 million people are eligible to vote. Secretary of State Natalie Meyer projected a turnout of about 35 percent. In the Senate race, polls published over the weekend showed former Boulder County commissioner Josie Heath, 52, ahead of Carlos Lucero, a 49-year-old lawyer. Heath led by 59 percent to 21 percent, and 41 percent to 32 percent. The winner will meet Rep. Hank Brown, a popular Republican who is giving up his seat in Congress after 10 years to run for the Senate. Republican Sen. Bill Armstrong is not seeking re-election. Republican state Sens. Wayne Allard of Loveland and Jim Brandon of Akron are vying to face Democrat Richard Bond, who is unopposed for Brown's congressional seat.

DOC.HEAD: Settler Convicted of Killing Arab Released Ahead of Schedule
DOC.TEXT: A leader of the Jewish settler movement imprisoned for the shooting death of a Palestinian was released today after serving three months of a five-month sentence. Dozens of supporters and two legislators from the right-wing Likud bloc greeted Rabbi Moshe Levinger on his release from the minimum security Nir prison. The legislators lifted Levinger on their shoulders and began dancing in celebration, the national Itim news agency reported. Levinger was convicted by a Jerusalem District Court in April of causing the shooting death of Kayed Sallah, 42, through negligence. He plea-bargained to reduce the charge of manslaughter. In the Sept. 30, 1988 incident, Levinger fired his pistol indiscriminately after Palestinians stoned his car. Sallah, who was standing in front of the shoe store he owned, was killed. Levinger vowed today to open fire again if he believed he was in a life-threatening situation. ``If I'm in a situation of danger again, I'll again open fire,'' Levinger said on Israel radio.``I hope that next time, I will be more careful and I won't miss the target. Levinger served only 92 days of his term and was released early for ``good behavior,'' Prison Authority spokeswoman Shuli Meiri said. Members of the left-wing Mapam party demonstrated outside the prison to protest Levinger's early release, scuffling with Levinger's supporters, it said. Levinger, a champion of the settlement movement, lives in Kiryat Arba near the West Bank town of Hebron. Some 75,000 Jewish settlers live amid 1.7 million Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, which were captured by Israel in the 1967 Middle East War. Vehicles driven by Jewish settlers have frequently come under stoning attacks by Palestinians waging a 32-month uprising against Israeli rule. Betselem, an Israeli information center monitoring human rights abuses in the occupied territories, has reported that 29 Palestinians have been killed by settlers.

DOC.HEAD: No Rush To Join The Army
DOC.TEXT: Young Arabs may by lining up to do battle for or against Iraq's Saddam Hussein, but America's youth so far have not responded to the call to arms, military recruiters said today. ``No more than usual,'' said an Army recruiting officer in Durham, North Carolina, when asked if the Middle East crisis had inspired more enlistments. ``About the same,'' said a recruiter in Atlanta. ``There's been no unusual fluctuation in enlistment,'' said Mary Auer of the Recruiting Battalion in the Cincinnati area. She said a ``very few people'' who had been in the military before had inquired about returning, but there had been no surge in new recruits. Major Doug Hart, public affairs officer at the Pentagon, said enlistment figures are compiled on a quarterly basis and it was too early to tell whether the threat of war in the Middle East will increase the number of volunteers. ``But if Panama and Grenada are guidelines, there will be no significant difference'' in enlistments, Hart said, referring to U.S. military actions in those areas. He also cautioned that increased interest in military service would not necessarily mean more enlistments. ``We are still in a draw-down period mandated by Congress to make the army smaller,'' Hart said. The armed services recruited 128,300 people in the first half of fiscal year 1990, beginning on Oct. 1, 1989, he said. In fiscal 1989 the figure was 293,900. Recruiters said volunteers might increase if fighting breaks out between the United States and Iraq. ``It's kind of quiet here now,'' said a Navy recruiting officer in Washington D.C. who declined to give his name. ''Maybe if the crisis goes further we might get some more patriotic responses, but right now it's business as usual.''

DOC.HEAD: Governor Declares State of Emergency in One County Plagued By Fire
DOC.TEXT: A fast-moving forest fire threatened up to 1,600 homes in northern California, and a state of emergency was declared for the county where fires have blackened parts of Yosemite National Park. ``The situation in some of these areas may get worse before it gets better,'' Gov. George Deukmejian said when he declared the state of emergency for Mariposa County on Monday. Fires have burned 210,000 acres of California during the past week. Fires today also blackened parts of Idaho, Utah, Oregon, Washington and Alaska, said the National Fire Information Center in Boise, Idaho. It said nearly 22,000 firefighters were at work. Cooler, damper weather slowed some of the fires. Of the 14 major fires in California, the biggest was the Campbell Complex that had burned about 114,000 acres in Tehama County. But the top priority for firefighters was a smaller Tehama County fire, the Finley Lake fire east of Red Bluff, that at one point threatened as many as 400 homes in Manton, 200 in Mineral, and an additional 1,000 in the general area. It had burned 17,500 acres, officials said. Firefighters created a 2-mile-long defense line in Manton, setting a backfire in hopes it would counter the northbound forest fire and keep it from destroying homes. Manton residents were advised to be ready to evacuate, officials said. The fire also was nearing Lassen National Forest near Mineral and Lassen Volcanic National Park to the north. In Yosemite National Park, three major fires continued to burn Monday. An estimated 17,000 acres had been charred. The A-Rock fire near El Portal burned 13,400 acres, and the Steamboat fire burned 4,000 acres. Both were about 50 percent contained today. Sixty-six homes were lost in Foresta last week in the A Rock fire, and the park's Rancheria Flat settlement was evacuated. An estimated 500 acres were also charred by the Aspen Fire in Yosemite, which was 20 percent contained Monday. The community of Aspen Valley was evacuated. Flames were within two miles of Yosemite's Merced Grove of giant sequoia trees. Some 12,000 firefighters were at work in California and were to be joined today by 1,200 soldiers from the 4th Infantry Division at Fort Carson, Colo. Two battalions totaling 1,200 from the 9th Infantry Division at Fort Lewis, Wash., were arriving in Oregon to relieve firefighters. One California firefighter was in critical condition after being struck by a falling tree limb, and a helicopter pilot suffered a broken leg and concussion when his craft crashed, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Curious Worker Takes Home Radioactive Cylinder
DOC.TEXT: A curious worker took home a tiny cylinder containing the radioactive element cesium which he found near a factory in central Russia, Pravda reported Tuesday. The cylinder was discovered in a shed near the worker's home in Tula after a routine aerial inspection reported a strong radiation source, the Communist Party newspaper said. Inspectors using radiation meters pinpointed the exact location, it said. An investigation has begun to determine who lost the cylinder on the grounds of the Tulachermet Ferrous Metallurgy Enterprise and when, Pravda said. ``It is not ruled out the small-scale Chernobyls may end up not only in Tula people's sheds but also their homes due to negligence by officials,'' the newspaper said. Pravda said the unidentified worker did not know what was in the cylinder when he took it home. Cesium is used in photoelectric cells.

DOC.HEAD: Two Skydivers Killed After Collision
DOC.TEXT: Two skydivers fell to their deaths Tuesday after they collided during a jump involving 12 parachutists, authorities said. Officials said Maurizio Moggi, 37, could not open his parachute in time to avoid a collision with the open parachute of Marco Bertolini, 22. The force of the impact collapsed Bertolini's parachute, causing both men to plummet to the ground. The accident happened during a jump by a dozen skydivers from an altitude of 2,640 feet. Vittorio Bertolani, an instructor at the parachute school at Pavullo, told the Italian news agency ANSA that both men were expert jumpers.

DOC.HEAD: Police Set Up Special Phone Number For Tips on Terrorism
DOC.TEXT: Police have set up a special telephone number in hopes of gathering anonymous tips that may help the government's effort to fight domestic terrorism. Starting Tuesday, citizens could dial 170 and provide tips on terrorism and other violent crimes. ``If they like they can leave their names or remain anonymous,'' said an officer who replied at that number. ``Most of the calls we received today were evidently hoaxes,'' he added. The new phone numnber will not deal with the question of rewards, the officer said, speaking on condition of anonymity. In April, the U.S. Embassy in Athens announced the opening of a Washington D.C. post office box to guarantee secrecy for people responding to an offer of rewards for information on international terrorism. In Greece, the November 17 leftist terrorist group has claimed responsibility for killing 14 people, including three American officials. It has also attacked American servicemen and property since it first emerged in 1975. Despite large rewards offered by the Greek government, private organizations and the United States, no members of November 17 have been arrested.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Official Says Cigarette Sales to Thailand Not Health Issue
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. agriculture secretary, Clayton Yeutter, said Tuesday that U.S. efforts to force open Thailand's market to foreign cigarettes have ``nothing whatsoever to do with health.'' Yeutter said Thailand discriminates because it allows its national tobacco monopoly to sell cigarettes, but it forbids imports. He was responding to questions after speaking to the Federation of Thai Industries. Yeutter will end a four-day visit to Thailand on Wednesday. Anti-smoking groups in the United States and Thailand have accused the United States and its tobacco industry of trying to export cancer. They say the sale of U.S. brands will lead to aggressive advertising and an increase in smoking, especially among children and women. However, foreign brands are readily available on the Thai black market, which is rarely policed. The United States this year asked the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a global trade organization, to judge the dispute. As the former U.S. trade representative, Yeutter opened Japanese, South Korean, and Taiwanese markets to foreign cigarettes. ``Whether the country be Thailand or Korea or Japan or any other, including the United States, the rules must be the same for imported products as they are for domestic products,'' he said. ``It shouldn't make any difference whether it's tobacco ... or semiconductors or soybeans.''

DOC.HEAD: Jazz Bassist Louis Vola Dies at Age 88
DOC.TEXT: Jazz bassist Louis Vola, a founding member of the legendary Hot Club Quintet in the 1930s, has died after a long illness, friends announced Tuesday. He was 88. Born in the Riviera town of La-Seyne-Sur-Mer, Vola helped found the quintet in 1934 and played bass on the first recordings by fellow group members Django Reinhardt and Stephane Grappelli. Vola went on to play bass in Ray Ventura's orchestra. He also backed up Benny Carter and Duke Ellington and the French singers Charles Trenet, Yves Montand and Georges Brassens. Friends said Vola died last week in a Paris hospital. There was no announcement on funeral services or survivors.

DOC.HEAD: Paper Warns Against Using Money to Make Handicrafts
DOC.TEXT: A fad among Chinese students of using money to make paper handicrafts drew a warning from an official newspaper Tuesday. Students in the industrial metropolis of Shanghai have been using Chinese ``renminbi,'' or the ``people's money,'' to make origami, intricately folded figures, the Youth Post reported. It said the fad was cause for concern. ``It is every citizen's duty to treasure the people's money. Using it to make handicrafts shows a lack of respect and also increases the burden on banks,'' the report said. ``It is not to be recommended.''

DOC.HEAD: China Evacuating Thousands of Its Citizens From Kuwait
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Chinese government announced Tuesday that it was evacuating thousands of its citizens from Kuwait, the official Xinhua News Agency reported. An unidentified Foreign Ministry spokesman was quoted as saying Chinese citizens who were involved in business, trade and other activities in Kuwait were safe but were unable to continue their work. The report did not give a precise figure for the number of Chinese in Kuwait. Earlier news reports said Chinese in Kuwait included students as well as diplomats and embassy staff, but also did not give any figures. Xinhua said the Chinese government was contacting the Iraqi government to request cooperation for the ``smooth return'' of Chinese from Kuwait to China. China has condemned the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and supported a U.N. Security Council resolution to impose economic sanctions against Baghdad. Beijing supplied billions of dollars of arms to both Iran and Iraq during their eight-year war and said it will cease arms sales to Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Begin Registering News Organizations; Prices Rising
DOC.TEXT: The government newspaper Izvestia on Tuesday became the first Soviet publication to register under a new press law guaranteeing freedom from decades of state censorship. While the new law appears to open new opportunities for prospective publishers and free the media of tight state political control, another move announced Tuesday could decrease readership. The State Press Committee announced a doubling in the price of many publications, blaming increases in the cost of paper, printing equipment and transportation. The popular magazine Ogonyok, which now costs 40 kopecks at the newstand, will rise to about 1 ruble _ more than double its price. The price of books also is expected to more than double, officials said. Some politicians have called the planned increases an attack on glasnost, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's campaign for greater openness. Boris N. Yeltsin, president of the largest Soviet republic, Russia, told speakers at a meeting in the northern Russian city of Vorkuta on Monday that the Soviet parliament had been too easy on the Communications Ministry. ``We should have taken it under control. ... We'll return to the issue and after that they will probably stop their attacks on glasnost,'' Yeltsin said in remarks reported by the Interfax news agency, an arm of Radio Moscow. Press committee officials in Moscow said the Communications Ministry is billions of rubles in debt because of the increases in production costs. They also said newstand prices could remain the same if the unions and other groups that publish periodicals were willing to sacrifice their profits to cover the increases. Dmitri Mamleyev, first deputy chairman of the State Press Committee, told a news conference that none of the old or new national publications applying for registration has been turned away. More than 120 newspapers and other Soviet news organizations have applied. The new press law, approved unanimously by the Supreme Soviet in June after months of debate, took effect Aug. 1. ``Goodbye, Censorship,'' read an Izvestia headline on the first day of the new law. On Tuesday, it headlined an article about its latest move, ``Izvestia Registers No. 1.'' The new law forbids censorship of the mass media. In addition, to establish a publication or news organization, Soviets need only provide their name, address, frequency of publication, circulation figures and source of financing. All will be permitted except those urging the violent overthrow of the government, promoting racial or religious intolerance or publishing propaganda for war, violence or cruelty, according to the law. In addition to Izvestia, the government issued certificates later Tuesday to the Moscow city council's Kuranty (Chime) newspaper, the privately funded Original and the Academy of Sciences' Poisk (Quest) newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: Hoses Banned as Drought Turns Green and Pleasant Land Brown
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Julio Sastre says he often gets dirty looks from the neighbors when he waters his garden. A ban on garden hoses is in force in drought-hit Kent county and other parts of southern England, and Sastre says suspicious minds do not believe that he is simply using water recycled from his bath and kitchen. Drought? In rainy England? Yes indeed. Some areas have gone 36 straight days without rain, and 18 million people are under the so-called hosepipe ban. Temperatures of more than 85 degrees are turning parts of the green and pleasant land a depressing brown. Says Sastre, who lives in the Kent village of Borstal: ``We never thought we would have to pray for rain.'' Some showers fell on Kent on Tuesday but hardly made a difference, said Chris Lakeland of the London Weather Center. ``Unfortunately over the next couple of days the places that want the rain won't get it, and those that don't want it will,'' he said. In Kent and elsewhere, water authority inspectors are on the prowl. The fine for illegal hose use has just been raised five-fold to 2,000 pounds, about $3,750. Neighbor is expected to snitch upon neighbor. ``One doesn't like to encourage the idea of sneaking,'' said Dennis Field, area manager of Southern Water, Kent's water company. ``We're not trying to cause bad feeling among neigbors. ``But if people are suffering under a ban and they see their neighbors abusing the system, then they're inclined to report them.'' Southern Water says Sastre is doing nothing illegal by rigging a pump to his drainage system and reusing dirty water. But in a telephone interview, Field worried about less honest garden-lovers installing a pump and then running clean water through it from the faucet. Sastre said people often stop and glare at him as he waters the garden, and one neighbor has reported him to the authorities. Traditional English reserve doesn't apply, he said in a telephone interview. ``These people don't come out and ask me what I'm doing. I would willingly part with the information. But instead they just stand there giving me dirty looks.'' The water companies suffer from an image problem. They have been broken up into private-sector companies under the Conservative government's ``privatization'' drive to unload cumbersome state-owned industries. The consumer sees them as monopolies, more beholden to shareholders than to customers. ``Citizens are invited to ring in anonymously and squeal on neighbors,'' protested columnist Matthew Parris in the Times of London. ``Thus are we divided and ruled. Instead of joining hands as brothers in oppression and marching on our monopolist tormentors, we are to take up arms against one another.'' The industry blames the problem on a series of dry summers and winters, which have cut rainfall by 54 percent in some districts, plus on an antiquated, leaky mains system that will cost billions to modernize. Prosecutions are rare, and not always successful. Last year a woman was acquitted after proving that a photograph provided by a neighbor, which showed her watering her garden, was taken before the ban was imposed.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
Arab Editorial Opinion on Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts of editorials from newspapers in Arab countries on the Persian Gulf crisis sparked by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

From Jordan, the conservative, English-language Jordan Times commenting on Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's proposal to remove his troops from Kuwait if Israel leaves the occupied territories, if Syria leaves Lebanon, and if the United States leaves Saudi Arabia: Saddam Hussein has not fired a bullet in return for the American actions against him. Instead, he has presented a plan for ending all occupations in the Middle East and to bring about peace to this troubled area. Will all those who have a stake in averting war and massive destruction give a bit of time to discussing it? The initiative makes sense to many Arabs, and as such it is worthy of serving as a basis toward problem-solving in the area.

From Jordan, the conservative, Arabic language Al-Rai commenting on Washington's rejection of Saddam's proposal: This means in clear words that it (Washington) rejected international legitimacy ... it means it is consigning the U.N. Charter and Security Council resolutions to the trash can. It also indicates that Washington blesses the continuation of Zionist occupation of Arab lands. This enemy is still marching now toward our region pretending it wants peace and that it respects U.N. resolutions.

From the gulf state of Qatar, the pro-government, Arabic-language newspaper Al-Arab commenting on the Arab League's decision at last week's Cairo summit to send Arab troops to defend Saudi Arabia: The Cairo resolutions constitute a salient development in the course of events in the gulf, a demonstration by the majority of Arab powers in support of peace and stability in the region.

From Saudi Arabia, the pro-government, Arabic-language newspaper Al-Yawm: (Saddam Hussein is a) liar who misled his people and betrayed the Arabs only to score his expansionist ambitions. History will attest to the fact that Saddam bit the hand that tried to feed him.

From Morocco, the opposition-socialist, Arabic-language newspaper Al-Ittihad Al Ichtiraki: The greatest danger and the greatest threat to peace comes ... from foreign interventionist policy which denies the Arab world its capital role in the settling of differences, the safeguarding of regional stability and the protection of its national security. ... The great Western powers behave as though they are the instructors of the world, the guarantors of the functioning of the universe and the perfect masters of its machinery.

From Egypt, the state-owned, Arabic-language newspaper Al-Ahram, which reflects government thinking: The foreign preparations and the supplies pouring into the gulf region reflect a previously thought-out plan to stay for a long time. ... The Americans are talking about preparations to send up to 250,000 troops to Saudi Arabia, and this gives a wrong impression that it is an occupation force rather than a protective force. Therin lies the importance of the Arab League decision to send Arab troops to support the armed forces of Saudi Arabia and other gulf countries.

DOC.HEAD: King Hussein On Way To Washington After Visit to Baghdad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Bush and Hussein meeting Wednesday, details. Pick up 3rd graf pvs, `The Jorrdanian...'
DOC.TEXT: King Hussein left for Washington today to meet with President Bush, a day after traveling to Baghdad for talks with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. A senior Jordanian official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the king was carrying a letter to Bush from Saddam. The official did not disclose the contents of the letter, but said ``his majesty is carrying Saddam Hussein's views to President Bush.'' Hussein is scheduled to meet Bush Wednesday. The Jordanian official said Hussein will also ``discuss with President Bush the imposition of United Nations sanctions against neighboring Iraq and Jordan's stance on the issue.'' The Jordanian monarch has been trying to act as a mediator in the crisis created by Saddam's invasion and annexation of the oil-rich sheikdom of Kuwait two weeks ago. The state news agency Petra reported the king's visit to Baghdad Monday, but gave no details. It also said the king had telephone contacts with the leaders of Yemen, Tunisia, Sudan and the PLO in connection with the crisis. King Hussein recently spoke of ``my impossible job'' in trying to reach a diplomatic solution to the crisis sparked by Iraq's invasion and annexation of Kuwait, indicating pessimism that the crisis could be resolved without violence. The king forged a close alliance with Saddam during the 1980 outbreak of the Iran-Iraq war. The Iraqis used a crucial truck route to Jordan's Red Sea port of Aqaba to bring in weapons and other supplies. But Hussein also has stressed he still recognizes the government of the exiled emir. The king has taken a strong stand against the dispatch of U.S. forces to Saudi Arabia to protect its against a possible Iraqi attack, as well as against the decision of an Arab summit conference to send Arab troops to join the Americans. King Hussein maintains that the Kuwait crisis must be solved within an Arab context, excluding any foreign intervention.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Sanctions Have Had Limited Impact, Take Time to Work
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Trade sanctions of the type imposed on Iraq by the United Nations are difficult to enforce and often take a long time to work. The United Nations has only twice before imposed trade sanctions on nations _ South Africa and Rhodesia. In both cases, the sanctions failed to have any immediate impact, and sometimes they helped rather than hurt the nations. For example, the South African and Rhodesian governments both found that the international condemnation increased their internal support. The idea of fighting back against an unsympathetic world united whites in both nations. ``Let's show them. Be South African. Buy South African,'' said the slogan of an anti-sanctions campaign. The U.N. Security Council voted Aug. 6 to ban most trade with Iraq to force it to pull out of Kuwait. The sanctions, the toughest imposed by the United Nations in its 45-year history, are designed to cripple the oil-dependent Iraqi economy and force a quick capitulation. The only comparable action was when the United Nations imposed trade sanctions on Rhodesia in 1967 to force the white-minority government to share power with the black majority after it broke away from Britain. A far less harsh arms embargo was imposed on South Africa in 1977 to protest apartheid, and it is still in force. The restrictions imposed on Iraq, such as cutting off pipelines that carry Iraqi oil, have been put in to place far more quickly and strictly than the measures imposed on Rhodesia and South Africa. And while many U.N. members secretly violated the sanctions against Rhodesia and South Africa, the United States and other nations are using their power and extensive monitoring capabilities to ensure the sanctions against Iraq are not broken. Ironically, the U.N. sanctions helped strengthen the Rhodesian economy at first. The country was forced to reduce dependence on imports and develop its own industries to provide vital goods. This made it stronger. Rhodesia's economy boomed during the first year of sanctions. At least 250,000 new jobs were created and economic growth averaged about 10 percent annually in the first 10 years after Rhodesia declared independence. South Africa became a vital conduit for Rhodesia. Oil and other commodities were shipped through South Africa, evading U.N. sanctions. Foreign businesses helped evade sanctions for high profits, and Rhodesians set up dummy foreign firms to channel imports and exports. At least 60 U.N. nations ignored sanctions, secretly purchasing Rhodesian chrome, copper, tea and tobacco. Nations breaking sanctions included the Soviet Union, China and Czechoslovakia, which were arming the black guerrilla movements fighting the Rhodesian government. But the wave of Rhodesian prosperity also depended on the healthy world economy during the 1960s and early 1970s. When the world economy dipped, the Rhodesian economy started to suffer, and sanctions began to bite. South Africa, facing problems of its own, withdrew backing for Rhodesia, and ultimately sanctions began to take effect. Eventually the government was forced to capitulate in the face of growing guerrilla activity and accept elections that ended white rule in 1980. South Africa responded to the U.N. arms embargo by developing one of the world's most sophisticated arms industries. Faced by a cutoff of arms imports, state companies developed everything from aircraft to warships and tanks. South Africa's arms exports include long-range artillery to Iraq. South African military commanders have said the U.N. sanctions were a blessing in disguise for the country's military self-sufficiency. But other sanctions imposed by Western nations on South Africa have had more of an impact. The economy has suffered from cutoffs of credit and loans from Western banks, disinvestment by foreign firms and limits on exports and imports. ``Sanctions did certainly undercut economic growth, mostly because of capital constraints,'' said Nico Czypionka, chief economist of the Standard Bank.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Hussein Coming to US on Heels of Iraqi Trip
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; adds 6th graf with Kuwait forn minister meeting
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration today called in foreign ambassadors to consider ways to safeguard warships in the Persian Gulf from Iraqi reprisals. U.S. officials said Jordan's King Hussein would meet with President Bush on Thursday. As the gulf crisis deepened, the government urged Americans stranded in Kuwait not to flee ``due to the danger involved.'' Bush was flying back to Washington for a late afternoon news conference and a briefing by Pentagon military chiefs. Hussein was said to be carrying a letter to Bush from Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. The king has hoped to serve as a mediator between Saddam and the United States. By hesitating to support the embargo approved last week by the U.N. Security Council, he has maintained his position as a middle-man. Hussein will arrive in Washington Wednesday and then fly Thursday to the president's vacation retreat in Kennebunkport, Maine, the White House said. Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Hussein called Bush Monday night and requested the meeting. The details of the Saddam letter were not disclosed. Meanwhile, Secretary of State James A. Baker III met with Kuwait's Foreign Minister, al-Ahmad al-Jabir Al Sabah. The envoy for Kuwait's exiled rulers declined comment on their hour-long discussion at the State Department. In Atlanta, Defense Secretary Richard Cheney warned Saddam against using chemical weapons against American troops. He said there was a ``wide range of measures'' available to Bush if Saddam uses chemical weapons, but indicated strongly that the use of American chemical weapons stock was not in the cards. ``I cannot conceive of a situation where the United States would want to use chemical weapons. We're trying to discourage all nations in the world on their reliance,'' he said at a news conference at Ft. Stewart, Ga. Cheney said Iraq has 200,000 troops in Kuwait and the southern part of his own country, which abuts Saudi Arabia. ``The notion that we have overreacted is not a valid one at all,'' he said at Ft. Stewart, Ala. He said the deployment of forces ``has discouraged further aggression.'' In Washington, ambassadors from the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China _ the four other permanent members of the U.N. Security Council _ were called to the State Department for the consultations. Two options will be discussed: creating a joint military command under the United Nations and having the ships carry a United Nations flag, a senior U.S. official told The Associated Press. ``We would need to know what the role of the U.S. Navy would be,'' the official said. ``We have to exchange ideas.'' The first idea, advanced initially by the Soviet Union, is to set up a joint chiefs of staff under the Security Council to coordinate defense of the U.S., British, French and other warships in the Gulf should they come under Iraqi fire, the official said. The second option under consideration is to give the warships the protection of the U.N. flag. The United States was criticized Monday in New York by Cuba _ and questioned also by Canada, France and Malaysia _ for sending an armada to the Gulf. The official called the closed U.N. meeting, held at Cuba's behest, an informal session. He said the ships were in the gulf area at the request of Saudi Arabia and the Kuwaiti government toppled by Iraq. He said the United States would engage in combat _ individually or collectively _ only if fired upon and under Article 51 of the U.N. Charter. The Soviet, British, French and Chinese ambassadors were called to the office of Robert Kimmitt, the undersecretary of state for political affairs, to see if their governments would go along with the proposals. ``The joint chiefs have never performed this role before,'' the official said of the idea of forming a joint military command. ``The very fact we are exploring this ... mechanism shows we have no intention of ignoring the United Nations.'' The U.N. Security Council last Monday called for worldwide economic sanctions against Iraq for its invasion of neighboring oil-rich Kuwait. It was only the third such step taken by the Council in the 45-year history of the United Nations. Cuba and Yemen abstained from the 13-0 vote. Then, on Thursday, by unanimous vote, the 15 members of the Security Council declared Iraq's annexation of Kuwait ``null and void.'' In the meantime, the United States, Britain, Australia and about a dozen other nations sent warships to the Gulf. But the Security Council has not moved to enforce the sanctions with a military blockade. Concern heightened over the fate of Americans trapped in Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. The Voice of America, a radio service operated by the U.S. government, is urging the Americans still in Kuwait not to try to cross the border ``due to the danger involved,'' but advising them to get ready to leave on short notice. ``When the orderly evacuation of Americans wishing to leave Kuwait becomes possible, American citizens will be contacted by phone or by radio and information will be broadcast by the Voice of America and the BBC,'' VOA broadcasts said. About 500 Americans already have been able to sneak into Saudi Arabia, penetrating lax Iraqi security, but a caravan of others who tried to flee were forced to beat a sweltering retreat. The clandestine departures reduce the number of civilian Americans in Kuwait to 2,500, according to State Department figures. Also stranded are 500 to 600 Americans in Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Opposition To Saddam Remains Question Mark
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has systematically and ruthlessly eliminated dissent since he took power 11 years ago. The economic siege of Iraq likely will bring new hardship to his people, but it's open to question whether this will trigger serious opposition to his rule. A few weeks before he sent his troops into Kuwait on Aug. 2, Saddam arrested more than 40 senior military commanders in the latest of his periodic purges of men he suspected could challenge him, Iraqi dissident sources say. Generals who became too popular during the 1980-88 war with Iran have disappeared, fate unknown. Others died in a series of helicopter and auto accidents. They included Saddam's cousin, Adnan Khairallah, who was the defense minister. Whether the latest reported purge was linked to Saddam's invasion plans is not clear. But dissidents from various factions were reporting for some time before the arrests that there was discontent in the upper echelons of the military. Saddam, 54, is the absolute ruler of Iraq and its 16 million people. He operates through the nine-man Revolutionary Command Council and the Baath Party, which has been in power since a 1968 coup. After years as vice president and the real power in the ruling Baath Arab Socialist Party, Saddam shunted aside President Ahmad Hasan al-Bakr to take over the presidency. Saddam has packed key positions with his relatives, by blood or marriage. They answer to him alone. He is chairman of the Command Council and is also prime minister. He has a handful of long-time aides, such as First Deputy Prime Minister Taha Yassin Ramadan, who is considered his second-in-command. Another important figure is Tariq Aziz, the only Christian in his 24-man Cabinet. He is a deputy prime minister and foreign minister and Saddam's main adviser on foreign policy. Both are members of the Command Council. But Saddam is believed to wield almost total power. He is a member of the minority Sunni Moslem sect. Some 55 percent of Iraqis are Shiite Moslems, like most of Iran's 55 million people. ``Iraq is a well-organized police state and its government is one of the most brutal and repressive regimes in power today .... With the exception of freedom of worship, the Iraqi government ... ruthlessly suppresses even the smallest gesture of dissent,'' the U.S.-based Middle East Watch human rights group said in a recent report. Saddam controls Iraq's 1 million-strong armed forces and the country's security and intelligence apparatus. His intelligence services have hunted down and killed leading dissidents living abroad. Iraqis are encouraged to inform on their neighbors. During the Iran-Iraq war, Saddam publicly decorated fathers who turned in deserter sons. Publicly insulting Saddam is a capital offense, and sources in Baghdad said some Iraqis who made jokes about Saddam had their tongues ripped out. After the war against Iran, Saddam announced a package of reforms including a multiparty system, press freedom and presidential elections. Diplomats, however, said the changes were little more than cosmetic, to keep Iraqis acquiescent. That belief was underlined when the compliant parliament last month called for Saddam to be named president for life without any elections. Diplomats now expect Saddam to shelve the promised reforms, citing the crisis that he triggered. The U.N. sanctions against Iraq are the toughest ever imposed by the world body and are expected to be felt quickly. Saddam on Sunday called on Iraqis to tighten their belts for what are certain to be difficult days ahead. How long it might take for discontent to emerge is hard to say. Iraqis withstood hardship and shortages during the war with Iran, but the cease-fire raised expectations of better days. Iraq's official media daily churn out slogans hailing Saddam as the new Saladin, the 12th century Moslem warrior who defeated the Crusaders and recaptured Jerusalem. The reports make no mention of dissent. The reference to Saladin is ironic. Saladin was a Kurd, and his descendants are among the tough mountain people who have been waging a fierce war for independence against the Baghdad regime. In March 1988, Iraqi warplanes dropped poison gas bombs on the Kurdish town of Halabja, killing some 5,000 civilians. Western reporters who reached the town reported seeing hundreds of men, women and children dead. After the fighting with Iran stopped, Saddam launched a major campaign against the Kurds, again reportedly using chemical weapons. Saddam's other oppponents include the Iran-backed ad-Dawa Islami, or Islamic Call, a Shiite fundamentalist movement that has assassinated scores of Iraqi diplomats and senior officials. Hundreds of members, along with their entire families, have been reported executed.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Now Calls Kuwait a Southern Iraqi City
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein's government is now calling Kuwait one of the ``cities of southern Iraq'' after annexing the oil-rich state. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and installed a ``provisional government of free Kuwait.'' That government in turn declared a ``republic.'' Just 24 hours later, Iraq declared that it had annexed Kuwait. Iraqi spokesmen are now referring to ``Kuwait, al-Jahra ... and other cities of southern Iraq.'' Al-Jahra is one of the municipalities that made up the former state. Under the ousted emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, Kuwait was known as the State of Kuwait. It bridled at being called an ``emirate,'' because in Arabic that term connotes a tiny sheikdom or fiefdom.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Pressuring Japan to Contribute to Mideast Peace Efforts
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush pressured Japan on Tuesday to ``do its utmost'' and increase its participation in international efforts to punish Iraq for invading Kuwait. Japanese officials said they were debating what Tokyo should do because of a constitutional ban on overseas military activities. The ban stems from Japan's defeat by the United States in World War II and the postwar occupation of Japan by U.S. forces. It was the third time Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu had conferred by telephone about the Middle East crisis since the Aug. 2 invasion. A call from Bush two days after the invasion helped speed Japan's decision to announce economic sanctions. Kaifu then called the U.S. president to report Japan's action. In the latest phone call, Bush told Kaifu he hopes Japan ``will do its utmost,'' including providing support to Middle East countries ``that have sacrificed a great deal'' following the invasion, the Foreign Ministry said. Kaifu responded that Japan ``is considering how it can cooperate effectively,'' according to a ministry official. ``We are evaluating what sort of cooperation is most suitable for Japan,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Bush did not specify what contributions Japan should make, but his request for maximum efforts probably includes support for the U.S.-led multinational force that is blocking Iraqi shipping in the Persian Gulf region, said the ministry official. Japan's postwar constitution forbids the use of force to resolve international disputes. Defense Agency officials say the country cannot by law send military units to join the multinational force. As a result, ``Japan does not have any idea what to do beyond joining in the economic sanctions that have already been decided upon,'' the nationally circulated Asahi Shimbun said in an editorial Tuesday. Tokyo's sanctions include a trade embargo on Iraq and Kuwait, which together supplied 11.2 percent of Japan's oil this year. Japan's inability to decide on additional actions contributed to Kaifu's decision Monday to postpone a planned visit this week to the Middle East, news reports said. Advisers worried that if Kaifu made the trip without announcing new actions, it would give the impression Japan was not doing its share to help resolve the crisis, political aides said. Japan found itself in a similar situation in 1987, when the West demanded it aid in the effort against Iraqi and Iranian attacks on oil tankers in the Persian Gulf. Japan eventually financed a navigation system to keep track of ships in the gulf. It also gave Jordan loans and grants worth about $550 million and a credit line of $300 million, and increased the money it paid to support U.S. troops based in Japan. The Japanese government decided against sending a minesweeper to the gulf, as other countries did at that time, because of its ban on military action overseas. A Foreign Ministry official said Monday that Japan was determined to decide on ``concrete measures'' to help in the crisis. Makoto Watanabe, director of the ministry's Middle Eastern affairs bureau, said the government ``will examine all possible measures while observing the provisions of the constitution.'' ``In this rapidly changing world, Japan will be forced to make decisions on its own more frequently,'' the nationally circulated Yomiuri Shimbun said in an editorial Tuesday. ``It is now the time for the ruling Liberal Democratic Party and the opposition parties to start discussions to decide what Japan can and cannot do.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Returns to Washington for Budget, Mideast Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: News conference at 4 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: President Bush interrupted his summer vacation to return to the White House on Tuesday for a Pentagon briefing and a meeting with advisers on the impact of the Persian Gulf crisis on America's economy. The president will return on Wednesday to Kennebunkport where he will meet with Jordan's King Hussein on the crisis created by Iraq's invasion and annexation of the oil-rich sheikdom of Kuwait two weeks ago. A senior Jordanian official said in Amman that the king was carrying a letter to Bush from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. In the flurry of high-level diplomacy, Bush also was to meet late Tuesday in Washington with Foreign Minister Sheikh Saud-Al-Sabah of Kuwait. Although Bush deemed it necessary to break away for Tuesday's budget briefing, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady decided not to interrupt his own trip to take part in the talks. Brady, a key member of the budget team, remained in the Midwest on a two-day campaign swing for Republican politicians. Marlin Fitzwater, the president's spokesman, said Bush would meet with budget advisers Tuesday afternoon and travel to the Pentagon on Wednesday for an update on the gulf. Before leaving for Washington on Tuesday, Bush squeezed in a morning ride in the Atlantic on his high-speed boat, Fidelity. Returning to the dock, he showed off a 27-inch, 12-pound bluefish he caught. The president arrived at his seaside estate on rocky Walker's Point on Friday and is to remain here until Labor Day, with occasional quick trips back to Washington. Bush says he is confident that Americans do not begrudge him a vacation mixed with business. White House officials said the tense situation in the gulf dramatized the need for Congress and the administration to reach a deficit-cutting agreement to slash spending and raise taxes. The gulf crisis already has caused a spike in oil prices, creating a further drag on a sluggish U.S. economy tottering closer to a recession. The administration has said that the conflict could bring the economy's already-anemic growth rate ``closer to zero,'' but that a recession is not inevitable. Fitzwater said Bush wanted an update on the slow-moving budget talks with Congress. He said the president ``might want some discussion of any changes in our budget proposals that might have to be made to reflect the war.''

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Support for Saddam Growing, U.S. Flags Burned
LaserPhoto TLV1
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Palestinians chanting ``Death to America!'' burned American and Israeli flags Tuesday in one of several rallies in the occupied territories in support of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. In a response to growing anti-American sentiments among Palestinians, the U.S. Embassy in Tel Aviv urged Americans working in the occupied Gaza Strip to exercise caution, embassy officials said. Sources in Gaza said Americans were told not to enter trouble spots such as Palestinian refugee camps, where many pro-Saddam rallies have been held. ``There is something building up against the Americans. We are certainly on the watch. We are aware that the first target would be Americans,'' said Alexandra Senfft, spokeswoman for the U.N. Relief and Works Agency in Gaza. The agency employs three Americans and assists Palestinian refugees, mainly by providing education and medical care. She said she did not know whether American staffers were pulled off their duties in the refugee camps. U.S. Embassy spokesman Richard Langford said he was not aware of warnings issued to Americans in the West Bank. He said he did not know how many Americans were working in the occupied territories. Palestinians are celebrating Saddam as a national savior who can win back the West Bank and Gaza Strip and teach a lesson to the Americans. Israel seized the territories from Jordan and Egypt during the 1967 Middle East War. The support reached a near-frenzy earlier this week after Saddam linked a possible Iraqi pullout from Kuwait to an Israeli withdrawal from the occupied lands. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The strongest expressions of anti-American sentiment Tuesday were reported in the West Bank city of Nablus. About 100 Palestinians chanted ``Death to America'' as five activists of the Moslem fundamentalist movement Hamas set alight American and Israeli flags, Arab reporters said. Later, about 300 Palestinian marched through the Nablus market chanting ``Long live Saddam'' and other pro-Iraqi slogans. In Gaza City, dozens of youths chanted ``Saddam is here'' as they stoned Israeli border police. Slogans supporting Saddam appeared throughout the occupied lands. In the West Bank town of Bethlehem, soldiers ordered residents to paint over the slogans. Defense Minister Moshe Arens on Tuesday urged Palestinians not to support Iraq. ``They are throwing their support behind a bloodthirsty dictator. If it should lead to any increase or any acts of violence in the area, we'll know how to take care of them,'' Arens said on Israel radio. The Israeli newspaper Haaretz reported that troops were under orders to prevent any show of support for Saddam and to disperse pro-Iraqi demonstrations. Military officials denied it. ``We disperse demonstrations when we believe they will lead to violence, regardless of their theme,'' said an army official, speaking on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Boat Collides with Taiwan Patrol Ship, 21 Missing
DOC.TEXT: A fishing boat carrying 50 people who were being forced back to China rammed into a Taiwanese navy patrol ship and sank, and 21 people from the fishing boat were missing, the navy said Tuesday. In a news release, the navy said the accident occurred at 10:05 p.m. Monday when the Chinese vessel, Min Ping Yu No. 5202, sailed ``irregularly'' and slammed into the patrol ship. The navy ship was monitoring the forced repatriation of the illegal aliens from mainland China. The collision was at sea 13 miles north of the port of Keelung. The statement said 29 people from the fishing boat were rescued, and 21 were missing. Those saved were taken back to Keelung. The boat had left Nan Fang Ao, a fishing port in northeastern Taiwan, on Monday to return to China under orders of the government of Taiwan. Except for the crewmen, those on board were put in a cabin nailed shut with wood planks over the door. This was to prevent the illegal immigrants from jumping overboard and trying to return to Taiwan, officials said. Taiwan has repatriated more than 10,000 mainland Chinese since 1987 by forcing fishing boats that sneak into Taiwanese waters to return to China. Over the last decade, tens of thousands of Chinese have tried to illegally enter Taiwan to seek a better life on the prosperous island. Last week, China's official Xinhua News Agency claimed Taiwanese authorities sealed 26 Chinese in the cabins of a fishing boat and sent them back to China, causing 25 of them to suffocate to death. Taiwan denied the report and said authorities repatriated mainland Chinese in humane way. The Nationalist government was driven from the mainland to Taiwan by the Communists in 1949.

DOC.HEAD: Consumers Slow to Buy
DOC.TEXT: Retail sales were virtually flat in July, edging up just 0.1 percent, the government said Tuesday, and analysts predicted consumers will cut back spending even further because of rising oil prices. The Commerce Department said sales rose a seasonally adjusted $149.5 billion last month, up just $132 million from June. Nevertheless, some economists were encouraged by upward revisions showing stronger sales in May and June than previously had been reported. ``When you combine July with a restatement of more momentum in the prior months, you've got a consumer hinting at a firming of demand as the second half of the year got under way,'' said Steven S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Co. But that data has been ``rendered obsolete'' for now by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the resulting surge in oil prices, Roach and other analysts added. If the price of oil remains about $25 a barrel, ``the average American household will pay $260 more per year,'' Roach said. ``That obviously will put a crimp in consumer buying.'' ``The impact will have to be negative,'' agreed Lea Tyler, senior economist with the WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. ``The question is, how big?'' Consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity and has fueled much of the economic growth since the last recession ended in 1982. Retail sales themselves represent about half of overall consumer spending. In its revisions, the Commerce Department said June sales jumped a strong 1.1 percent rather than the 0.5 percent gain it reported last month. At the same time, it said May sales declined just 0.1 percent rather than the 0.7 percent first believed. The adjustment in the May figure, combined with declines in April and March, still meant sales had fallen for three consecutive months _ the first time that had happened since the recession year of 1981. Sales of durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last more than three years _ rose 0.3 percent in July following a 0.4 percent gain the previous month. Building materials were up 3.9 percent while furniture and other household furnishing sales rose 2.5 percent. But a 0.6 percent tumble in automobile sales wiped out a 0.6 percent advance in June. Weakness in auto sales has been a major factor contributing to the overall sluggishness of consumer spending this year. Excluding autos, retail sales were up 0.3 percent. Non-durable goods sales were unchanged following a 1.5 percent gain in June. Department store sales posted a 0.8 percent advance after a revised 3.5 percent increase the previous month. June department store sales first were reported to have risen 2.8 percent. Grocery store sales were up 0.4 percent while drug store sales climbed 0.6 percent. But sales fell in three non-durable sectors _ gasoline station purchases were off 0.3 percent, clothing sales were down 0.9 percent and sales at restaurants and bars fell 0.4 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Word Battle: Eulogy of a ``Disgraced'' Knight
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
By ALY MAHMOUD
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Reviving traditions as old as Arab history, two renowned Arab poets have brandished virulent words against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's military stab into Kuwait. Writers have unleashed a barrage of condemnations and lamentations that depict Saddam as a ``knight-turned-thief'' and an ``ungrateful, perfidious brother.'' Ghazi al-Gusaibi, a respected thinker and former Cabinet minister who now serves as Saudi Arabia's ambassador to Bahrain, fired the first poetic salvo. Suad al-Sabah, cousin of the exiled emir of Kuwait and a confirmed poet, wrote in London a vow that Kuwaitis will fight on to liberate their homeland. Her poem was widely distributed in the Persian Gulf. Demoting Saddam to a ``fallen, disgraced knight,'' al-Gusaibi reminded him that he owes his might and stature to Arab benefactors. He was alluding to Kuwait and Saudi Arabia which, according to gulf-based Arab and Western diplomats, poured more than $34 billion into Iraqi coffers to help defray costs of the 1980-88 war with Iran. ``We turned you into our sword, but look...the sword has cut a deep wound into our heart,'' al-Gusaibi decried in the poem, published in the pro-government newspaper al-Sharq al-Awsat. ``And once you were our shield, but behold... the shield has turned into a burning lance in our back.'' The poet wondered how the gulf Arabs once looked upon Saddam as a trusted friend, and how they took him for a faithful brother. He reminded the Iraqi leader of his war with Iran ``When we shared with you our bread, when we wrote with our blood a covenant for which we bled.'' ``You were our army, tell us if you may...How you lost the way to Jerusalem?'' al-Gusaibi asked. ``A giant in our eyes you were, how ugly a giant you've become ... In the dark you've killed a tender (Kuwait) bird.'' He dismissed Saddam as a ``disfigured knight, turning into a killer-thief in the dead of night...an insolent liar outright.'' Saddam will not last, he concluded, because ``No perfidious comrade ever can survive.'' The poet, once a leading citizen of the oil-rich kingdom, in recent years lost his Cabinet portfolio on account of a poem in which he bitterly criticized his king. The Kuwaiti emir's cousin writing in London said: ``Never will you steal from us daylight... You came at dawn with a tank that we'll fight...We'll resist the tank and the rogue ... has a tank ever conducted a dialogue?'' ``We, young and old, reject oppression... Wherever you go in Kuwait, with vile aggression ... sands will turn into rocks of gloom, and the sea into a fire of doom,'' she wrote. ``What you (Saddam) dub a great epic and stride, I call it a tragic fall and suicide.'' Ms. al-Sabah reviled Saddam who ``ruthlessly ruined my home...when we gave him in our hearts a home... We gave him God's victory and exaltation...and he repaid us with invasion and occupation.'' She lamented ``a stab in my back with an Arab sword, tinges history with disgrace... when my cousin slaughters me with no warning word, the Arab unity dream becomes sawdust flying in space.'' Poetic expression is an Arab legacy dating back to pre-Islamic times, when the bards and orators assembled with their tribal groups once a year at a marketplace called Okaz to compete for acclaim. Tribal wars, peace treaties and vendettas were attributed to Okaz poems. Concepts of unfounded pride, exaggerated praise and slander that elevated common men to legendary heights and humiliated kings also were attributed to Okaz poems. Kuwaiti poet Abdul-Rahman al-Najjar joined the current parade of anti-Saddam poets with nine lines in the London-based Kuwaiti newspaper al-Qabas International. ``Sons of homeland, O son, remain free...despite fires, misfortune and the invasion spree,'' he wrote. ``Folks of dignity are never deterred, be them living or even interred.'' The current poetic fury reminds Persian Gulf nationals of the Egyptian poets Ahmed Fuad Nejm and the blind Sheik Imam, who composed prolific ballads against the late President Gamal Abdel-Nasser and his successor, Anwar Sadat. One of their last ones discussed the U.S.-brokered Camp David peace treaties between Egypt and Israel. ``They have sold our guns and our galabiya (native robe) for a phony peace,'' Imam wailed. ``In moving sands, forlorn Egypt is lonesome without its Arab folks.''

DOC.HEAD: UPI Laying Off 31
DOC.TEXT: United Press International will lay off 31 employees, transfer others and leave some small news bureaus with no staff as part of a series of organizational changes, the news agency said Tuesday. The Washington-based wire service is also negotiating to purchase the use of the news report of States News Service, another Washington-based news organization, as part of a joint venture intended to supplement its own coverage of the federal government, a UPI spokesman said. The spokesman, Milt Capps, said four regional reporters who had been tailoring UPI reports of federal news for individual states and regions will be assigned other duties. He said UPI's coverage on Capitol Hill will not otherwise be affected. Capps said the layoffs involve 16 fulltime employees and 15 probationary staff members in UPI bureaus around the country. The Washington Post said the wire service plans to eliminate one-person bureaus in Green Bay, Wis.; Scranton, Pa.; Atlantic City, N.J.; Springfield, Mass. and Fairfax County, Va. Capps confirmed that reporting of news in nearby Fairfax County will now be handled by UPI's Washington bureau but said he would not address other details. He did say that although some of the news bureaus are not now being staffed, UPI has not closed them and retains the option of reassigning reporters to them. ``We aren't reducing any of our coverage in those areas,'' Capps said. ``We do not consider that there will be any substantive change in our reporting from those regions.'' He said the changes are part of a long-term strategy aimed at trimming personnel costs while sharing news reporting with joint-venture partners, including Financial News Network, a cable television network. UPI is owned by Infotechnology Inc., which also owns 47 percent of FNN. ``Our aim is to free up additional resources to differentiate UPI's reports from those of our competitors in ways that cannot be easily duplicated,'' Capps said.

DOC.HEAD: Women's Focus on Depression May Lengthen It, Researcher Says
DOC.TEXT: Women may have longer depressions than men partly because they tend to dwell more on the low mood, a researcher suggested Tuesday. That may be a way to figure out why the depression occurred, but works ``in a way that gets you stuck in a downward cycle,'' said Susan Nolen-Hoeksema. Some small preliminary studies lend support to the hypothesis, the Stanford University researcher said at the annual meeting of the American Psychological Association. She called it one of several possible explanations for recent, early evidence that women tend to have longer depressions and run a higher risk of multiple episodes. The rumination reaction includes focusing on such things as how tired and unmotivated one feels, and on possible causes and consequences of the depression. It contrasts with a ``distractive'' response, in which a person does things to get his or her mind off the depression. In one study, 43 men and 36 women, all depressed, filled out a form every day for a month. They reported how they felt that day, how severe the depression was, and which of 32 coping responses they used that day. On average, women reported more ruminative responses, such as seeking solitude to think about their depression, than men did. Their average was about three out of the 16 listed, versus two for the men, Nolen-Hoeksema said. The difference was statistically significant, she said. No one person could report all 16 ruminative responses because some of them were mutually exclusive, she said. Analysis also showed that the degree of rumination was related to the depression's impact on a person, she said. Impact accounted for severity and duration of depression. Degree of rumination also was related to the number of days that a person felt moderate or severe depression, she said. Gender played no role in that, she said. In a second study, 25 men and 25 women were made to feel sad by reading a sad story. Then they could choose a card-sorting task that focused on their feelings, or a distracting card-sorting task in which they ranked nations by level of industrialization. Seventy-nine percent of the women but only 52 percent of the men chose the emotion task, Nolen-Hoeksema said. Her hypothesis appears ``very plausible'' as a partial explanation for the sex differences in depression, said psychology professor Paul Blaney of the University of Miami. Studying such vulnerabilities in women may lead to identifying them in some men as well, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Denies Subsidizing Mexico's Debt Reduction Agreement
DOC.TEXT: A senior Treasury official vigorously denied Tuesday a congressman's charge that the Bush administration spent $192 million to subsidize Mexico's debt reduction agreement with commercial banks. Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the House Banking Committee, said such a Mexican transaction, completed in January, is just one of a number of ``back-door financing schemes'' put together ``behind closed doors'' to fund Treasury's international operations. ``Mexico's important. ... I come from a Mexican background, but I never felt that we had to give the family jewels in order to prove that we're good neighbors,'' Gonzalez told David C. Mulford, under secretary of the Treasury for international affairs, at a hearing. ``We do not believe in producing subsidies for foreign governments,'' Mulford replied. ``The entire debt strategy is an indication that our efforts have been devoted to curing this problem without recourse to taxpayers money.'' The Mexican deal was the first and most important struck under the so-called Brady plan. Named after Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, it seeks to force banks to forgive part of the crushing $1.3 trillion debt burden on Third World countries in exchange for economic reforms in the nations that will make it possible for them to pay their remaining debts. At issue is whether the United States gave Mexico a favorable price when it sold $2.99 billion in zero-coupon Treasury bonds. Mexico used the bonds as collateral to guarantee repayment of its remaining debt after commercial banks agreed to accept some losses on the debt. Mulford maintained that Mexican purchase of the bonds in effect saved U.S. taxpayers more than $100 million compared with what the United States would have had to spend to raise the money in the standard way _ selling interest-paying bonds through financial markets. However, the General Accounting Office, Congress auditing arm, disputed that. It said the zero-coupon bonds sold to Mexico are the equivalent of a derivative bond product known as STRIPS, which, like a zero-coupon bond, pays no interest. Both zero-coupon bonds and STRIPS are sold at a deep discount from the face value. The bondholder reaps a profit by receiving the full face value at maturity, 30 years later. The price of the bonds sold to Mexico should have been set in relation to the price of STRIPS, which generally is somewhat lower than the price of similar interest-bearing bonds, the GAO said. However, ''Treasury set a price for the bonds that involved an effective subsidy of approximately $192 million,'' said Allan I. Mendelowitz, the GAO's director of international finance issues. Gonzalez said the larger issue was the law which gives the Treasury secretary power to make such decisions without congressional authorization. He said it amounts to a circumvention of the congressional appropriations process. However, Mulford said Treasury would continue to consider using zero-coupon bonds as it thought proper as part of Third World debt reduction deals. He said such bonds likely would be used as part of a deal in process between banks and Venezuela. Gonzalez was the only member of his 51-member panel to attend the hearing. Congress is in recess for its summer vacation.

DOC.HEAD: Network Middle East Coverage Boosts Ratings
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The networks' coverage of the Middle East crisis last week boosted ratings for their evening newscasts by 19 percent and gave them a larger average audience than prime-time entertainment shows.
