The increase was due to public interest in the news from the Middle East and U.S. military movements there, said NBC research vice president Preston Beckman. ``I have no doubt about that,'' he said Tuesday. CBS, NBC and ABC evening newcasts collectively averaged a 28.8 rating and a 60 percent share of the audience last week, compared with a 28.1 rating and 53 share for prime time programs, Nielsen audience estimates showed. ABC's front-running ``World News Tonight'' averaged a 10.6 rating. ``The CBS Evening News,'' whose anchor, Dan Rather, has been in the Middle East since Iraq's Aug. 2 in invasion of Kuwait, averaged a 9.3. ``NBC Nightly News'' ran third with an 8.9 average. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. The audience share is the estimated percentage of homes tuned to a given program in its time period. ABC research vice president Alan Wurtzel said that it's rare for news ratings to do better than entertainment ratings. He attributed last week's ratings both to viewer interest in the crisis and ``the summer doldrums in prime time viewing.'' CNN officials said their network's ratings had generally doubled; the newscasts were seen in 763,000 homes Friday night, and 659,000 homes on Sunday. Viewers of Monday night's network newscasts saw the first TV footage from a press pool flown out to the carrier Independence in the Gulf of Oman. CBS anchorman Rather, among the correspondents on the big ship, taped his anchor portion of the ``CBS Evening News'' there. Although the TV correspondents had to share pool video footage shot by a network cameraman, Rather's report included a home-video segment taped by an unidentified sailor. It showed Rather touring the ship and interviewing crewmen. While in the ship's boiler room, Rather, using a microphone attached to the sailor's videocamera, alluding to the star of ``Top Gun,'' told viewers: ``Tom Cruise doesn't make movies about this place.'' ``Hi, Mom and Dad,'' said one grinning young sailor as Rather held the microphone up for him. Under press pool rules, CBS had to share Rather's home-video footage, some of which was fuzzy and taken in poor light. But there were no takers, spokesmen for the other networks said Monday. The quality wasn't good, said David Miller, NBC's foreign news editor: ``I thought it was shabby.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Bert Parks, who last sang ``There She Is'' 11 years ago to Miss America, will return to perform in this year's pageant, a spokeswoman for the event said Tuesday. His exact role will be announced at a news conference Wednesday in New York, pageant spokeswoman Mary McGinnis said. Pageant director Leonard Horn previously said Parks was invited to the pageant's 70th anniversary, with at least 26 former Miss Americas returning. In response, Parks, 75, said he wanted to do more than serenade the winner with his trademark song. A message left Tuesday at Parks' Greenwich, Conn., home was not returned. Parks was fired in January 1980 after being host of the Miss America Pageant for 25 years. Then-pageant director Albert Marks Jr., who died last year, said Parks was too old at age 65 to continue as host. The firing drew a nationwide protest, including a mail-in campaign organized by Johnny Carson. But Parks later joked that the firing was the best thing to happen to his career, because he got other jobs, including host of the Mrs. America Pageant and the national finals of a small dog contest. Gary Collins and Phyllis George are co-hosts of the pageant again this year. Last year, Collins sang ``There She Is'' to the winner.

Curtis Mayfield, a rhythm and blues singer popular in the 1960s and '70s, was seriously injured by a lighting tower toppled by wind at an outdoor music festival. Mayfield, 48, was listed in critical but stable condition Tuesday at Kings County Hospital with head and neck injuries. Three stagehands and four concert volunteers also were hurt, police spokeswoman Sgt. Mary Wrensen said. Mayfield was preparing to perform Monday night when a gust blew over the lighting tower and some speakers. ``I had just introduced him to the crowd, and all of a sudden it was like a tornado, the wind that came through,'' said state Sen. Marty Markowitz. Chicago-born Mayfield started as a teen-age guitarist, songwriter and occasional lead vocalist for The Impressions. His hits included the civil rights song ``People Get Ready.'' He left the group in 1970 and two years later wrote the music for the film ``Superfly,'' including the song ``Freddie's Dead.'' He also wrote the soundtrack for the 1975 Bill Cosby-Sidney Poitier film, ``Let's Do It Again.''

Superman may be more powerful than a locomotive, but it's David Letterman whose motive is a bit loco. Letterman, host of the NBC's ``Late Night With David Letterman,'' was in this central Connecticut city Monday for the taping of a segment called ``Smashing Things With a Train.'' ``We hope to fill up three minutes of television time,'' Letterman said. The taping involved a train locomotive speeding along at about 35 mph into piles of crushables, including fish tanks loaded with gallon of guacamole, an ice sculpture, a big stack of melons and a superhero doll. ``We are just running over a lot of weird things with a locomotive,'' said Randy Cohen, a writer for the show. ``If it entertains America just a little, then we've done our part.'' The segment is for Friday's show.

Singer-songwriter Joan Armatrading has canceled two concerts planned for Australia later this month. Tour spokeswoman Gaynor Crawford said Tuesday that Ms. Armatrading told organizers she was acting on medical advice in canceling her visit to promote her recently released album ``Hearts And Flowers.'' Ms. Armatrading, a native of the West Indies who moved to England as a child, had been scheduled to perform in Sydney on Aug. 29 and Melbourne on Aug. 31.

Actress Esther Rolle remained in serious but stable condition Tuesday at the hospital where she is being treated for injuries suffered in a car crash Sunday. Miss Rolle, 69, remained in the intensive care unit of University Medical Center. She suffered lacerations of the head and face, fractured ribs and a bruised heart. Miss Rolle's credits include the television series ``Good Times'' and the movie ``Driving Miss Daisy.'' She was a passenger in a car that rolled over on Interstate 15 near the California border, killing the driver, Paulene Hopkins, 70, of Marshall, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: New Indictment Possible in Noriega Case
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors may ask for a new indictment in the drug-trafficking case against Manuel Noriega, a spokeswoman for the U.S. attorney's office confirmed Tuesday. ``The investigation is continuing,'' said Diane Cossin. ``Additional charges have been contemplated.'' In recent court hearings for Noriega co-defendant Roberto Steiner, prosecutors told U.S. Magistrate William Turnoff that the new indictment would broaden the charges against the 16 defendants. A source close to the investigation told The Associated Press on condition of anonymity that the new case is not ready to present to the grand jury, but Ms. Cossin refused to comment. Newsweek magazine reported this week that a separate Tampa indictment accusing Noriega of marijuana smuggling may be folded into the Miami case. The report said many consider the original Miami charges weak. Ms. Cossin would say only that the case will be tried in Miami. Noriega attorney Jon May said he had heard reports of a new indictment. ``I'm mystified by the whole thing,'' he said. ``The government doesn't need to bring a new indictment to bring new evidence in, and they certainly don't need to bring new charges to keep Noriega in jail for the rest of his life.'' The only effect of a new indictment, he said, would be to further delay the planned Jan. 28 start of the trial. The Miami indictment was issued in February 1988. It accuses Noriega, who is being held at a federal prison outside the city, of turning Panama into a way station for U.S.-bound cocaine in return for $4.6 million in bribes from Colombia's Medellin drug cartel. One co-defendant, William Saldarriaga, has pleaded guilty and agreed to testify for the government. In addition, the government has been discussing a plea bargain with Noriega aide Luis Del Cid, who accompanied the Panamanian leader on top-level trips to Cuba and allegedly collected funds for him. Those talks with Del Cid, however, have been held up by the Panamanian government's refusal to drop charges in that country, according to defense attorney Samuel Burstyn. In addition, co-defendant Amet Paredes, the son of former top Panamanian official Gen. Ruben Dario Paredes, surrendered to U.S. officials a month ago and was immediately released on bond despite charges that could put him in prison for 95 years. Noriega defense attorneys have claimed he also is bargaining with the government.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq-Bound Ships Can Transit Suez Canal Despite Sanctions
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Ships going to or coming from Iraq will be allowed to transit the Suez Canal despite international sanctions against Baghdad because of a 102-year-old treaty requiring free passage, the government said Tuesday. Under the 1888 Constantinople Convention governing navigation through the canal, ships can be denied transit only if they fly the flag of a country at war with Egypt, Cairo officials say. President Hosni Mubarak cited the convention one week ago when he rejected Iraqi demands that Egypt bar canal passage to U.S. and other naval units sent to the Persian Gulf after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``The Constantinople Convention forbids passage only to ships from countries at war with Egypt. Just like you look after your interests, I look after mine,'' Mubarak advised Iraq at the time. The Constantinople Convention provides in its first article that the canal ``will remain continuously free and open in time of peace and also in time of war before all vessels, whether commercial or military, without any discrimination.'' Article 10, however, says provisions decreeing freedom of passage shall not conflict with Cairo's need ``to defend Egypt and maintain public security therein.'' Egypt interprets this as meaning that it has the right to deny passage to ships from countries at war with Egypt. It invoked the article in denying transit to Israeli ships before the countries signed a peace treaty in 1979. Although Egypt was not officially a belligerent in World War II, British occupation forces in the canal zone closed the waterway to ships from Nazi Germany and Italy. Article 10 apparently was their justification. Egypt also normally bans passage of ships propelled by nuclear power or carrying nuclear weapons. It says the rule is necessary for the security of the waterway and the three major population centers along its 100-mile stretch. But in recent years, Cairo has bent the no-nuclear rule on several occasions to help the United States in emergency situations. Only last week, Mubarak allowed transit for the nuclear-powered U.S. aircraft carrier Dwight D. Eisenhower. The same exception was granted U.S. warships at least twice during the eight-year war between Iraq and Iran and once, in 1986, in connection with a crisis between the United States and Libya. Egypt has had a special relationship with the United States since Washington brokered its peace treaty with Israel. Cairo has received $2.1 billion annually in U.S. military and economic aid in recent years. The state-run Middle East News Agency quoted a spokesman for the Suez Canal Authority on Tuesday as saying that barring Iraqi or Iraq-bound ships was neither possible legally nor practical. ``Those who ask Egypt to close the canal to Iraq-bound ships should try to stop these ships at the points of origin, not in the channel,'' he said. The spokesman added that even if the waterway were closed to Iraq-bound vessels, ``These ships can simply change their destinations to Aqaba (in Jordan) instead of to Iraq.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Acknowledges Sending Checks to Deceased Veterans
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Veterans Affairs has paid benefits to more than 1,200 deceased veterans, including about 100 dead a decade or more, the General Accounting Office says. The agency pegs the potential annual loss due from the erroneous payments at $5.7 million. Auditors for the congressional investigating agency said the department could have reduced the erroneous payments by matching VA benefit payment files with death information maintained by the Social Security Administration. The department, agreeing with the GAO's findings, said it now intends to follow that procedure. ``We found that in April 1989 VA paid compensation or benefit payments for 1,212 veterans whom Social Security Administration records reported had died at least four months earlier,'' the GAO said in a report to the Senate Veterans Affairs Committee. ``About 100 had been dead 10 years or more.'' The Veterans Affairs Department pays out more than $14.7 billion a year in disability compensation and pension benefits to more than 2.8 million veterans and nearly 1 million surviving spouses and other dependents. The GAO said that while benefits should be ended when a beneficiary dies, ``if surviving relatives or other knowledgeable persons do not report death to VA in a timely manner, substantial erroneous payments can result.'' The agency said the department has relied on voluntary reporting of deaths as a basis for ending benefits. But investigators said the Social Security Administration goes much further, receiving reports of deaths from many sources and buying death certificate information from states. Federal agencies such as the VA are authorized to obtain this information, the GAO said. The congressional agency said that by matching VA's benefit payment file with Social Security files containing information on 39 million deaths ``we identified 1,212 veterans who were reported dead as of December 1988.'' The GAO said it first found 1,065 veterans that Social Security data showed were dead but who were still receiving VA benefits. ``Erroneous payments to these veterans' accounts could amount to $5.1 million annually,'' it said. The GAO said it then matched the VA payment file with a Social Security file containing about 450,000 death certificates purchased from the states. That search added an additional 147 deceased veterans whose bank accounts were continuing to receive payments. The GAO said it estimated these erroneous payments at $638,000. The review was conducted between August 1989 and April 1990. The Veterans Affairs Department, acting at the GAO's request, investigated several of the cases, with these results: _A veteran, identified by Social Security as having died in August 1984, continued to receive VA benefits. Records showed that a total of $30,369 in direct deposits had been made to the veteran's bank accounts. The VA ended benefit payments, concluded that overpayments of $30,000 had been made and opened an investigation. _Social Security records showed another veteran had died in September 1983 but the department continued to make direct deposit payments totaling $13,797. The payments were ended and the department is considering further action. _Social Security records showed another veteran had died on Aug. 8, 1986. VA payments had been sent since then to the veteran's last known address. The VA ended payments after determining that the veteran was indeed dead and that a sister had been cashing his checks. Erroneous payments were estimated at $2,755. In a letter to the GAO, Edward J. Derwinski, the secretary of veterans affairs, said he concurred with the agency's findings and was moving to obtain death information from the Social Security Administration. ``Upon verification of the death, we will take prompt action to stop any erroneous payment and to resolve any overpayment that would develop,'' Derwinski's letter said.

DOC.HEAD: More and More Women in Medical Schools; Minority Enrollment Stagnant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For Release at 4 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: The proportion of women in medical schools continues to grow but the percentage of black and Hispanic enrollments is largely stagnant, according to a report by the American Medical Association. One medical school dean says that's a symptom of the ``lip service'' that the nation has given to minority medical education. In the past 10 years, female enrollment at medical schools has jumped from 16,315, or 25.4 percent, to 23,501, or 36.1 percent, said a report in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association. Minority medical enrollment has remained about level, with the 4,076 black medical students last year amounting to 6.3 of all enrollees, and the 3,518 Hispanics making up 5.5 percent of medical students, the report said. A decade ago, total black enrollment was 3,708, or 5.5 percent, the AMA said. In 1979, the closest year for which comparable figures are available, Hispanic enrollment was 2,289, or 3.7 percent, it said. ``Since the early 1970s, there has been a national commitment to expand the opportunities for members of minority groups to enter medicine and other health professions,'' said the first report, headed by Dr. Harry S. Jonas, director of the AMA's Divison of Undergraduate Medical Education. ``Despite this commitment, the percentage of black and Hispanic applicants and matriculants has not shown a significant rise.'' William Wallace, associate dean of the University of Illinois School of Medicine at Chicago, disagreed with that assessment. ``I don't think there has been a national commitment (to recruit minority medical students),'' said Wallace, whose school has one of the largest minority enrollments in the country. ``The commitment has been more lip service than a national commitment.'' For example, the federal government is giving the University of Illinois' medical school less money this year than last for minority recruitment, or a total of $140,000, he said. The high cost of medical education may be one factor discouraging potential minority applicants, another report in the Journal said. The average debt for medical students who borrowed money was $42,374 at graduation in 1989, up more than $4,000 from only a year earlier. Four of five graduates were in debt. For minorities, the debt burden averaged about $6,000 higher, said researchers led by Paul Jolly of the Association of American Medical Colleges in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Four Hurt When Car Bomb Explodes by Peru's Presidential Palace
DOC.TEXT: A powerful car bomb exploded next to the Government Palace as President Alberto Fujimori was meeting with advisers, injuring four passersby, police said Tuesday. Other car bombs exploded in the highland cities of Cuzco and Ayacucho, killing one person, police said. The attacks ended a lull in political violence since Fujimori took office July 28. The car bomb attack against the palace late Monday shattered windows in the residential area of the building. The blast also blew a 3-foot-wide crater in the sidewalk and knocked chunks of concrete from the wall. Police blamed the attack on the pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement. They said the car contained 22 pounds of dynamite. Army troops and police sealed off the streets around the palace and the Plaza de Armas facing the building after the attack. One man died and at least 17 people were wounded in the blast in Cuzco, a tourist center in Peru's Andean mountains 350 miles southeast of Lima, police said. The bomb exploded Monday in front of an army barracks, one block from a leading tourist hotel. No tourists were hurt in the explosion though four soldiers were among the wounded, police said. Police said the attack was probably carried out by the Maoist Shining Path rebel movement. The Shining Path exploded 22 pounds of dynamite before dawn Tuesday in a car in the center of Ayacucho, a highland city 230 miles southeast of Lima, police said. No one was injured in the blast, which broke windows and damaged buildings. Two other bombs exploded in Ayacucho earlier Tuesday, police said. Shining Path rebels also killed three village officials near Huaraz, police said. Huaraz, 175 miles north of Lima, is a popular destination of mountain climbers. The rebels staged a trial of the three men in the plaza of a small village and then killed them each with a shot to the head. More than 19,000 people have died in political violence in Peru the past 10 years.

DOC.HEAD: Colorado Primary Focus on Senate Race, Stadium Issues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Polls close 9 p.m. EDT. Material below dash should stand.
DOC.TEXT: Two candidates battled for the Democratic U.S. Senate nomination Tuesday in the Colorado primary election and voters in metropolitan Denver were asked to approve financing for a major league baseball stadium. An estimated 1.8 million voters were eligible to cast ballots in the primary, but Secretary of State Natalie Meyer expected only about 630,000 to turn out, or about 35 percent. In the Senate primary, Josie Heath had about a 2-to-1 lead in polls over Carlos Lucero in their race for the seat now held by Republican U.S. Sen. Bill Armstrong, who did not seek re-election. Recent polls showed voters in six Denver-area counties nearly even on whether to approve a 12-year, 0.1 percent sales tax _ one cent on each $10 purchase _ that would raise $139 million for a new stadium. In the 4th Congressional District, two state senators, Wayne Allard of Loveland and Jim Brandon of Akron, faced each other in a runoff for the Republican nomination. Republicans also faced a decision in the attorney general's race between Richard ``Mac'' McManus and Gale Norton, with the winner to face Democratic incumbent Duane Woodard in November. Woodard was unopposed Tuesday.

Incumbent Gov. Roy Romer had no Democratic primary opposition and neither did his Republican opponent, John Andrews. Heath, 52, of Boulder, whose only political experience was as a Boulder County commissioner, picked up strong party support during the precinct caucuses last spring, forcing former state Democratic Chairman Buie Seawell out of the race. She captured the top line on the primary ballot at the Democratic State Assembly in June, leading Lucero by a 2-to-1 margin and kept ahead of him in the polls right up until the election. Lucero, 49, an Alamosa lawyer, kept his hopes of winning the nomination alive chiefly by mounting a relentless attack on the savings and loan scandal, particularly on Denver's Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan. Lucero had what appeared to be little party support and hardly any money. He entered politics in 1984, losing to then-Lt. Gov. Nancy Dick in a Democratic primary for the U.S. Senate. The winner will meet GOP nominee Hank Brown, who faced no opposition Tuesday. Most polls have shown Brown would easily beat the Democratic primary winner in the November general election. Allard and Brandon were vying for the right to succeed Brown in the 4th District. The Democratic nominee, state Rep. Richard Bond of Greeley, was unopposed. The proposed baseball stadium tax would not be imposed unless Denver is awarded a National League expansion franchise. The city is bidding for one of two baseball franchises to be awarded this year. Baseball proponents hope approval of the tax will lure a team.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney to Return to Saudi Arabia; Bush to Meet With King Hussein
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS graf 7, Bush himself ... to CORRECT Bush meeting with Kuwaiti foreign minister, not ambassador
DOC.TEXT: President Bush broke off his vacation today to return to the White House for budget and military briefings after agreeing to meet here Thursday with Jordan's King Hussein. Bush himself was sticking with plans to spend less than 24 hours in Washington, returning to his oceanfront compound here on Maine's rocky coast in mid-afternoon Wednesday. But the president kept up his frenetic diplomatic efforts by telephone, calling Japan's Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu Monday night and taking a call from King Hussein, just back from conferring with Iraqi strongman Saddam Hussein in Baghdad. King Hussein asked for a meeting ``to discuss the matter directly with the president,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said today. ``The president agreed and phoned the king back a short time later to confirm the arrangements.'' Fitzwater said there was ``no indication'' the king is carrying a message from Saddam, but senior Jordanian officials in Amman said the king was carrying a letter from the Iraqi leader. Bush instructed Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to head back to Saudi Arabia on Friday to visit American troops mustered in the desert and confer again with King Fahd. Bush himself planned to spend the afternoon at the White House reviewing budgetary problems with aides, facing reporters and then meeting with Kuwaiti Foreign Minister Sheikh Saud-Al-Sabah. While the White House initially said the budget session would include both Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and budget director Richard Darman, neither planned to attend. They were sending deputies in their stead. Brady was on a speaking trip for Republican candidates in the Midwest. Darman's office refused to say where he was. After spending the night in the White House, Bush will be driven to the Pentagon Wednesday morning for a full-scale military briefing on the situation in the Gulf. He also will speak to Pentagon workers in the courtyard of the huge military complex before taking a helicopter to Andrews Air Force Base and the return flight to his summer home. Bush got in a morning of fishing with his wife, Barbara, before returning to Washington. The White House said Monday it was ``very optimistic ... that the embargo will hold,'' cutting off not only Iraq's exports of oil, but also denying it food and other goods. ``The nations of the world are abiding by their commitments,'' said Fitzwater. The naval barricade forced ``two or three ships'' to turn back at sea without reaching Iraqi ports, he added. The White House said the gulf crisis has added new urgency to the quest for a bipartisan agreement to reduce the gaping federal deficit. ``We think it's even more important that we reach an agreement now because there needs to be a unity of purpose in this country, not only about the conflict in the gulf, but also about our spending issues and about where the budget is going,'' Fitzwater said. Bush stayed out of the public eye Monday, calling Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez to discuss the crisis and world oil supplies, and relaxing by taking his high-speed boat Fidelity out on fishing runs in the Atlantic. In Tokyo, Foreign Ministry officials said Bush asked Kaifu that Japan boost its aid to Middle East countries hurt by the embargo on trade with Iraq. The ministry did not specify which nations might be involved, but Egypt, Jordan and Turkey are among Japanese aid recipients affected by the increased tensions. Fitzwater declined to reveal what the two leaders talked about. Bush plans to return to Maine by mid-afternoon Wednesday after his military briefing and a speech to Pentagon employees. But he may do more shuttling back to Washington before his crisis-clouded vacation ends on Sept. 3.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Says His Life After Electoral Defeat Is `Rich'
DOC.TEXT: Daniel Ortega says he doesn't miss being president of Nicaragua and is enjoying his new role as a leader of the political opposition. Ortega, who was defeated in elections Feb. 25 after ruling his Central American nation for 10 years, said in an interview Tuesday that his Sandinista National Liberation Front was revamping itself to appeal to a broader range of Nicaraguan voters. The Sandinistas this month began holding ``public debates'' in Nicaragua for people to tell Sandinista leaders what they did wrong and what they did right during their rule, Ortega said. ``The door is open for everyone to talk,'' the former president said. The criticism will lead to a reformation of the party's policies and objectives, with an eye on the country's next elections, in 1996, Ortega said. He said it was too early to tell if he will be the Sandinista's presidential candidate. Ortega came to New York this week to maintain ties with supporters here _ he gave a speech in a church Monday night to 2,500 people _ and to contact publishers for a book he plans to write. The book might be a work of fiction based on fact, he said, drawing on his own experiences. Ortega acknowledges that the Sandinistas committed several errors, which sent many Nicaraguans over to the side of U.S.-supported Contra rebels who fought for almost a decade to overthrow the leftist government, at a cost of some 40,000 lives. In the days after the Sandinistas toppled Anastasio Somoza in July 1979, the dictator's supporters, the Somocistas, were targeted to have their large land holdings redistributed to the poor. ``Some landowners were affected who weren't precisely Somocistas,'' Ortega acknowledged. ``The urgent demand for land made us act in a hasty way, giving a very negative impression to rural people,'' he said. ``This gave the Contras the opportunity to say the Sandinistas want to take land away from everyone.'' Ortega said the Sandinistas also mistreated the Miskito Indians, who opposed the government and were forcibly removed from their homelands in northeastern Nicaragua in the early 1980s. The Miskito and other Indian tribes joined the Contra's armed resistance to Sandinista rule, largely because of the relocation program. Ortega appeared relaxed during the 45-minute interview, conducted in Spanish at the apartment of a friend of his former foreign minister, Miguel D'Escoto, who also came on the trip to the New York. The apartment on New York's exclusive Upper East Side, decorated with a Picasso and other priceless artworks, seemed an incongruous setting for the former revolutionary. Ortega, who robbed banks in his early teens to get money for the anti-Somoza insurrection, wore a blue blazer and necktie. ``It's unprecedented for a revolutionary who fought a dictatorship with weapons to later win power and then become the opposition ... within a democratic context that he himself helped create,'' he said. ``So I think this is a rich experience.'' The Sandinistas have organized two strikes since President Violeta Chamorro was inaugurated April 25, imperiling her new government and raising fears that the Sandinistas would try to wrest power away from her. Ortega said the Sandinistas will not use forcible means. ``If we are going to return to running the government of Nicaragua, it will be through elections.''

DOC.HEAD: So Far, the Enemy is the Heat
EDITOR'S NOTE _ The following is based on pool dispatches.
DOC.TEXT: With no Iraqis in sight, the biggest problem for American troops deployed in the desert sands is the 115-degree heat. Soldiers in full battle dress added a chic touch to their gear _ liter bottles of mineral water. The U.S. forces were told to drink at least six gallons of water a day. One medic said Tuesday he had treated numerous dehydration cases, some requiring intravenous injections of nutrient-rich fluids. Troops at a staging camp said the heat had ``fried'' some radios, rendering them useless. Even reporters _ members of the Pentagon-organized news pool _ had to wear long pants. The Saudis frown on shorts. Perhaps such hardships are just as well. ``They could put us up in air-conditioned buildings,'' said a 24-year-old medic from Hollywood, Fla. ``But then, if we have to fight people used to this, we're not going to last very long. ``I'm like their mother,'' the medic told Peter Copeland, a reporter for Scripps Howard News Service. ``It's my job to see that they eat, and if you see a guy with two full canteens, you know he's not drinking.'' As the American buildup continued, U.S. forces took up positions side-by-side with Saudi marines at a Saudi naval base near vital oil terminals. Transport planes continued landing U.S. troops and materiel at an air base elsewhere in the country. A British Airways jet was also seen arriving. Already lined up at the airport were dozens of Saudi fighter jets and a smaller contingent of Canadian fighters. U.S. bulldozers, front-end loaders, armored vehicles and jeeps lined the base roads. Pallet after pallet of munitions, gear, food and other supplies were stacked along the roads. In all, the American reporters visited with members of the 82nd Airborne at three sites _ the naval base, the air base and a nearby air-defense camp that the Saudis have given over to the Americans. Ground rules for the pool prohibit the release of exact numbers of weapons, exact locations of U.S. deployments and the names of most troops here. Only officers with command duties can be quoted by name. Tuesday's tour gave the pool reporters their first chance to see U.S. troops in the field with Saudi forces. At the naval base, the 82nd was working to secure the area for Marines, who began arriving in Saudi Arabia Monday. While at the base, two lengthy convoys of double-decker buses carrying U.S. troops passed along a nearby highway to a barracks area of the sprawling base. A small detachment from the 82nd took up positions on sand dunes overlooking the water. Nearby were Saudi forces from the naval base. The air defense camp bristled with Vietnam-era M551 Sheridan airborne-assault vehicles _ light tanks that can be air-dropped. Also at the site was a multiple rocket launcher. As the troop presence intensifies, many foreign civilians are leaving the area. Cmdr. Christopher J. Elles, who heads a 20-member U.S. Navy training detachment in Saudi Arabia, said 10,000 foreign nationals, including about 2,000 Americans, had left the city where he is stationed since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Many of those are relatives of oil workers who have stayed behind. Asked about the defenses in place at the oil facilities, Elles said, ``One bomb in the right place obviously would create a lot of problems.'' He added, ``That's a personal opinion.'' With the exception of the Canadian jets, the reporters have not seen forces from any other nations. Diplomatic sources in Riyadh, the capital, said Syrian units landed Tuesday to join U.S., British, Egyptian and other forces. ``There's a great deal of working relationships that have to be worked out,'' Elles said of the growing multinational defense force. One of those relationships involves respect for the Saudis' Islamic faith. At one spot on the naval base, Americans and Saudis are housed in tents about 50 yards apart. Between the tents, Copeland's report said, is an area with two 25-foot-long pieces of canvas. The Saudis asked the Americans not to step there because that is where they face Mecca and pray five times daily. How do the two tents communicate? A 26-year-old Saudi sergeant had this answer, delivered through an interpreter: ``Some of us speak a little English. Or we use Arabic. But, mostly, it's sign language.'' And what do they talk about? ``Whatever comes to mind,'' the sergeant said. Often, the talk is about the heat. The Saudi sergeant, sweat running down his face into a thick, black beard, said of his American counterparts, ``God willing, they will get used to the heat soon.'' His advice to the Yanks: ``Keep the flaps of your tent open.''

DOC.HEAD: Jordan Continues Shipments to Iraq Despite Embargo
LaserPhoto AMM1
DOC.TEXT: Truckloads of goods rolled into Iraq from Jordan and Iraqi-bound cargo was unloaded from ships at the southern port of Aqaba on Tuesday, despite U.N.-ordered sanctions against Baghdad. King Hussein flew to Washington on Tuesday for talks with President Bush, still refusing to sever what could become Iraq's economic lifeline. The king departed carrying a message to Bush from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, with whom he met Monday. This indicated Hussein is still hoping for a diplomatic solution to the crisis caused by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Hussein's refusal to comply with the embargo against Iraqi goods stems from the impact this would have on Jordan's fragile economy and the expected violent reaction from the largely pro-Iraqi Jordanians. Foreign Ministry Undersecretary Mutasem Belbeisi explained that though the U.N. sanctions are mandatory, ``every country whose economy can be severely affected can consult with the Security Council to see what measures could be adopted and what sanctions could be imposed, if any.'' Western diplomats said the Jordanian delegation to the United Nations was discussing this point in New York. The imposition of sanctions by Jordan would block 40 percent of the country's total exports and raise Jordan's 16 percent unemployment rate by 10 percent to 12 percent, Jordanian officials say. In addition, Jordan imports 90 percent of its domestic oil needs from Iraq. In Israel, meanwhile, parliamentarian Binyamin Ben-Eliezer demanded Tuesday that Israel impose a blockade on the Jordanian port of Aqaba, where Iraq-bound supplies were being unloaded. The southern port is the last opening for goods to reach Iraq if Western vessels completely seal the Persian Gulf. Its closure could have a severe impact on Iraq, which is heavily dependent on imported foodstuffs and other goods. Associated Press photographer Martin Cleaver said three ships docked in the port Tuesday and were unloading. Norwegian newspapers reported that police in Aqaba ordered a Norwegian ship to unload corn bound for Iraq after the captain stopped deliveries. Cleaver said one of the ships was the Tanga, from Norway. He could not confirm that police had ordered it to be unloaded. Photographers were unable to approach the Tanga, which was heavily guarded by Jordanian troops. Numerous loaded trucks were driving north from Aqaba toward Amman and the Iraqi border. It was unclear which of the cargoes were destined for Iraq. AP photographer Yousef Allan reported from the Ruweishid border post, on the main highway linking Jordan with Iraq, that the volume of heavy trucks and oil tankers traveling both ways had increased over the past few days. Officials at the Ministry of Commerce said oil also continued to flow out of Iraq through a small pipeline to a point near Amman. It is Iraq's last operating oil pipeline, since Saudi Arabia and Turkey have stopped shipments of Iraqi oil transported through pipelines on their territory. Jordanian Commerce Ministry officials said apart from Jordanian domestic needs, the operating pipeline is only used to transport $50 million worth of oil annually to Brazil. In the Persian Gulf, U.S. and British warships have reportedly started checking for shipping bound for Iraqi ports, Western diplomats said. The diplomats said if Jordan continued to serve as a transit point for Iraqi goods it could harm the multinational barricade. But they said it was unlikely U.S. warships would intervene in the Gulf of Aqaba to stop and check shipping. King Hussein is eager to act as an intermediary in what he has described as ``the impossible job'' of settling the Kuwait crisis peacefully through Arab mediation. He flew to Baghdad on Monday for consultations with the Iraqi leader. The official Jordanian news agency, Petra, did not announce his trip until after the king returned home Tuesday. Petra said the king also talked by telephone to the leaders of Yemen, Tunisia, Sudan and the Palestine Liberation Organization.

DOC.HEAD: Arens: Israel Will Not Interfere If Jordanians Break Embargo
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Leads with 12 grafs to ADD legislator's demand for blockade of Aqaba, reports of ships unloading at Jordanian port. Corrects typos in 3rd and 14th grafs. Pickup 15th graf pvs, `During those...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israeli officials on Tuesday urged neighboring Jordan to join the international embargo against Iraq, but Defense Minister Moshe Arens said Israel would not take action if Jordan ignored the pleas. ``There is no reason for us to interfere,'' Arens told Israel radio. ``Israel is not part of the sea embargo declared by the United States. This is being carried out with American ships and European ships ... We are not part of this.'' His remarks were in line with Israel's stated policy not to become directly involved in the current crisis. However, Israel has repeatedly said that if neighboring Jordan allowed the Iraqi army to use Jordanian territory, it would attack. Washington has been careful not to enlist Israel, its closest ally in the region, for fear such a move would anger Arab states now backing the West. International attention is increasingly focusing on Jordan and its Red Sea port of Aqaba, the last opening for goods to reach Iraq if the Persian Gulf is sealed. Binyamin Ben-Eliezer, deputy head of the Parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee, demanded Tuesday that Israel impose a blockade on Aqaba. U.S. media reports said an Iraqi freighter carrying weapons was en route to Aqaba, which is on the Jordanian-Israeli border and only five miles from the Israeli resort of Elat. Three ships docked in the port Tuesday and were unloading, according to Associated Press photographer Martin Cleaver. In addition, numerous loaded trucks were driving north from Aqaba toward Amman and the Iraqi border. It was unclear which of the cargoes were destined for Iraq. An Israeli government official urged Jordan to end ``its very hesitant policy'' toward Iraq. ``We hope that Jordan will join the international consensus and join the embargo,'' said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity. He said Aqaba would play a central role in the American showdown with Iraq. ``Aqaba will be of major importance for Iraq's ability to survive,'' he said. Other government officials said they were watching traffic in the Gulf of Aqaba very closely and had not noticed any substantial increase. Shish Dekel, the captain of an Israeli yacht moored in Elat, also said traffic in Aqaba port appeared to be normal. Dekel, speaking on Israel radio, said that at the height of the Iran-Iraq war, when Iraq did not have access to Persian Gulf ports, as many as 90 ships with cargo for Iraq would pass through Aqaba every day. During those days, Jordan built an elaborate road system to truck goods from Aqaba to Iraq, Israeli military analysts said. The analysts said Jordan might seek to sidestep pressures from both Iraq and the West by trying to get away with a partial embargo. ``On the one hand, they fear being portrayed as joining the great powers against Iraq. On the other hand, they don't want to be seen as anti-American,'' said Asher Susser, head of the Dayan Center, a think tank at Tel Aviv University. Susser said if Jordan's King Hussein goes along with a full embargo, it would probably cause domestic upheaval. Jordan has witnessed mass pro-Iraqi demonstrations by Palestinians and Moslem fundamentalists. But another analyst, Dore Gold, said the United States probably would not allow goods to reach Iraq via Aqaba because it would damage the effectiveness of international sanctions. ``If there is any sense that the blockade, or let's use the word quarantine, is porous to a certain extent, then immediately nations with greater mercantile interests will start trading with Iraq,'' said Gold, an analyst at the Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies at Tel Aviv University.

DOC.HEAD: Pan-German Abortion Debate Intensifies As Unity Nears
DOC.TEXT: A searing debate on abortion got hotter Tuesday when a leading lawmaker insisted West German women be barred from taking advantage of East Germany's liberal abortion law after unification. ``Abortion tourism (to East Germany) would be unleashed if there were no threat of punishment,'' said Wolfgang Boetsch, a high-ranking member of a conservative party that is part of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's coalition government. Sentiments on the issue are so divided that last month the two nations postponed deciding on a united Germany's abortion statutes until an all-German parliament can take up the matter. When unity occurs by the end of the year, two abortion laws will exist in one nation _ West Germany's strict statute, and the far more lenient one in what is now East Germany. In West Germany, abortions are allowed only if there is a life-threatening risk to the mother, if the pregnancy resulted from rape or incest, or if birth would create extraordinary social and economic hardship. East German women, on the other hand, have a fundamental legal right to an abortion, as long as it occurs within the first 12 weeks of pregnancy. East Germany, with a population of about 16 million, last year recorded 73,000 abortions. The figure was 75,297 in West Germany, which has a population about four times greater than its eastern neighbor. East Germany has insisted that its abortion law be retained after unification. The debate is not only between two nations, but also between political partners. The liberal Free Democrats, junior coalition partners in Kohl's government, have proposed not to prosecute West German women if they choose to travel to what is now East Germany for abortions after unification. That idea has enraged the conservative Christian Social Union. ``The CSU will not abide by such a step,'' Boetsch said Tuesday. ``Reversing the state's protection for the unborn life is out of the question (for West Germans), under any circumstances.'' Liberal politicians have said that if West Germany retains its abortion laws, a West German woman who had an abortion in an East German clinic could face prosecution on her return home. East German doctors say West German women have already begun crossing the border to benefit from East Germany's abortion laws. But East German doctors are not permitted to perform abortions on foreigners. So far, there have been no reports of East German doctors violating the law. Parliament President Rita Suessmuth, a top Kohl ally, has ruffled a few conservative feathers by lambasting the West German law. ``If men were those people who were primarily affected, they would have made a humane as well as life-protecting law long ago,'' Ms. Suessmuth said earlier this month. Kohl has stayed clear of the fight. But his Christian Democrats have insisted that West Germany's abortion law should serve as the model for that of a united Germany. Ms. Suessmuth has tried to calm the waters by proposing a compromise law for a united Germany. Her idea is to meld the intensive consultations required under West German law with a woman's basic right to an abortion within the first trimester. For many conservatives, however, that sounds too much like the current East German law.

DOC.HEAD: More Aircraft and Marines Arrive in Saudi Arabia
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon said Tuesday that additional Air Force aircraft and Marines had arrived in Saudi Arabia to participate in the military buildup code-named Desert Shield. An announcement said an unspecified number of KC-10 and KC-135 tanker aircraft and RC-135 reconnaissance aircraft, as well as Airborne Warning and Control System radar planes had arrived for the Saudi operation. In line with Pentagon practice during the buildup of forces in the Saudi desert, no details were provided on numbers of aircraft or troops arriving in the gulf, nor their exact locations. The announcement said advance elements of the 1st Marine Expeditionary Force from Camp Pendleton, Calif., and the 7th Marine Expeditionary Brigade, from Twenty-nine Palms., Calif., had arrived in Saudi Arabia. Also, other elements of the 1st Marine Expeditionary Force have begun deploying to the gulf area from California, it said. The Marine group includes elements of the 1st Marine Division and the 1st Force Service Support Group from Camp Pendleton, and the 3rd Marine Aircraft Wing from El Toro, Calif. A Marine expeditionary force usually totals about 50,000 personnel, but the Pentagon has declined to specify the size of the unit deploying to Saudi Arabia. The Pentagon also said elements of the 4th Marine Expeditionary Brigade, headquartered at Norfolk, Va., are deploying to Saudi Arabia. The brigade includes units from the 2nd Marine Division and the 2nd Force Service Support Group of Camp Lejeune, N.C., and the 2nd Marine Aircraft Wing at Cherry Point and New River, N.C., the announcement said.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Students Demand Immediate Unification
LaserPhotos SEL2,3
DOC.TEXT: About 10,000 radical students rallied Tuesday to demand the immediate unification of the divided Korean peninsula and vowed to march to the heavily fortified border to press for free travel to North Korea. The students, gathered at Seoul's Yonsei University, said they would begin the 35-mile march to the border Wednesday, the 45th anniversary of Korea's liberation from 35 years of Japanese colonial rule. A mass unification rally was scheduled to be held with North Korea at the border village of Panmunjom on Wednesday. Before Tuesday's rally, 79 radical students and dissidents were arrested at the sprawling U.S. 8th Army headquarters in central Seoul, five of them for ramming a car through the main gate. The car, carrying dissidents and a student radical shouting ``Drive out Yankees!'' smashed through the military headquarters' main gate and was stopped about 30 yards inside the facility. At the rally at Yonsei, students chanted anti-American and pro-unification slogans. ``Let's drive out the Yankees who block unification of the fatherland!'' they shouted. ``Free travel, total border opening!'' The students are demanding the withdrawal of the 43,000 U.S. troops stationed in South Korea, saying their presence hinders dialogue with communist North Korea on unification. The students also cut rolls of barbed wire to symbolize hopes for an end to the division of the Koreas. Student leaders said thousands of people would march to attend the unification rally at Panmunjom. ``Let's go North,'' chanted the students. Under a South Korean proposal, the heavily armed border was to have opened for unrestricted travel to North Korea for five days beginning on Monday. But both sides failed to agree on procedures. More than 61,000 South Koreans applied to visit the North during the proposed trial border opening. The government's Unification Ministry charged North Korea with blocking the first proposed free travel between citizens of the divided peninsula and urged the North to open its border. The two Koreas have been bitter rivals since the division of the peninsula in 1945. They fought a three-year war in the early 1950s. The border is heavily fortified and there is no mail or other forms of regular communication between the two sides. In North Korea, 1,000 people, including Koreans from overseas and from the South, attended ceremonies Monday as a prelude to the Wednesday unification rally, the official North Korean news agency said.

DOC.HEAD: 96 Dogs Eye Broadway Role
DOC.TEXT: Dogs spoke, sat and stayed, and a few had little accidents, as 96 canines auditioned Tuesday for the role of Asta in the Broadway musical ``Nick and Nora.'' ``Isn't it a riot?'' said Denise Lee of New York, who brought 4-year-old Hector, a wirehair terrier, to the Roseland ballroom in Manhattan. ``He's thinking `Dogs, dogs, dogs!' '' When Ms. Lee, an actress, commanded Hector to ``speak'' onstage, a canine chorus obliged from the audience. The owners all hoped their dogs would play the sidekick to sleuths Nick and Nora Charles in a musical based on the Dashiell Hammett novel ``The Thin Man,'' which also served for several films. The musical is to open in February. There was an occasional beagle or Dalmatian, but most of the would-be stage dogs were terriers, like the dog in the movie. ``Her name is Asta, but nobody believes us,'' said Jesse Eisenberg, 12{, of Ridgewood, N.J., who showed off his 2{-year-old wirehair terrier. ``She has no stage experience, but she's very personable,'' he said. ``She's a little scared today. But she would get over it eventually.'' A pianist played show tunes while the owners presented their dogs onstage. When a dog had the right look, trainer Warren Eckstein commanded it to lie down, sit, heel and stay. Some got the ultimate test: sitting still while being tempted with a favorite toy. Some dogs trembled, but remembered their manners. Others bolted; employees knelt in the wings to catch runaways. ``They get a little energized,'' said Brig Berney, an assistant to the producers, who darted around the ballroom with a roll of paper towels. Sammy, a 3{-year-old cairn terrier, had played Toto in a Westchester County production of ``The Wizard of Oz.'' His audition won applause. ``He asked us to bring him here today. He said the part was made for him,'' said his owner, Karen DiMargo of Carmel, an obedience instructor. ``People want their dog to be a star,'' said co-producer James Pentecost, who lamented: ``I'm a cat person. I'm allergic to dogs.''

DOC.HEAD: ... And Our Flag Was Still There
DOC.TEXT: There was no rocket's red glare, no bombs bursting in air. But our flag was still there Tuesday at a surf shop where officials backed off ticketing the owner for flying Old Glory. It only took hours for Mayor Fred Lager _ perhaps thinking about what happened to Roseanne Barr _ to rescind the ticket, citing a misinterpretation of a local law. Atlantic Beach Surf Shop owner Tom Sena has been flying the flag outside his Long Island store since he opened it five years ago. But on Monday Inspector Frank LeVecchi gave him a $250 ticket for violating a 1976 ordinance barring ``hanging, exhibiting and swinging of banners and flags without the written permission of Atlantic Beach's board of Trustees.'' Lager said the law was meant to keep shop owners from flying several flags, particularly in commercial displays. The mayor said LeVecchi apologized and that the town might consider changing the flag law's language.

DOC.HEAD: Syria Joins `Desert Shield'; Middleman King Heads for U.S.
LaserPhotos planned
DOC.TEXT: Syrian troops planted their flag beside the American in the defense of Saudi Arabia on Tuesday, and Arab harbormasters in the Persian Gulf kept embargoed Iraqi freighters at bay, turning up the heat in the simmering showdown with Baghdad. In Washington, the U.S. and Soviet superpowers conferred on putting a United Nations umbrella over any anti-Iraq naval blockade. The new middleman of the Middle East, Jordan's King Hussein, headed for the United States and a meeting with President Bush, carrying with him a private message from Iraq's Saddam Hussein. As peace efforts and economic pressure stepped up, U.S. military forces continued to pour across a 7,000-mile air bridge into the Arabian desert. It was the seventh day of ``Desert Shield,'' the operation designed to face down an Iraqi army that seized Kuwait and could threaten Saudi Arabia. Out in the sand wastes, paratroopers of the U.S. Army's 82nd Airborne Division found friendly Saudis and some tastes of home, like a delivery of fast-food burgers, according to reports from journalists in a U.S. media pool. But the young Americans also had to deal with 115-degree heat and the potential for chemical warfare with Iraq. Said one GI, ``We're trained and ready.'' North across the desert, hundreds of other Americans remained trapped in Kuwait and Iraq. One Iraqi spokesman, the ambassador to Greece, told reporters in Athens the Americans and thousands of other foreigners stranded when Iraq invaded Kuwait could leave ``as soon as the threats from the United States and its allies are eliminated.'' The Voice of America radio, in a message beamed toward the troubled upper gulf, cautioned the trapped Americans _ an estimated 2,500 in Kuwait and 500 to 600 in Iraq _ not to try to flee across the Kuwait border into Saudi Arabia, ``due to the danger involved.'' Under all the pressure, Iraq sounded unyielding. In Baghdad, the state-run newspaper Al-Jumhuriya said Iraq knows how to ``foil'' U.S. measures. If Iraq is attacked, it said, Iraq can ``move the battlefield to where (the United States) does not want or expect it to be.'' Iraq said it launched its lightning strike against Kuwait Aug. 2 because of disputes over oil and money: It said Kuwait deliberately cut Iraqi oil revenues by overproducing its own oil and driving down prices, and unfairly pressed for repayment of an estimated $15 billion in Kuwaiti loans to Iraq. The Iraqis also cited old claims on Kuwaiti territory. After its conquest, Iraq announced the ``annexation'' of Kuwait. To underline that declaration, the Baghdad government this week began referring to Kuwait city as a ``southern Iraqi city.'' At U.S. urging, the U.N. Security Council on Aug. 6 ordered a worldwide punitive embargo on trade with Iraq. Bush then dispatched U.S. troops and warplanes to Saudi Arabia, saying the massing of Iraqi troops just across the border in Kuwait threatened U.S.-aligned Saudi Arabia, U.S. oil supplies and, ultimately, the U.S. economy. On Aug. 10, twelve of 20 Arab League nations voted to also send their troops to stand beside the Saudis. The latest Arab contingent, from Syria, began arriving in Saudi Arabia in the early morning Tuesday, said diplomatic sources in the Saudi capital of Riyadh. No details were available on the size or kind of unit involved. Most of an estimated 5,000 Egyptian troops promised for the Saudi defense were already there, and Moroccan troops are expected soon. A total of at least 50,000 U.S. troops are expected to be committed to Desert Shield within weeks, including Marines, Army air assault forces, paratroopers and infantry. At times in recent days, U.S. air transports were landing every 10 minutes in Saudi Arabia with American soldiers and supplies. Facing them were an estimated 200,000 Iraqi troops in Kuwait. Out in the warm aquamarine waters of the gulf, meanwhile, there was new evidence Tuesday of the effectivness of the maritime embargo. Authorities in the United Arab Emirates refused permission for an Iraqi freighter, despite repeated appeals from the captain, to enter the port of Dubai. The freighter, Al-Abid, stood anchored uselessly three miles outside the Dubai breakwater, shipping sources said. Another Iraqi freighter, Al-Baya, also waited futilely off Dubai, the sources said. The international embargo could cripple Iraq by cutting off its all-important trade _ exports of oil and imports of food and military supplies. The sanctions are beginning to bite in Baghdad, said a Yugoslav businessman who reached Belgrade on Tuesday. ``We noticed that availability of foodstuffs ... has been reduced, and sugar and flour are ... in short supply,'' he said. The Bush administration has made clear that dozens of U.S. Navy ships assembling in the gulf region would be used to blockade Iraqi maritime traffic if necessary. But U.S. allies and other U.N. members object that the Security Council embargo resolution did not specifically authorize such a naval operation. In an effort to reach an understanding, the State Department on Tuesday summoned the Washington ambassadors of the four other Security Council powers _ the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China _ to discuss the possibility of establishing a joint U.N. military command in the region, or of flying the U.N. flag on the warships in the gulf. The Soviets, who have a handful of warships in the area, have said they will not take part in a naval blockade except under Security Council auspices. At U.N. headquarters in New York, diplomats said the Security Council was unlikely to act until after it hears reports Friday on how the 159 U.N. members are observing the embargo. The boycott against Iraq was far from solid, particularly in neighboring Jordan. Iraq-bound cargo was still being landed at the Jordanian port of Aqaba, off the Red Sea, and eyewitnesses reported truck traffic continued normally across the Iraq-Jordan border. Iraq's major oil outlets, pipelines through Turkey and Saudi Arabia, were effectively shut down. But a smaller line into Jordan remained operating, Jordanian officials said, and Iraqi oil was being loaded into tanker trucks and sped to ships at Aqaba.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Army's Order for Desert-Bound Troops: 5,550 Bottles of Suntan Lotion
DOC.TEXT: The local K mart whipped up a custom-made blue-light special when the Army called with an order for special supplies to equip Fort Stewart soldiers heading to the Middle East. K mart manager Wesley Bennefield said Tuesday he agreed to fill the order at no profit: 5,550 bottles of suntan lotion, 2,400 cans of bug spray, 5,550 bottles of skin lotion, 5,550 tubes of lip balm, 5,550 containers of foot powder and 174,000 gallons of bottled water. Bennefield said the Army called Friday and he was able to deliver most of the items to the post Sunday night. Fort Stewart began sending troops and equipment to Saudi Arabia over the weekend. ``This has been a real treat,'' Bennefield said. ``I've learned one thing about the military: They're hard to deal with. They follow guidelines to the letter.'' Bennefield said he was having trouble filling the water order. The Hinesville K mart doesn't carry bottled water, and he said he was having it shipped from other companies. He had rounded up 84,000 gallons as of Tuesday morning. Fort Stewart's public affairs officer, Maj. Don Keeling, said it isn't unusual for Army units to shop at local businesses for such items. ``We have been going to various vendors to obtain whatever we think is necessary for the protection of the welfare of our soldiers,'' Keeling said. Bennefield said he doesn't know how much the Army's final tab will be, but his store is not making a profit off the deal. ``You might say we're waving the flag. I'm a patriotic guy,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Precede HARBEL
Prince Johnson Laughs Off Rebel Claims He Was Killed in Liberia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with quotes from Johnson at news conference, details, edits to trim and delete dated material. No pickup. ADDS byline
DOC.TEXT: Rebel leader Prince Johnson met with reporters this afternoon and laughed off claims by rival rebels that he had been killed in an ambush. Charles Taylor, Johnson's rival in the yearlong battle to oust President Samuel Doe, claimed this morning his fighters had killed Johnson when he was surprised at a rubber plantation outside the capital Monrovia. A man identifying himself as Johnson earlier had called the British Broadcasting Corp. in London on a radiotelephone to deny he was dead, shouting into the phone, ``Taylor's a liar! I am alive!'' In Washington, the State Department said a ``very reliable source'' saw Johnson alive today. The rebels hours earlier failed to show journalists Johnson's body, as had been promised. Taylor's spokesman and defense minister, Tom Woewiyu, who announced Johnson's death, said in an interview that if anyone talked with Johnson this afternoon, they were ``talking with a corpse.'' Told that the U.S. State Department said Johnson was seen alive today, hours after the reported ambush, Woewiyu said, ``They must have a different Johnson.'' At today's State Department briefing, spokeswoman Margaret Tutweiler said, ``We have a reliable source this morning that told us they have seen him today. ... Alive. ... They said they had a very reliable source that said they had seen him today.'' Earlier, a rebel commander identified as Oliver Varney led the ambush that supposedly cost Johnson his life, said rebel officers at their headquarters on the Firestone Rubber plantation about 37 miles southeast of Monrovia. Woewiyu, spokesman for Taylor's National Patriotic Front, earlier told reporters in Abidjan, in neighboring Ivory Coast, that Johnson had been killed on Bushrod Island while trying to leave Monrovia. ``Johnson was trying to get out of Monrovia when he ran into our forces,'' Woewiyu said in a telephone interview. Woewiyu had said Johnson's body had been taken to NPF rebel headquarters and would be shown to reporters. The two guerrilla leaders split three months ago in their violent war to oust Doe, and since then each has threatened to kill the other. Johnson's men had been holding much of Monrovia for several weeks after launching a surprise attack from a swamp north of the city. They caught Doe's troops by surprise and took control of the city's port area and also several residential districts. The report of Johnson's death came as an African peacekeeping force appeared to be meeting further delays. Troops from Ghana, Nigeria, Guinea, Sierra Leone and Gambia have gathered in neighboring Sierra Leone, but there was no sign of an early departure. Woewiyu said Taylor would be flying to Banjul, Gambia, this week to talk with Gambia President Sir Dawda Jawara, head of the African mediation committee trying to end the nearly eight-month civil war in Liberia. This seemed likely to delay the arrival of the peacekeeping force. Johnson was one of the original rebels who invaded Liberia from Ivory Coast last Dec. 24, according to rebel sources and his friends. Johnson, 31, broke with Taylor several months later, perhaps over the issue of who would lead the movement. Johnson, whose forces have been described by U.S. officials as more disciplined than Taylor's and perhaps stronger, is entirely of African descent. Taylor is of mixed Americo-Liberian, African ancestry. Americo-Liberians are the descendents of American slaves who founded Liberia in 1847. Johnson, who joined the army in 1981 and also received some U.S. military training, was arrested during the unsuccessful 1985 coup led by Brig. Gen. Thomas Quiwonkpa, but escaped and rejoined other exiles in Ivory Coast.

DOC.HEAD: Number of Idled Acres Off 16 Percent from 1989
DOC.TEXT: Farmers agreed to idle 26 million acres under this year's federal crop programs, about 16 percent less than they did under the 1989 programs, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. The 1990 contract figures were released by the department's Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service. The final land-idling figure was up 1.2 million acres from the 24.8 million acres announced in a preliminary report May 18. To be eligible for federal price-support and related benefits, farmers must take a percentage of their crop base acres from production and put the land in conservation uses that help protect the soil. The idled acres signed up for 1990, according to the final report, included: corn, 10.1 million acres, down from 10.8 million acres in 1989; sorghum, 3.1 million, down from 3.3 million; barley, 2.7 million, up from 2.3 million; and oats, 230,000 acres, down from 310,000. Feed grains totaled about 16 million acres, down from 16.7 million last year. Wheat signed up in the 1990 program included 7 million acres of idled land, down from 9.6 million last year; upland cotton, 1.9 million, down from 3.5 million; and rice, 1.1 million, the same as last year. The report said farmers enrolled 168.8 million acres of feed grain, wheat, cotton and rice in the 1990 program, which represented 78 percent of the 216.6 million acres in the national base for those crops. The idled acres are part of the 168.8 million acres that were enrolled. Last year's gross enrollment was 168 million acres, or 76.4 percent of the 1989 base of 220 million acres.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: at Aqaba.
DOC.TEXT: King Hussein, walking a tightrope between his powerful Iraqi neighbor and world opinion, met with Iraq's President Saddam on Monday in Baghdad, and is to meet with Bush Thursday at the U.S. chief executive's vacation home in Maine. The Jordanian monarch, trying to mediate the crisis, ``is carrying Saddam Hussein's views to President Bush,'' a senior Jordanian official said. American leaders are also likely to press the king to close the embargo loophole in Jordan. Aqaba is within reach of U.S. Navy units, which have been keeping an eye on a tanker that sought, unsuccessfully, to take on Iraqi oil at the nearby Saudi port of Yanbu. The U.S. naval commander in the gulf, Rear Adm. William M. Fogarty, told reporters aboard the flagship USS LaSalle that he now has at his command 24 ships, 17,000 men, 200 aircraft and three aircraft carriers in the gulf, the nearby Arabian Sea and the Red Sea. Warplanes from the carrier Independence, just outside the gulf, fly nightly missions over that strategic sea. The Navy operated behind a cloud of diplomatic semantics. Bush said the U.S. warships would stop oil shipments and other Iraqi trade. But Navy commanders said they had no specific orders on how to waylay Iraq shipping, and U.S. officials avoided calling it a blockade _ a term connoting wartime status. A few British and French warships were also in the area, and Australian, Canadian and Dutch ships were on their way, or soon will be. But debate grew in some of those countries over the role their forces would play. Even some members of Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke's own party questioned his decision. On Tuesday, an alert went out in the gulf that Iraq may have planted seaborne mines in an important shipping lane. The warning was later rescinded, but U.S. Navy commanders took no chances. On the bow on the U.S. cruiser Antietam, lookouts with binoculars stood duty, watchful for mines.

DOC.HEAD: Ferrying Troops and Tanks Strains Military Transport Systems
LaserPhoto FAY1
DOC.TEXT: Try moving a medium-sized city 7,000 miles across an ocean within days to a desert where thousands of people need to eat, sleep, bathe and defend themselves against a million-man army. That's what the Pentagon is up against in Operation Desert Shield, its largest military operation and most taxing logistical problem since Vietnam. ``You have two things against you _ geography and time. And as soon as it gets there, you have to resupply right away,'' said Duane Cassidy, a retired four-star general who until last year commanded the United States Transportation Command, the logistical arm of the military. ``This operation is something no one else in the world can do. Nobody else knows how to do it or practices it,'' said Cassidy, now a vice president for CSX Corp., a transportation company in Richmond, Va. The Pentagon refused to give specific numbers on troop shipments and which air carriers are involved. But Cassidy estimated 90 percent of the troops and 50 percent of the cargo arriving in the Saudi Arabian desert are being flown on commercial airliners. The Pentagon has used commercial carriers for over 30 years to ferry troops around the globe. That frees up Air Force planes to carry cargo, such as the C-141, which can hold 200 troops and 34 tons of equipment at the same time, and the C-5, which can hold 340 troops and 130 tons of equipment. Every 10 minutes, a plane lands in Saudi Arabia. Each non-stop flight takes about 15 hours, and National Guard and Air Force Reserve crews are part of the operation. Among the U.S. airlines taking part are Eastern, World Airways, Tower International and Federal Express _ which gives a military slant to the slogan when it absolutely, positively has to be there overnight. An all-out sealift is also underway, although the Navy has only eight fast ships capable of carrying tanks, armored personnel carriers and helicopters on the two-week-long voyage to the Persian Gulf. It would take all eight ships just to transport the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division from Savannah, Ga. The Navy also has about 94 slower ships in a reserve fleet that could be pressed into service. ``The whole United States Transportation Command _ air lift and sea lift _ is heavily taxed right now. It puts a strain on the system. It's not a crisis, but it's certainly busy and hectic,'' said Capt. George Sillia, an Air Force spokesman at the Pentagon. Desert Shield is much different from last year's Panama invasion, which was a much smaller operation. Besides, the United States already had forces on the ground in Panama and had its own bases to land its jets. Desert Shield is also lightning-like compared to the escalation in Vietnam, which by the nature of the conflict occurred much more gradually. There were 300 U.S. military advisers in Vietnam in 1959. Two helicopter companies were deployed at the end of 1961, raising the total of U.S. personnel in Vietnam to 1,500. By the end of 1963, the U.S. commitment had grown to 16,500 troops. But the first combat troops didn't arrive until 1965, when a major buildup boosted troop totals to 181,000. Peak involvement reached 550,000 troops. Most of the equipment was sent by sea. The Air Force, which has the largest fleet of transport planes in the non-communist world, says the Middle East crisis underscores the need to move troops quickly to flashpoints of conflict around the globe. The Air Force wants to replace its 25-year-old C-141s with the new C-17s. One new transport could do the work of two older planes at less cost, Air Force officers said. The policy of moving troops and dependents by commercial charter began in President Eisenhower's administration as a way to cut costs. It lessened the need for the Air Force to invest in transport aircraft. ``It's an efficient way to move, cargo and government equipment,'' said Staff Sgt. Mark Johnson of the Military Airlift Command, the long-range air lift arm of the military based at Scott Air Force Base in Illinois. A 1986 Pentagon study said it would take $2 billion to buy 20 airliners and train crews to fly them. About 95 percent of all Pentagon personnel flying overseas use commercial flights, according to government records.

The Hubble Space Telescope can't look to the edge of the universe until its vision is corrected, but it is beginning to give scientists unprecedented views of celestial objects closer to home. NASA released the first such photograph on Monday, a detailed look into a prolific star-forming area, clearly showing 60 stars in an area once thought to have only a single, massive star. ``The picture has exciting scientific content and demonstrates the Hubble Space Telescope is very much alive,'' said Ed Weiler, the NASA scientist in charge of the project. The picture was made Aug. 3 of a star cluster called 30 Doradus, located in the constellation Dorado, the swordfish _ an area in the southern hemisphere known as a star nursery. The cluster is believed to be 160,000 to 170,000 years old, a baby in a universe 10 billion to 20 billion years old.

A backlash against the homeless has hit progressive Santa Monica, a city so tolerant it serves street people free meals on the City Hall lawn. Grumbling over the city's benevolence toward the homeless erupted into a revolt after a vagrant with a pair of scissors mugged an 89-year-old woman in a grocery store in March. Although the man was convicted and sentenced to 14 years in prison, community activists in this city of 96,500 launched a campaign to oust City Attorney Robert Myers, blaming his policy against prosecuting nonviolent homelessness-related crimes. ``It's an outrage,'' said activist Leslie Dutton. ``These policies have encouraged the criminal element to stay in our community. People are prisoners in their apartments. They're even afraid to go shopping.''

In a medical first, five tablespoons of umbilical cord blood saved after the birth of a baby were given to her 4-year-old brother in hopes it will help him form new bone marrow and beat fast-acting leukemia. Michael Sancilio received the transfusion at Johns Hopkins Oncology Center on Monday. His 3-month-old sister, Christina, is too young to donate bone marrow, the usual treatment for Michael's form of leukemia, and doctors were afraid he wouldn't survive the three-month wait before his sister became old enough. ``We didn't have any other choice,'' said the youngsters' mother, Denise Sancilio. ``We couldn't put our baby through a bone marrow aspiration. It's very dangerous for her. We were in a situation where we had to do it.''

President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has acted to restore the rights of victims of Josef Stalin, under whose rule millions of peasants died of starvation, were shot or sent to labor camps as ``enemies of the people.'' In his toughest condemnation yet of Stalin's forced collectivization of agriculture, which began in the late 1920s, Gorbachev said Monday that thousands of innocent people still bore a ``stain of injustice.'' In a sweeping decree, Gorbachev said the ``repressions conducted ... during the period of collectivization'' were ``unlawful and contradictory to the main civilian and economic rights of human beings.'' He condemned repressions against ``all citizens on political, social, ethnic, religious and other motives in the 1920s through the 1950s,'' and moved ``to completely reinstate the rights of these citizens.''

The Pentagon will be getting fewer high-tech weapons of the sea _ the Seawolf submarine and the Arleigh Burke destroyer _ in line with cuts ordered by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. In an attempt to save $7 billion over the next four fiscal years, Cheney ordered slowdowns in the production rates of the two high-tech vessels on Monday. A slower production rate for the submarine will cut one ship and some advance purchased material from next year's budget, resulting in a savings of $1.8 billion. Plans had called for buying 10 of the submarines every three years. Instead, the Pentagon will reduce the purchase to three ships every two years, according to a statement released at the Pentagon.
