DOC.HEAD: Adv for Weekend Editions, Aug. 18-19

DOC.TEXT: A Wall Street blackout displaced Iraq's Saddam Hussein as the bogeyman of the U.S. financial markets, disrupting trading in stocks, bonds, currencies, and commodities. The fire at a Con Edison power substation Monday forced the American Stock Exchange, New York Mercantile Exchange and other futures markets in southern Manhattan to close by early afternoon. The New York Stock Exchange was unaffected by the outage, but trading volume slowed at the nation's biggest stock market as electricity-starved offices elsewhere in the financial district emptied.

A federal judge defended and then began imposing a nationwide plan intended to compensate quickly thousands of workers with asbestos-related diseases, some of whom have waited years for payment. In a first step toward resolving 20 years of contentious litigation, U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein on Monday ordered hearings to determine whether Eagle-Picher Industries Inc. can settle 65,000 pending claims in a single class action case. Weinstein also endorsed combining the Manville trust with money from other defendant companies into a national fund that would apportion compensation on the basis of need.

Drivers and package handlers at United Parcel Service of America Inc. approved a new three-year contract, even though union leaders had recommended against the pact, the Teamsters union said. UPS account executives started calling or visiting the company's 1.1 million daily pickup customers to tell them the news, said company spokesman Ken Sternad. Delivery drivers will be handing out notices to delivery customers Tuesday. The contract covers about 146,000 workers nationwide.

Increased OPEC oil production could cover the shortfall caused by the embargo of Iraq but the United States should be prepared to tap its own crude reserve if necessary, an industry official said. The American Petroleum Institute estimated Monday that OPEC could boost production by roughly the 4 million barrels a day that Iraq and Kuwait had been exporting before Iraq invaded its neighbor on Aug. 2.

Oil-producing countries are planning a new meeting to discuss how they should handle oil shortages that have resulted since Iraq invaded Kuwait, the Saudi ambassador said. Prince Bandar Bin Sultan said Monday that members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are holding ``consultations'' in preparation for the meeting.

Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp. closed coke ovens and blast furnaces as the ailing steel maker braced for a strike Thursday by 5,500 union workers in Ohio, West Virginia and Pennsylvania. The Wheeling, W.Va.-based company said Monday it cut production after the United Steelworkers rejected a contract that included a $3,000 signing bonus and a raise of $2 an hour in each of the next four years. Workers at 13 USW locals last month authorized a strike beginning just after midnight Wednesday.

Federal Aviation Administrator James Busey announced a freeze on some hiring and said contingency plans are being made for sharp cuts if Congress fails to pass a fiscal 1991 budget. Following White House instructions for all departments to plan for cuts, Busey told 50,600 FAA employees Monday they might face mandatory furloughs without pay for 2{ days each two-week pay period and that national air traffic would have to be reduced.

Longtime U.S. employees of Chase Manhattan Corp. are being offered severance payments to leave their jobs early as the nation's second-biggest banking company begins efforts to trim costs by $300 million. The company made the offer last week to employees with at least 10 years service, a company spokesman said Monday. He was unable to say how many of the company's 30,000 domestic employees are eligible for the program, but estimated it is a few thousand.

USAir Group Inc. said it would lay off about 200 pilots in a cutback that could also affect flight attendants and other employees, a spokeswoman for the airline said. ``We will not fly as much new service as originally planned, in view of the state of the economy,'' spokeswoman Susan Young said in explaining the layoffs Monday. She said she could not elaborate on the number of workers involved or when they might be let go. Earlier Monday, the Air Line Pilots Association announced to members that the Arlington, Va.-based carrier had decided to lay off 211 pilots around the end of the year.

An afternoon rally sent stock prices higher Monday after a steep opening slump, but trading was reduced by a power outage that curtailed operations at the American Stock Exchange and several brokerages. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 30.20 to 2,746.78. Gold prices climbed to five-month highs. The dollar slumped against forewign currencies. Long-term government bond prices fell. Grain and soybean futures fell sharply and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Defends, Starts Imposing National Class Action Plan
DOC.TEXT: After 20 years of contentious litigation over sickness and death caused by asbestos, a federal judge has taken the first step toward a comprehensive solution to the nation's biggest product liability issue. But several attorneys are questioning the viability of a single plan to resolve tens of thousands of disparate lawsuits seeking compensation for lung cancer and other respiratory ailiments caused by asbestos. ``This litigation is too diffuse to expect that all parties and all state courts will consent to a mandatory class action,'' said Andrew Berry, a Newark, N.J., attorney representing several defendants. In the first move toward a class action lawsuit, U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein on Monday ordered hearings to determine whether Eagle-Picher Industries Inc. can settle 65,000 pending claims in a single case. Weinstein also endorsed combining the Manville trust _ the nation's largest asbestos claims resolution system _ with money from other defendant companies into a national fund that would apportion compensation on the basis of need. The action followed an unusual joint order Friday by 10 federal judges from around the country who were frustrated by clogged court dockets, mounting claims and resolution so slow that many asbestos victims die before they are paid. ``We have got to pay these people who are entitled to be paid and we have to reduce the costs,'' Weinstein told a crowded hearing in U.S. District Court in Brooklyn. Weinstein and the nine other federal judges approved a three-tiered plan for resolving about 90,000 lawsuits pending in state and federal courts nationwide. Thousands of new lawsuits are filed monthly and legal experts estimate hundreds of thousands more cases will be made. Judges have complained that legal costs are siphoning away two-thirds of the money earmarked for victims. Under the plan, Weinstein would handle a class action involving Eagle-Picher and up to five more companies that don't have the money to fight cases in court or pay present and future claims. Before the case can proceed, the court must determine the defendants lack resources. Weinstein's case is expected to include the Manville trust, which was formed in 1988, six years after Manville Corp. was forced into bankruptcy court protection under the weight of asbestos claims. In part two of the plan, Thomas D. Lambros, chief judge of federal district for northern Ohio, would attempt to fashion a single out-of-court settlement of asbestos claims. Finally, U.S. District Judge Robert Parker, chief judge of the eastern federal district of Texas, would supervise a class-action trial for defendants unwilling or unable to reach settlements. The movement to reform asbestos litigation gained momentum earlier this year when the Manville trust announced it had run out of money for new claimants and said others wouldn't get money until well into the 21st century. Most claimants inhaled asbestos, which was used widely for insulation, while working in shipyards and factories as long ago as the 1930s. Judges complain that the same issues are argued over and over, leading to millions in expenses that might otherwise be used to pay victims. Frivolous claims, high fees charged by plaintiffs lawyers and a refusal by some defendants to settle also have been criticized. But some attorneys oppose the judges' plan, saying the issue is too complex for a single national solution. They predicted a breakdown in current settlement talks and time-consuming court appeals that would further delay compensation payments ``If we don't have something available to the victims for the next three, four, five years it takes to establish a national class action, that would be a disaster to the victim,'' Gene Locks, a Philadelphia plaintiffs lawyer, told Weinstein. In the Eagle-Picher case, Weinstein appointed former federal judge Marvin E. Frankel to hold hearings on whether the company lacks resources so it can qualify for a class action all plaintiffs would be required to join. Weinstein, who devised a national settlement for Vietnam War-related injuries from the defoliant Agent Orange, said hearings would open Wednesday and promised they would conclude within three weeks. ``I do not intend that in this court (victims) wait eight years before they get (compensation),'' he said. ``This will not be a Manville reorganization.'' Eagle-Picher, based in Cincinnati, said in court papers it spent $119.7 million on litigation last year and is being named in 2,000 new lawsuits a month.

DOC.HEAD: Teamsters Ratify Contract With UPS
With Graphic
DOC.TEXT: United Parcel Service of America, Inc., wasted no time letting customers know it was business as usual after the Teamsters union announced its truck drivers and package handlers had ratified a new, three-year contract. UPS account executives started calling or visiting the company's 1.1 million daily pickup customers Monday to tell them the news, said UPS spokesman Ken Sternad. Delivery drivers will start handing out notices to delivery customers today. A strike threat that had surfaced during the negotiations forced UPS customers and competitors to come up with alternate delivery plans, and Sternad said it was too early to determine what effect that would have on business. ``We're going to offer the same service we always have, and hopefully that will be enough to convince anybody that may have held off during this period that they'll stay with us,'' he said. Some customers had begun shifting their business to the U.S. Postal Service or Roadway Package System, Inc., of Pittsburgh, UPS's two main ground-delivery competitors. Union members voted 65,463 to 53,091 in favor of the contract, or 55 percent to 45 percent, Teamsters President William J. McCarthy said Monday in a statement from union headquarters in Washington. About 146,000 UPS workers nationwide are covered by the contract, which is retroactive to Aug. 1. The contract includes a one-time $1,000 bonus to full-time workers, hourly wage increases totalling $1.50 an hour over three years and increased company contributions to health benefits. McCarthy did not say what provisions the union leadership found inadequate. Repeated telephone calls to his office were not returned. In his statement, McCarthy charged that Greenwich-based UPS ``went to unprecedented lengths'' to win ratification. ``In the final outcome, I believe that many of the company's employees were frightened by management's ability to use permanent replacement workers, or scabs, in the possible event of a strike,'' McCarthy said. UPS said last week that it did not plan to hire replacement workers. Company spokesman Ken Sternad said he wouldn't comment on McCarthy's assertions. ``The bottom line is we made what we felt was a good offer and it was accepted,'' Sternad said. ``All the other words are unnecessary.'' Teamsters officials began counting ballots Friday, and UPS officials spent the weekend awaiting results. The union had asked for a 10-day extension to gather the ballots just before the old contract expired July 31. The Teamsters had agreed Friday to go back to the bargaining table if the contract was rejected, despite a threat of a nationwide strike early in the negotiations, Sternad said. UPS, the world's largest package handler, delivers more than 10 million packages a day, and made 2.8 billion deliveries in 1989 for $12.4 billion in revenue. It's total work force is 230,000. The contract will increase the hourly wage for the highest paid workers from $16.10 an hour to $17.60 an hour by August 1992. The contract also calls for a cost-of-living allowance of up to 20 cents an hour, per year, depending on inflation, Sternad said. Part-time workers, who start at $8 or $9 an hour, will also receive an additional $1.50 hour over three years, Sternad said. Company contributions for health benefits and employees' pensions will increase from an average of $8,300 a year for full-time workers to an average of $10,500 during the life of the contract, Sternad said. The proposal also includes the bonus, to be paid within the first month of ratification, of $1,000 to full-timers and $500 to part-timers, he said. Improvements to working conditions in the contract include replacement of worn-out truck seats with more comfortable air-suspension seats and easier-to-handle dollies. The contract affects only U.S. workers. UPS has 12,000 to 13,000 employees outside the United States, Sternad said. There has never been a national strike against UPS, which has had a national Teamsters contract since 1979, but sporadic work stoppages and strikes have occurred regionally. The latest and biggest was in 1976, when 18,000 workers in 15 Northeast states walked out for 13 weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Rise, Industry Group Says Petroleum Reserves May Be Needed
DOC.TEXT: The United States should be prepared to draw on its emergency oil reserves even if oil-producing countries increase their output during the Persian Gulf crisis, an industry official said. The president of the American Petroleum Institute, Charles J. DiBona, said Monday there is no immediate pressure to release the stockpile, ``but that could change and we should be prepared to do that.'' The White House said late last week it had no plans to open the reserve, which is in caverns in Louisiana and Texas. But DiBona said the turmoil in the world oil markets ``is clearly the kind of circumstance for which the oil reserve was designed.'' Meanwhile, the Saudi ambassador to the United States, Prince Bandar Bin Sultan, said members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are planning a meeting to consider their response to oil shortages since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. ``Saudi Arabia, a key gulf producer, has indicated a willingness to help,'' DiBona said. ``So has Venezuela. And to the extent they do, they will largely make up the 4 million barrel per day shortfall. However, no one can know at this point what the net effect on world oil supplies will be.'' The price for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude, rose to $26.77 per 42-gallon barrel Monday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Trading was halted early because of a power failure in lower Manhattan. Earlier, Bandar said the Saudis would like ``to have a stable and predictable market for oil.'' At the most recent OPEC meeting, which concluded in Geneva, Switzerland, July 27, the 13 OPEC ministers raised the target price $3 to $21 a barrel. They also agreed not to puncture the production ceiling of 22.5 million barrels a day until the end of the year. Earlier this year, the price declined to the low $16 range partly because crude output by OPEC and other producers was outpacing world demand. Prices began rising earlier this summer after the cartel reached an agreement to restrain production. They shot sharply higher after the invasion of Kuwait on speculation that Iraq might attack other vital oil producers in the region, such as Saudi Arabia. The emergency stockpile of oil, called the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, was established after the oil crises of the 1970s. It contains some 590 million barrels of crude that could be distributed at a rate of up to 3.5 million barrels per day, according to the Energy Department. Robert C. Porter, a spokesman in Washington for the Strategic Petroleum Reserve Program said it would take about two weeks for an oil sale to be made once a presidential order came in. ``Right now, we are on a higher alert level,'' Porter said. ``The reserve is always on a stage of readiness, but when you get a situation like this, you make sure you are ready, and we are.'' A trader with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures, Peter Beutel, said the OPEC nations could make up for the shortfall without too much difficulty, so he did not believe it was time to get into the strategic reserve. DiBona also said the government could lessen the impact of Mideast supply disruptions by opening up production at more offshore oil fields. He called on the government to open the Point Arguello oilfield off the California coast, which he said is sitting idle because state officials have not given oil companies permission to deliver their oil. The field could immediately produce 90,000 barrels per day, but it has been kept on hold because of environmental concerns, DiBona said. More crude also could be produced in Alaska if environmental restrictions were lifted, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Slows Seawolf, Destroyer Purchases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon will be getting fewer high-tech weapons of the sea _ the Seawolf submarine and the Arleigh Burke destroyer _ in line with cuts ordered by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. In an attempt to save $7 billion over the next four fiscal years, Cheney ordered slowdowns in the production rates of the two high-tech vessels on Monday. A slower production rate for the submarine will cut one ship and some advance purchased material from next year's budget, resulting in a savings of $1.8 billion. Plans had called for buying 10 of the submarines every three years. Instead, the Pentagon will reduce the purchase to three ships every two years, according to a statement released at the Pentagon. Cheney ordered that only four destroyers be purchased every year instead of five or six. That means the Pentagon will buy 16 ships from fiscal 1991 through fiscal 1994, instead of the 25 originally planned, for a savings of $5 billion. Overall, the changes in the two programs are designed to save $2.2 billion in the budget that is now before Congress and $7 billion in the Pentagon's spending plan for the fiscal years 1991 through 1994, the Pentagon's statement said. The reductions can be made because of the lessened Soviet threat, but the crisis in the Persian Gulf reveals the need for an up-to-date Navy, the secretary said in a statement. ``There is little doubt that the recent events in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe have altered the social and political makeup of the world, and our ongoing planning assessments are based on the increased prospects for reduced world tensions,'' Cheney said. ``However, current events remind us of how fragile world peace can be. Therefore, we continue to require a superior naval force to maintain free and open use of the seas.'' The review was one of several Cheney has ordered for most of the Pentagon's major weapons programs, given the nation's budget woes. Following a similar review of aircraft in April, the secretary slashed his request for B-2 stealth bombers from 132 to 75. The statement said the Pentagon's original plan for the Seawolf called for maintaining a force of 100 attack submarines, but that ``the size of the Navy's overall submarine force is still being considered.'' The submarines _ designed by the Newport News Shipbuilding Co. of Virginia and Electric Boat Division of General Dynamics in Connecticut _ are slated to take the place of the service's Los Angeles-class attack boats. The nuclear-powered sub had been devised to counter what the Pentagon saw as the rapidly improving capabilities of the Soviet Navy. The Burke-class destroyer is designed to operate in carrier battle groups. It carries the Aegis radar and weapons systems, which allow it to track and guide weapons to destroy multiple targets at any one time. Cheney said purchasing fewer of the vessels will allow the destroyer's fighting capabilities to be upgraded through improving its electronics and anti-submarine weaponry. The changes will mean one less destroyer in fiscal 1991, resulting in a net savings of $407 million, the statement said. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., has been highly critical in recent months of the destroyer, which is built by Bath Iron Works of Bath, Maine. Dingell, the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on oversight and investigations, has questioned the survivability of the ship and the Aegis system against missile attack. Dingell has alleged that the Navy's contract with Bath is a ``procurement nightmare'' of fraud and abuse. The destroyer is called the Arleigh Burke class after the World War II naval hero and former chief of naval operations.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Rise in Japan, Dollar Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Strong performance on overseas markets overnight lifted share prices sharply on the Tokyo Stock Exchange today while the dollar slipped against the yen. The Nikkei index of 225 selected issues won back 496.10 points, or 1.90 percent, to close at 26,672.53. The benchmark index suffered a loss of 1,153.12 points, or 4.22 percent, Monday after Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu announced the cancellation of his planned trip to the Middle East because of the worsening Persian Gulf crisis. Traders attributed the rebound to gains in overseas markets, especially New York. Bargain-hunting following Monday's plunge also encouraged investors' buying. Despite the sharp upsurge today, traders remain cautious about the market's direction. In currency dealings, the dollar traded in a narrow range before closing at 149.90 yen, down 0.75 yen from Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Weighing Travel in Light of Middle East Conflict, U.S. Economy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: G.L. McLeland figures he drove about a million miles during his 33-year career as a traveling salesman, but he's staying put this summer. ``I'm pulling in my oars for a little while,'' the retired Oklahoma City man said. ``I had some trips planned, but now I'm just going to sit and wait a month or two. See how things come out.'' Rising gas prices, falling stocks and the Middle East standoff have led many would-be travelers to reconsider their vacation plans, industry experts said Monday. ``Consumers are taking a wait-and-see attitude,'' said Diane Polomski, a spokeswoman for American Express Travel Related Services Inc. in New York. ``People still want to travel ... but they are being more cautious now.'' Travelers with reservations in Middle Eastern countries are anxious about whether Iraq's Saddam Hussein will withdraw from Kuwait or make a grab for more territory. And domestic tourists, afraid that the nation's economy might be heading into a tailspin, are reluctantly considering whether their leisure trips should take a back seat to necessities. ``No one's sure if this is a recession,'' said Suzanne Cook, executive director of the U.S. Travel Data Center in Washington. ``(But) if consumers feel squeezed in terms of their financial situation, they have to make some decisions.'' At least in some U.S. regions, travel has been coming up short. Officials warned that the final results weren't in, but by the end of June tourism was off at many popular destinations such as the Grand Canyon, California's San Diego Zoo, Washington's monuments and Cape Cod. ``If people are worried about their jobs or increasing costs, they have to put that into their thinking when making travel plans,'' said Deborah First, acting director of the Massachusetts Office of Travel and Tourism. They also have to think about safety. That's why ticket agents and tourism officials representing Greece, Israel and Turkey have been receiving scores of calls from anxious travelers. ``They want to be reassured, but I don't know of any massive or large-scale cancellations,'' said Harvey Cohen, deputy director of the Israel Government Tour Office in New York. Similarly, Kamil Muren of Tusem Tours International said he had received calls from clients leery of making trips to Turkey. But, he said, reassurances have been enough to avert cancellations in all but a few cases. Americans are loath to forgo their annual vacations. It's perhaps for that reason that business has remained constant or improved in some cases despite the softening economy and rising travel costs. ``People are accustomed to traveling and they like it,'' said Jerry Cheskie spokesman for the American Automobile Association in Heathrow, Fla. ``They're more apt to postpone the purchase of big-ticket items like TVs or refrigerators than travel plans.'' People will cut their trips short, stay closer to home and forgo luxury accommodations. But even fears of recession aren't likely to keep them from hitting the open road this summer, tourism officials said. Robert and Florice Cohagen plan to drive from their home in Columbus, Ohio, to Houston to visit relatives. ``We'd rather not spend the extra money, but it isn't going to stop us,'' said Cohagen, 72.``It might only be worse next year.'' That's the kind of attitude recommended by Richard Rippe, chief economist at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in New York. ``We will face for a time somewhat higher inflation as the oil prices are reflected in wholesale and consumer goods,'' he said. ``(But) a massive shift to saving rather than spending ... would only push the economy into a recession.''

DOC.HEAD: Apple Consumption Reaches Record High Despite Alar Scare
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: People ate more apples last year than ever before despite bad publicity about chemicals used by growers and a slight decline in overall consumption of fresh fruit, Agriculture Department figures show. The department's Economic Research Service said that a large crop and low prices combined to push per capita consumption of one of America's favorite fruits to 21.6 pounds in 1989, up from 19.87 pounds the previous year. Twenty years earlier, the figures showed, per capita apple consumption was just over 17 pounds. The low mark in the 20-year records was 15.53 pounds in 1972. Apple growers feared the worst in March 1989, when the Natural Resources Defense Council said that apples treated with Alar increased the risk of cancer in children. Several school districts banned apples. Apple growers responded with a media campaign. ``Bananas and apples continued to be the two most popular fresh fruits in the United States,'' the Agriculture Department said. ``Banana consumption rose with heavier imports, while fresh apple consumption reached a record 21.6 pounds due to the large crop and lower retail prices.'' Overall, fresh fruit consumption dropped 2 percent last year to an average of 96.6 pounds per person. That included citrus and non-citrus. ``Tighter domestic supplies of fresh market oranges caused an 18 percent drop in per capita fresh orange consumption from 1988's 15.4 pounds,'' the report said. ``Similarly, U.S. consumption of fresh lemons, tangelos and tangerines declined to tighter supplies,'' it added. ``Lower consumption of these commodities, combined with fresh orange consumption, offset an increase in per capita consumption of fresh grapefruit and limes.'' For fresh citrus as a group, per capita use was a four-year low of 24.4 pounds, down from more than 27.1 pounds in 1988. The per capita consumption of fresh non-citrus fruit rose to 72.1 pounds in 1989, up only 1 percent from 1988. Bananas, at 24.56 pounds per capita, edged apples in per capita use, but apples showed a much sharper year-to-year gain. ``Increased use of fresh apples, bananas, cherries, kiwifruit, mangoes, pears, pineapples and strawberries offset reduced consumption of fresh grapes, nectarines, papayas, cranberries, avocados, apricots, plums and prunes,'' the report said. Although not in the big league of some of the more popular fruits, a few other records were set last year for per capita consumption. Limes, for example, averaged 0.8 pound per capita, up from 0.68 in 1988, a record level, the report showed. Also, pineapples, at 1.95 pounds, and strawberries, 3.32 pounds, showed record per capita consumption in 1989.

The number of workers employed by farmers showed a seasonal increase in July but was down about 8 percent from a year ago, according to a new survey by the Agriculture Department. A quarterly report said Monday the hired work force on farms was estimated at 1,106,000 workers during the week of July 8-14, up from 833,000 in April. But that was down from 1,197,000 in the work force in July 1989. Those did not include 356,000 ``agricultural service'' workers provided by crew chiefs and labor contractors. In April, those totaled 203,000 workers, and in July 1989 they were estimated at 351,000. Weather was a factor. Showers and thunderstorms were widespread during the July 8-14 survey week over much of the eastern half of the nation, the report said. Heavy rains and flooding were common in some areas. ``Winter wheat harvest was 77 percent complete, two percentage points behind the five-year average,'' the report said. ``Harvest was complete in Kansas and Oklahoma, and nearly complete in Texas.'' The report also noted that during the July survey the peach harvest continued ahead of normal in the Mississippi Delta and the Southeast, while the tobacco harvest progressed in Georgia and North Carolina. ``Melon harvest was active in the California San Joaquin Valley,'' the report said. ``In Oregon, broccoli, lettuce and snap bean harvests were under way in the Willamette Valley. Raspberry, blueberry, cherry, peach and vegetable harvests were active in Washington.'' Average pay for all workers hired directly by farmers was $5.30 per hour, up from $5.23 per hour a year earlier but below the average of $5.54 in April, the report said. For workers hired by contractors, there was no national wage rate available. However, workers in California were reported at $5.82 per hour, compared with $6.59 in April and $5.80 a year earlier in July 1989. Florida workers averaged $6.11 per hour, compared with $5.93 in April and $5.55 a year earlier.

The Agriculture Department has issued another report about Africanized bees to assure people that the ``killer bees'' of Hollywood lore have a sting no worse than ordinary honeybees. A USDA scientist said that ``contrary to some people's expectations'' the Africanized bee has less venom than the ordinary U.S. honeybee. And the venom itself is no more potent. But Justin O. Schmidt of the department's Agricultural Research Service said the Africanized bees rally quickly and use more stings to repel an intruder. ``People should steer clear of their nests,'' he said. ``These bees are extremely defensive when their nests are threatened.'' Department officials have been warning that the Africanized honeybees, which started migrating northward from Brazil years ago, are expected to enter the United States from Mexico at any time. Schmidt works at the agency's bee research center in Tucson, Ariz. He said the chance of someone being severely injured by Africanized honeybees is far less than the chance of being hit by lightning.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian Fuel Prices Rise 9 Percent ^Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The government has decreed a 9 percent increase in fuel prices following a cutoff in oil purchases from Iraq, Brazil's main foreign supplier, Brazil's leading TV network reported. Officials and observers have said in recent days that the rising price of oil on international markets caused by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait had made a domestic increase inevitable. The pump price of gasoline rose from $2.13 a gallon to $2.32, TV Globo said. The network said the price of pure alcohol fuel rose from $1.60 a gallon to $1.74, it said.. Alcohol fuel is subsidized by the government so it is cheaper for consumers than gasoline, though production costs are actually twice as high. About 4.5 million Brazilian vehicles, roughly one-third of the country's total, run on alcohol made from domestically grown sugar cane. The retail price of diesel fuel, kerosene, and cooking gas also went up, Globo reported. Iraq was Brazil's top oil supplier before this South American giant adhered to U.N.-imposed sanctions, including a ban on petroleum imports from Iraq. In 1989, Brazil bought $1.46 billion in crude oil from Iraq, about 30 percent of total daily imports. This country produces 665,000 barrels of oil daily, about 60 percent of domestic needs. Monday's increase was the second this month. Fuel prices were sharply raised and then frozen March 15, when President Fernando Collor de Mello decreed an economic austerity plan. Inflation has dropped sharply since March, when prices soared 84 percent, but is still rising at a rate of about 10 percent a month. Economists say continued inflation combined with minimal price increases for fuel had resulted in gasoline and alcohol being underpriced by about 30 percent and 15 percent, respectively.

DOC.HEAD: USAir Says It Will Lay Off 200 Pilots
DOC.TEXT: A drop in business will force USAir Group Inc. to furlough about 200 pilots by the end of the year and consider laying off other employees, an airline spokeswoman said. Susan Young on Monday confirmed reports from the Air Line Pilots Association that the Virginia-based carrier was planning the cutbacks. ``I think it's safe to say that the airline's traffic and the industry's traffic is flat,'' she said. ``We will not fly as much new service as originally planned in view of the state of the economy.'' The pilots union told its members in a tape-recorded telephone message that it learned of USAir's plans last week in Los Angeles during a meeting with airline president Seth Schofield and other airline executives. The message said Schofield told the pilots' Master Executive Council that USAir foresees a further decline in traffic and higher fuel prices. The vice chairman of ALPA's Master Executive Council, Chris Beebe, urged the pilots to adhere exactly to the wording in their contract and not to fly overtime. Ms. Young, at the company's offices in Arlington, Va., acknowledged that business is slow. USAir Group lost $113.1 million in the first half of this year and has not posted a profit since the second quarter of 1989. However, Ms. Young said the airline may have too many pilots for its fleet. The excess could have resulted from ``older aircraft and rescheduling of aircraft deliveries,'' she said. Twelve new jets had been scheduled for arrival this year, but USAir delayed taking delivery in an unusual cost-cutting move. It also has tried to save money by paying less overtime to maintenance crews. Ms. Young said flight attendants and other unidentified employee groups also may be subject to furloughs. She said she could not elaborate on the number of workers involved or when they might be laid off. USAir employs about 6,300 pilots, all of whom are members of the ALPA, Ms. Young said. The carrier has 55,000 hourly and salaried employees, about 12,000 of whom work in the Pittsburgh region.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
DOC.TEXT: Domestic steel production totaled 1,901 net tons during the week ending Aug. 11, up 2.3 percent from the previous week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The week's production represented 85.2 percent of the industry's domestic capacity, the steel industry group said Monday. American steel makers produced 1,818 net tons in the same week last year. Domestic steel production so far this year is 60,363 net tons, 2.9 percent below last year's production at this time, AISI said. Production by district for last week, (previous week in parentheses). North East Coast 231,000 tons (202,000 tons); Pittsburgh-Youngstown 305,000 tons (322,000 tons); Lake Erie 148,000 tons (144,000 tons); Detroit 161,000 tons (151,000 tons); Indiana-Chicago 498,000 tons (503,000 tons); Southern 266,000 tons (253,000 tons); Western 99,000 tons (98,000 tons).

DOC.HEAD: Sales Edge Up For Second Straight Monthly Gain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Retail sales edged up a weak 0.1 percent in July, their second straight monthly gain after three consecutive declines, the government reported today. The Commerce Department said sales rose a seasonally adjusted $149.5 billion last month, up from $149.4 billion in June. The department also revised upward, to 1.1 percent, the June advance that originally was reported to have been just 0.5 percent. It was the first gain since last January and followed declines of 0.1 percent in May, 1.0 percent in April and 0.4 percent in March. Sales were unchanged in February. But the small July increase was certain to renew questions about whether the consumer would continue to help fuel the economy, now approaching the end of its eighth year of expansion. Retail sales represent about half of consumer spending, which has been a driving force for the economy since the end of the 1981-82 recession. Overall, consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. There have been signs recently of consumer caution amid recent reports of a weakening economy. To avoid a recession, the Bush administration and many economists have urged the Federal Reserve to stimulate the economy by lowering interest rates. The Fed has held rates high to curb inflation by slowing the economy. Sales of durable goods _ items expected to last more than three years _ rose 0.3 percent. These big-ticket goods have been particularly affected by the Fed's policies since they often are financed through loans. Automobile sales were down 0.6 percent, offsetting a 0.6 percent advance in June. Weakness in auto sales has been a major factor contributing to the overall sluggishness of consumer spending this year. Excluding autos, retail sales were up 0.3 percent. On the other hand, sales of building materials remained strong, rising 3.9 percent on top of a 3.2 percent increase the previous month. Home furnishing sales also rose, up 2.5 percent after a 1.4 percent decline in June. Non-durable goods were unchanged following a 1.5 percent gain in June. Department store sales posted a 0.8 percent advance after an even stronger 3.5 percent increase the previous month. Grocery store sales were up 0.4 percent after a 0.7 percent advance in June. Drug store sales climbed 0.6 percent after a 1.6 percent gain. But sales fell in three non-durable sectors. Gasoline station purchases were off 0.3 percent after a 1.0 percent jump; clothing sales were down 0.9 percent after a 2.1 percent increase, and sales at restaurants and bars fell 0.4 percent after a 0.8 percent advance.

DOC.HEAD: American Reportedly Interested in Bidding on Midway Airlines
DOC.TEXT: Speculation that American Airlines may be interested in acquiring Midway Airlines has push Chicago-based Midway's stock up almost 40 percent. Midway's stock jumped $2.125 a share to close at $9.625 a share in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange Monday. Shares of AMR Corp., American Airlines' parent, closed at $51.25 each on the Big board, up 25 cents. Market watchers said there is speculation that Fort Worth-based AMR is considering making a bid for the cash-strapped Midway. Quoting unnamed sources, the Fort Worth Star-Telegram reported today that AMR recently hired Goldman Sachs & Co. to advise it on the possible acquisition of all or parts of Midway. Midway spokeswoman Sandra Allen said AMR has not approached Midway, the nation's 13th largest carrier. American spokesman John Hotard said the company does not comment on rumors. Midway's most valuable assets appear to be its 23 gates at Midway Airport, in the shadow of the world's busiest airport, Chicago's O'Hare International Airport. O'Hare, which is the site of American's second-largest hub, is overcrowded. Midway also has orders and options on 62 McDonnell Douglas MD-80s for relatively quick delivery. American, the nation's largest carrier, already operates the world's largest fleet of MD-80s but likely could take on more scheduled for delivery in the next two to three years. Midway has been reeling from the combination of its $250 million acquisition last year of gates from Eastern Airlines, higher fuel prices, continued low-fare competition in the Midwest-to-Florida routes and the general weakness in domestic travel, analysts said. Last year Midway lost $20.7 million on record revenues of $493.5 million. In the first quarter of 1990, it lost another $22.9 million.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler in Talks with Three Foreign Makers
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca confirmed today that the struggling automaker had talked with three major European companies but added he didn't expect the discussions to result in a full merger. Speculation in Europe and the United States suggested that Italy's Fiat Group would buy a stake in Chrysler, the No. 3 U.S. automaker. While Iacocca said no such equity arrangement is imminent, he added that it is possible in the next decade. ``No, I wouldn't want to predict that today. Maybe in the year 2000,'' Iacocca said. ``Given the way things have evolved in the last 20 years, you might see some giant mergers, but I doubt that. I doubt any full merger talk.'' Iacocca said Chrysler had talked with Renault of France, Volvo of Sweden and Fiat, but he refused to give specifics. ``Everybody's talking to everybody,'' he said. ``I think over time everybody's going to need some kind of affiliation or a partnership.'' The chairman answered questions as production of the redesigned 1991 minivans began at Chrysler's assembly plant here, across the river from Detroit. Minivans account for a large portion of Chrysler's profits. The company earned $71 million in the second quarter this year but is expected to show a loss in the third quarter, largely because minivan plants in Windsor and St. Louis, Mo., shut down for a month to retool for new models. Chrysler has struggled this year with lagging sales and the loss of four top executives, which prompted Icacocca to delay his own retirement plans. During national contract talks, Chrysler negotiators have floated the ideas of partial employee ownership, as well as establishing a multi-company health care plan.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mostly Lower, Turn Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices opened mostly lower then turned mixed today on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting forecasts for a continuation of beneficial crop weather in the Midwest. Losses were limited, though, by buying linked to Monday's weekly Agriculture Department crop-progress report, which showed the corn and soybean crops still lagging well behind the normal pace. The report showed pods setting in 50 percent of the soybean crop as of Sunday, compared with the average of 69 percent for that date. Corn kernels were forming in 29 percent of the corn crop compared with a 58 percent norm, according to the USDA. Both crops remained in mostly good to excellent condition, but traders increasingly are concerned about the possibility of frost damage to late-maturing crops, analysts said. William Biedermann, research director with the commodities brokerage Allendale Inc. in Crystal Lake, Ill., predicted the two-sided trading probably would limit the crop markets to only slight movement today. In early trading, wheat futures were { cent lower to } cent higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.75\ a bushel; corn was } cent to 1\ cents lower with September at $2.44\ a bushel; oats were \ cent to } cent lower with September at $1.15{ a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents lower to 3\ cents higher with August at $6.01{ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .02 cent to .12 cent higher with August at 79.30 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .15 cent higher with August at 90.05 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .32 cent lower with August at 58 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .15 cent lower to .10 cent higher with August at 49 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures ended mixed on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Perez: Oil Production Levels Focus of OPEC Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Oil-producing countries could establish new pricing and production levels by the end of the week if agreements are reached at an emergency OPEC meeting, President Carlos Andres Perez said Tuesday. OPEC members Saudi Arabia and Venezuela plan to propose that production be increased if necessary to avoid a world oil shortage, Perez said at a press conference. Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are planning an emergency session, but the date and location have yet to be announced. President Bush, in a phone conversation with Perez on Monday, repeated a plea for Venezuela to increase production by 500,000 barrels daily. But Venezuela, while eager to provide the extra oil, has been holding out for an OPEC accord on how to replace the 4 million barrels of oil production blocked by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Venezuela normally sells about half its daily two-million barrel production to the United States, representing about 11 percent of America's oil supply. Many assume that Venezuela would also sell most of its additional oil to the United States, but Perez has denied making a specific agreement to do so. ``Our principal consumer is the United States. We have an obligation to them. But we can't be the only ones to give,'' Perez said. He said regular production of an extra 500,000 barrels could damage machinery. Venezuela is seeking American investment to expand its oil industry with an aim of producing 3.5 million barrels daily. Analysts here estimate that the current world supply should hold out another two to three months. Perez said that he and his foreign minister, Reinaldo Figueredo, have been in daily contact with OPEC as well with presidents of oil-producers Mexico and Ecuador. Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and other oil-producing countries are against drastic price rises, arguing that they would ``suffer the consequences (later),'' Perez said.

DOC.HEAD: Markets Returning to Normal a Day After Freak Power Outage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: NEW throughout to UPDATE with oil prices and gold rising, stocks and bonds down, more details on power outage. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Stocks and bonds fell while oil and gold climbed today as traders refocused attention on turmoil in the Middle East and sought to escape the effects of a serious Wall Street power failure. But remnants remained of the freak Monday outage that waylaid the nation's financial center and forced thousands of workers to evacuate powerless skyscrapers on a sultry August afternoon. The Consolidated Edison utility said it could take days to restore power to portions of the area in southern Manhattan blacked out by a substation fire. The American Stock Exchange and New York commodities markets reopened this morning. But hundreds of commercial customers, including some major investment firms, were forced to scramble to function with a semblance of normality. Some such as County Natwest USA turned hotel rooms into makeshift trading desks. The outage also impeded the ability of some financial information gathering services to transmit data on commodities futures and options. But the financial world's main focus returned to its preoccupation before the freak outage: Iraq's destabilizing influence over world oil supplies. Stock and bond prices drifted lower and the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip stocks was down about 5 points to the 2,741 level around noontime. In oil trading, West Texas Intermediate crude contracts for September jumped 77 cents to $27 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Traders called the rise a reaction to signs that the effects of a cutoff of Kuwaiti and Iraqi oil are beginning to be felt in the United States, which imports half its oil. ``We're seeing indications that marginal imports might go elsewhere or stay at home,'' said John Hill, a broker with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures in New York. Oil's rise continued to push up gold prices, which surged over the $400 an ounce level Monday to a five-month high, a reflection of anxiety over higher inflation. Gold traded at $411 an ounce in London today, up from $404.60 late Monday. American Stock Exchange spokesman Bob Shabazian said power was restored by late afternoon Monday and that trading resumed at the normal 9:30 a.m. EDT opening today. He said two standby generators parked outside the Amex building on flatbed tractor-trailers were ready to be tapped in case the exchange suffered another outage. Shabazian also said the Amex was treating Monday as an official trading day and had calculated closing prices for all listed stocks, many of which continued to trade on other exchanges after the Amex closed prematurely. Based on the recalculations, he said the Amex index fell 1.32 Monday to 338.00, vs. 338.14 when power failed shortly after 1 p.m. Monday. Volume for the day totaled 9.75 million shares, vs. a normal full day of about 14 million. Closing prices are important in securities and commodities trading because investors place buy or sell orders based partly on what the previous day's price is. On the New York Commodity Exchange, trading resumed 30 minutes late this morning for gold and silver. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, trading resumed about two hours later than normal. Unlike the Amex, the Comex and Mercantile Exchange were treating today's trading as a continuation of the Monday session, and based opening prices on Friday's close. Unfilled orders at the time power failed were deleted. The disruptions in trading caused by the fire at a Con Edison power substation added to the pressure bearing on the markets since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2. Oil prices were rising sharply when trading shut down on the New York Merc, a key market for petroleum. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 30.20 points Monday to 2,746.78, but the broader market for stocks was mixed and trading was light because of the power outage. In Tokyo and London this morning, stock prices rose while the dollar was mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Mobil Agrees to Buy Australian Gas Stations, Refineries from Exxon
DOC.TEXT: Mobil Corp. has agreed to buy an Australian gasoline station network and the stake it doesn't already own in two refineries there from Exxon Corp., the companies said. Terms of the deal, which was announced late Monday, were not disclosed, but published reports have said the price was about $400 million. A spokesman for Mobil said from Fairfax, Va., that he could not comment on the value of the deal. Exxon, based in New York, also declined comment on the sale price. Mobil said it had agreed to buy the network of about 300 service stations and 90 fuel distributors owned by Exxon's Esso Australia Ltd. subsidiary as well as Esso's minority share of an Esso-Mobil joint venture that operates two refineries. The deal also includes an ocean-going petroleum products tanker and Allen Bros. Asphalt Ltd., a road sealing business. Allen E. Murray, Mobil's chairman and chief executive, said the purchase ``will advance our strategy of increasing strength in the world's fastest growing market for petroleum products.'' Exxon, on the other hand, said it accepted Mobil's proposal because it offered ``a unique opportunity compared with the value of the ongoing business.'' The sale does not involve any of Esso's crude oil and gas exploration and production interests in Australia nor its interests in the coal, minerals, shale oil or chemical industries. Exxon said its Esso unit will continue to be Australia's largest oil and gas production operator. Mobil said the acquisition will boost its market share in Australia to more than 20 percent from 14 percent. Mobil already owns a 700-unit network of gas stations there. The sale is expected to close toward the end of the year pending approval by Australian regulators and the completion of definitive contracts. The Mobil-Esso joint venture is Petroleum Refineries (Australia) Proprietary Ltd., which operates refineries with a capacity of 120,000 barrels a day in Altona and 65,000 barrels a day in Adelaide. Mobil Oil Australia owns 65 percent of the venture, while Esso Australia owns the remaining 35 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Penney Profits Fall, Limited's Rise in Quarter
By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Weakened consumer demand helped push J.C. Penney Co.'s profits down 15 percent in the second quarter, but specialty retailer Limited Inc. posted a 24 percent gain during the period, the companies reported Tuesday. Dallas-based Penney said net income in the 13-week period ended July 28 totaled $83 million, or 63 cents per share, down from $98 million, or 74 cents per share in the same period in 1989. Revenue rose 4 percent to $3.83 billion, from $3.67 billion a year earlier. Penney Chairman William R. Howell blamed the profit decline on a ``relatively low level of overall consumer demand,'' which he said has had a particularly negative impact on the company's sales in the Southeast and Midwest. He noted that as Penney adjusts its merchandise mix, the retailer is ``temporarily giving up some volume in conservative women's sportswear.'' Without the economic slowdown, Howell said, ``neither the refining of our merchandise mix nor the costs associated with the development of new specialty businesses would be particularly felt.'' For the year's first half, Penney said net income rose 5 percent to $237 million, or $1.84 per share, from $226 million, or $1.71 per share. In 1989, the company recorded an after-tax charge of $20 million for the discontinuation of its interactive television shopping service. Revenue for the first 26 weeks amounted to $7.11 billion, up 5 percent from $6.78 billion in the first half of 1989. The Limited Inc., based in Columbus, Oh., reported net income for the period ended July 28 of $79 million, or 22 cents a share, up from $63.8 million, or 18 cents a share a year earlier. The company said net sales increased 17 percent to $1.16 billion from $990 million in the year-ago period. Limited Chairman and Chief Executive Leslie H. Wexner credited the Victoria's Secret and Express units for their contribution to the company's results at a time of ``economic uncertainty.'' For the first half, net income totaled $141.34 milion, or 39 cents a share, up 21 percent from $178.97 million, or 30 cents a share in the first half of 1989. Net sales during the period rose 16 percent to $2.26 billion, from $1.95 billion a year earlier. Limited, which owns Limited, Express, Victoria's Secret, Henri Bendel, Lane Bryant, Abercrombie & Fitch, among others, operates 3,290 specialty apparel stores.

DOC.HEAD: Cable TV Giant Reports Smaller Loss in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Tele-Communications Inc., the cable TV and theater giant, said Tuesday its loss narrowed in the second quarter compared with a year ago while its revenue and operating income rose. The nation's largest cable television system operator said it lost $44 million, or 12 cents a share, in the three months ended June 30 compared with a loss of $64 million, or 18 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter rose 22 percent to $890 million from $726 million a year earlier. Operating income rose 21 percent to $173 million in the quarter from $143 million a year earlier. For the first six months, Tele-Communications said it lost $101 million, or 29 cents per share, compared with a loss of $115 million, or 33 cents per share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 26.8 percent to $1.75 billion for the six months from $1.38 billion over the same period last year. It said revenue from its cable TV operations climbed 33 percent for the first half due to a combination of higher subscriber levels, higher prices and system acquisitions. TCI provided basic cable TV services to about 8.3 million subscribers and pay-TV services to 6 million subscribers as of June 30. Revenue from its theater operations rose by about 4 percent, mostly because of increases in ticket prices. The company said its purchase of TCI-Cooke Systems, the purchase of a 42.5 percent indirect interest in SCI Holdings Inc. and a business deal involving United Artists Communications Inc. and the United Cable Television Corp. depressed its latest results. TCI also announced that it has arranged $200 million in longterm financing for a wholly owned subsidiary with a group of major insurance companies, led by The Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. The borrower, TCI Northeast Inc., serves about 815,000 base subscribers in Ohio, West Virginia and Pennsylvania. It is based in Pittsburgh.

DOC.HEAD: Government Takes up Sparkler Dumping Charges
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government has agreed to investigate charges that imported Chinese sparklers are being sold in the United States at less than fair value. The International Trade Commission said it ruled 4-0 Monday that there is reason to believe the Chinese imports theaten material damage to the domestic sparkler industry. That means the Commerce Department will open an anti-dumping investigation and hold hearings. The department's preliminary findings, due by Dec. 10, could lead to possible import duties on the Chinese sparklers equal to the amount of underpricing deemed unfair, the commission said. Two of the three U.S. sparkler makers, Elkton Sparkler Co. of North East, Md., and Diamond Sparkler Co. of Youngstown, Ohio, petitioned for the investigation. Government figures show that starting in 1988, Chinese imports captured more than half of the U.S. market. American companies made 148,000 sparklers and had 53.5 percent of the market in 1987, compared to 94,000 sparklers and 42.2 percent in 1989, the commission said. The Chinese market share rose from 46.1 percent in 1987 to 57.3 last year, while total usage dropped from 258,000 to 213,000, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Weinberg Plans to Retire From Top Post at Goldman Sachs
DOC.TEXT: Goldman Sachs & Co., the giant investment bank and brokerage, said Tuesday it would install a pair of executives to replace John L. Weinberg when he steps down later this year as senior partner and chairman. Weinberg, 65, disclosed Tuesday he plans to retire after 14 years as senior partner and chairman of the management committee at the end of the firm's fiscal year Nov. 30. The firm said its co-vice chairmen for the past three years, Robert E. Rubin and Stephen Friedman, will share Weinberg's titles after he retires. Naming a pair of executives to head a firm is becoming more common as the complexity of running businesses has escalated. The accounting firm Ernst & Young, for instance, named co-chief executives, William A. Grant and Robert J. Kelly, after the merger of the firms Arthur Young & Co. and Ernst & Whinney last year. The media and entertainment giant Time Warner Inc. also is run by co-chief executives, Steven J. Ross and Nicholas J. Nicholas Jr. The company was created in a merger earlier this year of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. Weinberg shared the job of chairman of the management committee when he was appointed to it in 1976 with John C. Whitehead. Weinberg has been the sole chairman since November 1984 after Whitehead retired and later became deputy secretary of state. Goldman Sachs is one of the last major privately held investment firms on Wall Street and has about 6,400 employees worldwide. It ranked third among investment firms behind Merrill Lynch & Co. and Shearson Lehman Brothers in terms of capital at the start of the year, according to the Securities Industry Association. The firm has established a solid reputation in mergers and acquisitions, equity underwriting, corporate advisory services, trading and research. Weinberg cited both the pressures of the job and his desire to pursue private interests as reasons for his decision to step down from a post he called ``the greatest job in the world.'' The senior partner's position ``is a seven days a week, 52 weeks a year responsibility and it requires a total commitment. The pressures are often very intense,'' he said in a statement. Weinberg said the firm is in excellent condition with a strong capital position and earnings running somewhat ahead of last year's results. He said its prospects for growth and development were bright. During his tenure at the top of the firm, Weinberg said its annual profits rose about tenfold and its equity capital grew to $2.3 billion from about $80 million at the end of 1976. Weinberg will continue as senior chairman of the firm, responsible for client relationships and other unspecified activities. In a joint statement, Rubin and Friedman said they ``look forward to continuing on the course that we have set and followed together.'' Weinberg joined Goldman Sachs in 1950 and became a partner in 1956. He was named senior partner and co-chairman of the management committee in 1976. Rubin, 51, joined Goldman Sachs in 1966, became a partner in 1971 and a member of the management committee in 1980. He formerly headed the trading and arbitrage division and previously oversaw the firm's commodity and foreign exchange subsidiary. Friedman, 52, also joined Goldman Sachs in 1966, was elected partner in 1973 and became a member of the management committee in 1982. He headed the mergers and acquisitions division for several years and had been co-head of the investment banking division. Rubin and Friedman served as co-heads of the fixed income division from 1985-88 and have been vice chairmen of the firm since 1987.

DOC.HEAD: President, Aides Discuss New Deficit Woes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be updated with material from Bush's 4 p.m. EDT news conference. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush temporarily turned his attention Tuesday to work on a budget compromise. White House aides say the disagreement with Congress is becoming more urgent because of the Mideast crisis. The president interrupted his Maine vacation for two days of Washington work focused on the huge U.S. effort to punish Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait. His first order of business was a meeting with advisers on how the crisis could hurt the economy and the budget. Bush turned away reporters' questions during a photo session at the start of his budget meeting. The president was joined by his chief of staff, John Sununu, and economic adviser Michael Boskin, but Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and budget director Richard Darman did not attend. The rapid increase in oil prices sparked by the Iraqi aggression has the potential of tripping up an already weak economy. And maintaining the huge U.S. force in Saudi Arabia could add billions of dollars to the Pentagon's annual budget. Brady, while not predicting a recession, has said the slow growth rate of the American economy could fall ``closer to zero'' as the higher oil prices take full effect. Brady decided not to interrupt his own trip to take part in the talks. Brady, a key member of the budget team, was in the Midwest on a two-day campaign swing for Republican candidates. Meanwhile, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said, ``We think it's even more important that we reach an agreement now because there needs to be a unity of purpose in this country, not only about the conflict in the gulf, but also about our spending issues and about where the budget is going.'' One of the many sticking points in the budget talks, which are nearly four months old, is the level of military spending. Bush requested $303 billion in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, but the Senate has approved only $289 billion and the House Armed Services Committee has endorsed a $283 billion budget. The White House and congressional conservatives plan to use Iraq as an argument for a larger military budget. The budget talks will resume next month, when Congress returns from its summer recess. Bush has repeatedly expressed his frustration with the talks, which he initiated in May. The two sides are nowhere near an agreement despite Bush's ending his ``no new taxes'' campaign pledge. Bush and the Republicans have been criticized for suggesting higher taxes on alcoholic beverages and a proposal to limit the income tax deduction for state and local taxes. The Democrats, meanwhile, refrained from putting forward any substantive budget proposals until after the recess. The president last week indicated he would step up his rhetorical attacks on the Democrats, but refrained at the time because it coincided with his ordering of U.S. troops to the Middle East. The goal of the talks is to reduce the federal deficit at least $50 billion in fiscal 1991, more than has been accomplished in any previous budget pact. Even if that were accomplished, the spending plan would not meet the mandate of the Gramm-Rudman budget law. That law calls for a fiscal 1991 deficit no higher than $64 billion. According to the latest administration estimates, the deficit next year will be about $169 billion, not counting the $60 billion or more needed to continue the bailout of the savings and loan industry. If a budget agreement is reached, the legislation would stretch out Gramm-Rudman's timetable for a balanced budget. Instead of keeping that goal in sight for fiscal 1993, it would be postponed until fiscal 1995 or later.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Rise, Led By Soybeans
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly higher Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, largely erasing the previous day's losses in a rally led by the soybean complex. Gerald Zusel, manager of Balfour Maclaine Corp.'s trading-floor operations at the exchange, said the runup mostly reflected large-scale buying that appeared to have originated with a single speculator in the soybean market. Zusel could account for no change in supply-and-demand factors that might have prompted the buying. But other analysts said soybeans were supported by indications that Spain bought Brazilian soybeans overnight and by prospects for sales of U.S. soybeans to Taiwan and South Korea. A drop in supplies of soybeans certified deliverable against the August contract also boosted the soybean market, analysts said. At the close, wheat futures were 3 cents to 4\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.79{ a bushel; corn was unchanged to 1\ cents higher with September at $2.45\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to { cent lower with September at $1.16 a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 9 cents higher with August at $6.10 a bushel.

Stock prices closed slightly higher today in moderate trading, erasing earlier losses on favorable news from the Mideast. Jon Groveman, head of equity trading for the New York brokerage Ladenburg, Thalmann & Co., said the market rallied on the news that Jordan's King Hussein was on his way to the United States to confer with President Bush over the Iraqi situation. ``We've been inundated with negative headlines. With the market oversold like this, people are looking for an excuse to buy,'' Groveman said. Analysts also said the stock market was boosted by gains in the bond market and a drop in oil futures prices, also due to Hussein's trip and the lack of any fresh bad news from the Middle East. The markets received mixed signals on the economy this morning in a government report. The Commerce Department said July retail sales rose 0.1 percent, short of analysts' expectations. But the department revised upward the sales figure for June to a 1.1 percent increase from 0.5 percent. Stock trading was reported to be near normal today following Monday's curtailed session that stemmed from a power outage in Manhattan's financial district. The American Stock Exchange, which was forced to halt trading shortly after 1 p.m. EDT Monday, opened for business at the regular time. Most major brokerage houses whose operations were curtailed by the blackout reported their trading had returned to normal, but some still were operating with limited phone lines or in makeshift offices. The NYSE was unaffected by the outage, which was caused by a fire in a utility company substation.

DOC.HEAD: UAW Votes on Tentative Contract at Flint Parts Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lead planned after vote is announced. Voting was to begin at 2 p.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: United Auto Workers union members in Flint voted Tuesday on a proposed contract with General Motors Corp., which has been forced to idle several other plants because of labor unrest at Flint. The tentative contract was reached Monday afternoon, the fifth day of a strike called over local health and safety matters, work speedups and the use of outside companies to perform work that unionized GM employees could do. Voting at UAW Local 659 began Tuesday afternoon. Details of the tentative agreement covering about 2,800 people weren't announced before the voting. The strike at Flint has affected other GM plants because of the company's reliance on ``just-in-time'' distribution, a system that delivers parts and components to assembly plants frequently within hours of them being installed in new vehicles. By Tuesday, the Flint strike had shut down five assembly plants in Michigan, Ohio and Louisiana, and portions of some component factories, resulting in at least 17,000 layoffs. ``We could certainly see additional impact this week,'' GM spokesman John Maciarz said Tuesday. Tuesday's vote comes as the UAW negotiates national contracts with GM, Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp., to replace agreements that expire Sept. 14. The agreements cover more than 450,000 workers, including about 300,000 GM employees. It is unusual for the UAW to begin a local strike during national contract talks. Harley Shaiken, a labor professor at the University of California at San Diego, said the selective strike may be a preview of the union's strategy later on. Analysts also say the Flint strike sends a strong indication that the UAW will choose to concentrate its national negotiating efforts at GM. Under an arrangement known as pattern bargaining, an agreement reached at the target company is then presented to the other two of the Big Three automakers for minor customizing before being put up for ratification. ``If GM weren't going to be the target, it wouldn't make much sense to have this demonstration strike at GM,'' Shaiken said.
